PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of standing order 48a, as amended by sessional order, be suspended for this sitting as would prevent (a) the Speaker proposing the question-That the House do now adjourn-at 10.15 p.m.; (b) the Speaker interrupting the debate at 11 p.m., and (c) a Minister requiring that the debate be extended until 11.10 p.m.

This motion is just to make available more time this evening for the purposes of debate. Honourable members have asked me to arrange this. I give honourable members the undertaking that the normal Wednesday evening off will be adhered to for next week, so honourable members can make arrangements for next Wednesday night to do whatever they wish in terms of visiting restaurants, seeing their families or whatever they would like to do. I assure them that we will not sit next Wednesday evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The emotional concern of the Leader of the House (Mr Young) about the needs of all of us late at night is becoming extreme, even somewhat hypocritical. It is really quite extraordinary that the Leader of the House has come in here and moved this motion on the Wednesday of the second last sitting week, at a time when we have told him that we are quite prepared to sit for at least another couple of weeks in December. There are a range of matters that affect the people of Australia. The Government has not even spoken about the industrial troubles in Victoria; the industrial difficulties on the waterfront are now placing our exports at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that the Government is in a mess. We have seen the very irrational behaviour of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in Question Time and about the place over the past couple of weeks. We know that there are difficulties in the Australian economy. Those of us on this side of the House who spend our time out there in the electorates meeting people, instead of trying to sit down here in glorious isolation, as the Government and its bureaucracy tend to do, know how serious is the economic condition of the country. We know that it is important that the Parliament meets to consider these circumstances. If there were the opportunity, we would like to be able to tell the Leader of the House about the reasons for introducing, for example, a mini-Budget. It is quite obvious that the blow-out of the deficit will lead to enormous problems for people. Only today we have heard about the increase in home lending rates. Now that interest rates have gone up for people trying to borrow to fund their own homes, I would have thought that the Leader of the House, instead of making us sit later tonight, would have suggested that we might sit for a couple of extra weeks so that we would have an opportunity to talk about a range of issues which we would be delighted to canvass in this place.

I see the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) guffawing over there. The people of his electorate are worried about the returns on the grain profit and the extent to which they will be able to survive. The average mums and dads are worried about where their children will work next year. It is all very well for the Australian Labor Party-it is not worried about those things. Government members in office are more concerned about enjoying the perks of office. Frankly, staying up late at night does not seem to be one of the ways in which they can enhance their own image in the scheme of things. We see no reason, even if the Leader of the House wants to stay up late, why we should stay up with him. For that reason we intend to oppose this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-One of the reasons that we thought we ought to bring the session to an end is that, now that the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) has put in the blackball against the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), it will be a very embarrassing place for him and for the honourable member for Kooyong. It is a replay of a few years ago of the late Black Jack McEwen. Poor little Billy McMahon did all that phenomenal work for Australia over the years but he was blackballed by the then Leader of the National Party of Australia from being Prime Minister. Now we have another star on the horizon ready to serve this country as Prime Minister, the honourable member for Kooyong, and the Leader of the National Party wants to stop him. It is unbelievable. It is almost a breach of privilege to think that the Leader of the National Party met with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). Some people think he stood over him and said: `Look, we have had enough of this, John. You stay there because we can handle you, but we don't know about the colt from Kooyong. We don't know what he is going to get up to with all his fancy mates if he gets back in there as Leader of the Opposition. We have had enough'.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought, considering the position those opposite find themselves in at the end of this session, that they will all have their hands up for a very speedy adjournment of this session because they have a lot of work and a lot of thinking to do over the Christmas period. We want to facilitate that. We want to see those opposite get back into their electorates and back into their Party meetings to try to thrash out the enormous philosophical problems between the Nationals and the Liberals. What a bunch! Fancy anybody considering putting that mob into government the way it is at the moment. No wonder the Leader of the National Party said that his discussion with Mr Howard was confidential. He would want to keep it confidential. Could anyone imagine what he said to him in good old Country Party fashion? It would not take much summing up of what he had to say and the ramifications of what he had to say.

So the poor old colt from Kooyong, who usually comes in early in the morning and says his prayers with us, is missing this morning because members of the National Party have put the blackball on him and said: `We are not going to have you back'. It is a great relationship between the coalition partners as they sit in Opposition. Not only is the Liberal Party in absolute and total disarray, but now we find their country cousins, the Nats, following Joh's orders of laying down the law of what will be the relationship and who will be the leader of this once great coalition. All I can say is that we will finish our business next week and send those opposite back to their electorates, their Party rooms and their families and let them dwell on it. Let us see whether they can sort out their problems between now and 17 February when we come back. Let us see whether we can get a proper debate going in this country on some of the major issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let the people decide.

—I cannot understand why the honourable member supported the Leader of the National Party. The honourable member knows that the honourable member for Kooyong was going to put him back on the front bench. There is another brilliant career rusting on the back benches because the Leader of the National Party has stopped in his tracks this move by the honour- able member for Kooyong, who was just emerging again for the fifteenth time in his political career to become the leader with all his ideas about what he was going to put into practice for Australians. The honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) was going to be one of the honourable member for Kooyong's couriers. He was going to be one of his spokespersons on the front bench. The Leader of the National Party stopped it.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) was going to be elevated to the front bench. There is another one whose career has been stopped dead in its tracks just as he was again ready to emerge. He is a former Minister for the Army, someone much loved by our defence forces, someone who could have done a much better job than those serving on the front bench. Their leader is stopping them from ever playing the sort of role that they were born to play. I think that when those opposite get back into the National Party room to discuss their problems they should have a chat to their Leader, and say: `Look, there might be some changes made by the honourable member for Kooyong that could be beneficial to the National Party. We could have Tom McVeigh and Bob Katter back on the front bench'. My God! Even if there were not any more talent it would be a lot more colourful! It would be something with which to adorn the front benches of this Parliament.

The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and people like him have plenty of time. Honourable members have to remember that, when the honourable member for Gippsland was asked to run for parliament, he asked: `What's that?'. Opposition members said: `It's a big building in Canberra. You'll like it. They'll make you famous'. He said: `Yes, I'll run'. They said: `You have to join a political party'. He asked: `What's that?'. So he ended up joining the Nationals the day before they put him into parliament. So he can wait a while. He is not as conditioned as some of the older blokes on the back benches. Honourable members opposite should have a chat with the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and tell him that other things ought to be taken into consideration when we are talking about this parliamentary session. Sitting tonight will not cause brain damage even to members of the National Party. So we will sit tonight and we will have next Wednesday night off.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Young's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Bill 1986 is probably one of the most significant pieces of legislation tabled in this House in recent years relating to the Australian Public Service and the manner in which governments of the day should be responsible for the control of their servants. For that reason, the Opposition is of the view that the proposals contained in this legislation fall short in one specific area, that is, to return to the government of the day the ultimate responsibility and control over its Public Service. For that reason I seek to amend the legislation in accordance with the following second reading amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted to incorporate the principle of `no work as directed no pay' for those Commonwealth employees who engage in-

(1) the performance of work in a manner different from that in which it is customarily performed, or the adoption of a practice in relation to work, the result of which is a restriction or limitation on, or a delay in, the performance of the work;
(2) a ban, limitation or restriction on the performance of work or on acceptance or offering for work, or
(3) an unauthorised failure or refusal by persons to attend for work or an unauthorised failure or refusal to perform any work at all by persons who attend for work'.

This amendment has been tabled because one of the first actions of the Hawke Labor Government when it came into power was to amend the appropriate legislation to remove those penal clauses from the Public Service Act and five other Acts which required that persons employed by the Commonwealth would be subject to no work as directed, no pay provisions enacted in this Parliament back in 1980 deliberately to enable relevant Commonwealth authorities to withhold pay from staff refusing to work as directed. The Public Service Board in its report of 1983-84 made it very clear to the Government that it did not support the proposal to amend the legislation to remove those vital clauses. Subsequently actions by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and other trade unions in the Public Service area demonstrated clearly that an employer must have the power to control the work force when members refuse to carry out the duties required of them.

Members of this House will recall that early last year there were major Public Service strikes over wages issues. At that time substantial costs, approximately $80m, were incurred by the Government, and on its behalf the Australian people, because public servants across Australia refused to accept the decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which had rejected the 8.3 per cent pay claim made by the unions. These strikes required the Government to reconsider its position and go back to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and a higher wage was given as a result. That particular strike action has played a major part in ensuring a continual increase in wages but no change in productivity. A significant increase in unemployment has followed, and of course it has made Australia even less competitive on world markets than it would otherwise have been. For all of these reasons the Opposition is of the view that this amendment should be carried by the House. It will ensure a total package rather than that currently before us. Although the legislation has substantial advantages which the Opposition supports, it does fall short on this very important point; namely, it does not give to the Commonwealth the control which it must have over its work force.

The legislation must be seen against the somewhat extravagant commitments of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to streamline and rationalise the Public Service which he made in his address to the nation on 11 June last. On that occasion he said:

. . . under successive governments, including my own, the Federal Public Service has continued, inexorably, to grow in numbers . . . We will take steps to halt this expansion, to produce a leaner, more efficient Service.
There will be a streamlining and rationalisation of some existing functions and agencies.

This legislation, if judged against those comments, regrettably falls far short of the expectations of this Parliament, of the Opposition and of the Australian people. As usual, the Prime Minister's rhetoric has not lived up to reality. Despite his commitment to produce a leaner Public Service, it has continued to grow, even in the 1986-87 Budget by a further 0.3 per cent per 607.5 staff years in this year alone at a time when he has said in this Parliament that he proposes to reduce the size of the Public Service by 2,000 this financial year. In the last four Budgets the Hawke Government increased the size of the Public Service by no less than 3.5 per cent, or nearly 15,000 new positions. Yet he has the gall to talk about the inexorable expansion of the Public Service when it has all been as a result of his Government's policies. In contrast to the activities of this Government, the Fraser Government, over eight years and under very difficult economic circumstances for much of that period, effectively reduced the Public Service by 0.12 per cent per annum.

The second great omission from this legislation is the evidence of the Government's intention to streamline and rationalise existing functions and agencies. Despite the passage of time, no evidence whatsoever has been brought before this Parliament which would demonstrate to us that the Government is serious about transferring functions out of the public sector to the private sector or transferring functions from the Commonwealth public sector to States and local government. Much has been said but the runs are simply not on the board. The Prime Minister has totally ignored the fact that significant reductions in both the size and the cost of the Public Service can be achieved only by a systematic reduction in functions. That is what this Government has failed to do. In the four Budgets that it has brought before this Parliament it has continually increased the functions of the Public Service. Every week we sit we are passing more legislation with attendant regulations. This month alone we have been party to no less than two new statutory authorities being written into the statute book. Is that the record of a government that expects people to believe that it means what it says when it talks about a tighter and more efficient system of public administration?

When the Government speaks of doing more with less, it ignores the salient fact that the civil service are the servants of the government of the day and, by extension, of the Australian people. They do not just create work; they do not just create programs. They are acting in response to the policies of government. Members of the Opposition are sick and tired of hearing the continuous innuendo that somehow or other the public sector is able to increase willy-nilly when in fact the responsibility for increasing the public sector at all times rests with the government of the day and its approach to public administration. It ignores the fact that the Public Service must implement programs that are initiated by the Government. Therefore, if the size of the Public Service is to be reduced, so must be the impact of those programs. Unless it has the courage to identify program priorities and to reduce systematically the introduction of additional expenditure, there is a very real limit to being able to do more with less. Beyond that point, no effective system of administration can possibly survive. What is therefore lacking is any evidence that this Government is determined to restrain its socialist ethic.

Also in this legislation there is a conspicuous absence of any proposals to negotiate with the States on the transfer of functions which can be better managed at that level of government. Nor has the Government apparently considered the need to rationalise and restructure departments to minimise duplication between programs. I have asked before in this House and I will repeat: How can the Government justify in excess of 130 income support and maintenance programs which are currently being administered by no less than 10 different Federal departments of state? It is obvious that there is massive duplication and substantial additional administrative costs, and these are all requiring additional labour to carry out work which is not necessary in the first place. If, as the Government proposes, we are to have concepts such as efficiency dividends for each department, let us see members of the Government come into this House and have the courage to say: `We expect efficiency to follow because we are not increasing resources on the one hand, but we will decrease the demands on those resources on the other'. With great regret, we continue to wait in vain to see such action taken by this Government.

The legislation also fails in a number of very important areas. We still have no coherent management philosophy for the Public Service. We do not see in this legislation or elsewhere a systematic training of public servants in management. While substantial improvements have taken place, especially in the context of the Senior Executive Service, the fact is that the area of middle management, which comprises classes 8 to 11 of the Public Service, is still not being given the degree of consideration that it needs. I have said before and I repeat it: Until we have a system which encourages people in middle management to improve their qualifications and experience and until we are prepared to apply a regular system to ensure adequate review arrangements for people who are eligible for promotion, regardless of who they may be and from what department they may come-until a system of annual assessment is put in place-we will not be able to assure the people of Australia that senior management will be able to be drawn from the best people in that cadre within the public sector which is obviously vital for maintaining efficiency and effectiveness in the longer term.

One of the other areas which again, I regret, the socialist ethic has prevented this Government from moving in is that of giving individual officers greater responsibility for decisions and for the outcome of those decisions. They must be more prepared to allow managers to manage. We have seen through this Parliament over the last four years a raft of restrictive legislation greater than any that has come to this Parliament in the last 50 years. It is restrictive legislation which affects not only the private sector; equally importantly it dominates the efficiency and effectiveness of the public sector. It in fact runs quite contrary to freeing up the system, letting managers manage. I will come back to that later in this debate.

In addition, we do not see in this legislation any proposals to give individual public servants greater incentives to improve the administrative system or for individuals to perform to their maximum capacity. There is an absence of measures by which personal performance can be measured in terms of resources in relation to output and stated objectives. But the greatest shortcoming is that, until we are prepared to give our public servants responsibility for the actions which they carry out, we will never be able to get a system in place which is cost efficient and effective, which according to the Government is meant to be the purpose of this legislation and one of the reasons why it was introduced in the first place.

Nevertheless, I have to emphasise that the Opposition supports all the administrative changes which have been introduced. For example, we were delighted-although, again, there is no mention of this in this legislation-with the proposals that the 71,000 keyboard and clerical assistants in the Australian Public Service, who are currently employed in no fewer than 48 distinct classifications with some 160 separate pay points, should be changed significantly to achieve greater integration, on the one hand, and a reduction in the number of separate work levels, on the other. The highly likely outcome of that will be that managers will be better able and more appropriately to use the resources which have been allocated to them. The objective of that, of course, is for departments to be able to organise their work more efficiently and there will be greater flexibility in the use of staffing resources. Nevertheless, these matters are still in the process of negotiation. The Prime Minister told us that in the House two months ago. We have heard nothing in the meantime, nor is there any indication in this legislation of the Government's intentions in that particular area.

We are also told in relation to this Bill that the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act will be repealed. Again, this is an initiative which the Opposition supports. Under the CE(RR) Act there were no fewer than four appeal points by which people who were being asked to leave the Service for various reasons could appeal against those decisions. Under these proposals there will be only one appeal and, of course, that will significantly improve efficiency, effectiveness and the ability of managers-above all, of departmental managers. We believe this is one of the major improvements in this legislation-to determine how governments can remove labour which is redundant or no longer efficient and effective under the definitions contained in the Act. One of the problems in the past has been that the removal of public servants has been slow, complicated and costly, featuring long lead times, extensive paper work and, as I said, multiple appeal points as well.

Nevertheless, this legislation addresses redundancy provisions. Again this is a step in the right direction. Currently it takes a minimum of three months to remove staff declared surplus to the Public Service. Normally there would be detailed consultation with the unions, extensive efforts to redeploy staff and considerable delays, at times as long as 12 months. During this time, of course, officers continue to receive their full pay. Now staff will continue to have the right to appeal against decisions relating to their redundancy, but the appeal system will be much tighter and, I have not the slightest doubt, more efficient compared with what we have had in the past. Under the new arrangements, Secretaries-not the Public Service Board-will be primarily responsible for notifying and consulting with unions on potential redundancies. Voluntary retrenchment payment arrangements will be brought into place and only if the voluntary arrangements are not successful will the redundancy provisions have their full impact. Staff will be identified as excess and when that takes place there will be no appeal mechanism.

I should mention the provisions in the legislation for invalidity retirement. Staff who are totally incapacitated for work, or partly incapacitated but cannot be redeployed to suitable alternative duties, may be retired on invalidity grounds. That has always been a provision in the Public Service Act. However, superannuation benefits on invalidity retirement are more generous than for ordinary retirement. In fact, an officer aged 55 with 20 years service receives a government financed pension of 50 per cent of salary if he or she is retired on invalidity grounds, as against 36 per cent if he or she retires voluntarily. As was brought to the attention of this Parliament by the Waste Watch Committee-and I shall refer to this matter later today when the appropriate legislation comes before us-the whole situation relating to early invalidity retirement is a scandal which this Government has taken far too long to recognise. Only now, four years down the track, do we see any serious attempt being made to improve and control the current situation.

The provisions in the Act which relate to inefficiency are also significant. Under current legislative arrangements staff who are inefficient and cannot be retained at their level may be declared by the Public Service Board as suitable for redeployment elsewhere in the Public Service. The very fact that one has to seek to redeploy somebody whom one has already determined to be inefficient is a contradiction in terms. Even if another department can be found that is silly enough to take on those persons, they are still known to be inefficient and therefore ineffective. One of the important elements in this legislation is that the definition of inefficiency is more clearly enunciated and the powers vested now in departmental management will be substantially greater than they were previously. When an officer has been given a formal warning and the opportunity over a three-month period to reach the necessary standard of work performance but has failed to do so, the Secretary will be empowered to reduce the officer's classification or to require him to retire. There is a limited right of appeal against such a decision, but nevertheless the powers and responsibilities will be vested in supervisors to counsel staff whose work performance is not up to standard.

That is why I return to the point that I have mentioned twice already. We must have in place an efficient system of annual assessments as there is automatically a counselling mechanism. It is a bit late when a person is about to lose his job, allegedly for inefficiency, to then tell that person what was wrong. If there is an annual system of assessment it is the responsibility of supervisory staff to make sure that officers are informed throughout their career as to how they are performing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like the armed services.

—Yes, just like the defence services. I would recommend that the Public Service Board look at the Department of Defence's assessment criteria for officers and NCOs, if it has not already done so. I have always regarded the armed services' system as most adequate. There is also provision in the legislation for increments. Again, under the old provisions, officers believed they had a right to increments, irrespective of their efficiency and effectiveness. I am not totally satisfied with the proposals here in relation to improving and tightening up the provision of increments. They will now be based on an officer's diligence, efficiency and attendance to duty. Of course, those are perfectly appropriate criteria on which to draw. But, unfortunately, where the Government and the Public Service Board have not been prepared to grasp the nettle is in considering implications of concepts such as merit pay.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier the Opposition believes we must develop a Public Service where individual officers can feel in a very real and tangible sense that their efficiency will result in promotion or other rewards. In many departments regrettably, despite the provisions in the Act that promotion should be based only on merit, many other factors are taken into account, with the result that efficient officers are not necessarily promoted and not necessarily paid consistent with their worth to that department and to the public sector management overall. The United States in recent years has been carrying out some very interesting experiments in relation to merit pay. I do not resile from the fact that it is a complex area, but I would like to have seen in this Act a provision that departmental management should have the responsibility of determining, within guidelines of merit pay, mechanisms within departments which can make that a reality. Once we do that, we open up a whole new spectrum of opportunities for individual officers. It is not just a case of doing one's duty, which we hear so much about; officers of merit who are doing a good job at all levels of the public sector will also feel that they can gain as a result.

Perhaps the greatest area where merit pay could be utilised is in the social welfare area. Throughout Australia, in virtually every town, Commonwealth Employment Service officers are doing work of a similar nature, irrespective of where in the community they may be. It is therefore possible in comparative terms to determine efficiency and effectiveness and product- ivity criteria on an office by office basis. Management could, therefore, develop a method by which officers who have contributed considerably towards the achievement of good results ought to be in a position to feel, at the end of a specific period, that they have gained some reward. Napoleon, the great General and Emperor of France, made the observation: `If my generals want more medals and it makes them better soldiers, let them have more medals'. I simply say to this Government that in this legislation it has missed the opportunity to place in law provisions by which officers of merit, irrespective of the promotion system, will be able to gain more salary. The best way in which that can be achieved, of course, is by a flattening out of the annual incremental arrangements so that officers of merit can leapfrog on the incremental scale without necessarily having to achieve promotion if it is not possible for other reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we give them medals too?

—Whether public servants should have medals is another matter. The point I am making still stands: Merit needs to be rewarded publicly. A system that requires undue equality automatically reduces the capacity of individuals to demonstrate where they have been able to make a worthwhile contribution to the improvement of efficiency and effectiveness in the system.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area which the Government has totally failed to control is its burgeoning bureaucracy, particularly in relation to the establishment of statutory authorities. I have noted on just a rough analysis that we now have in excess of 60 statutory authorities established by the Hawke Government and there are at least another two or three coming through the legislative system at present. It is amazing to me that the Government's own paper, `Labor and the Quality of Government' which the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) was a participant in writing before the Government was elected, emphasised that statutory authorities would be established only under the most specific and tight criteria. What it said was that under most circumstances additional functions should be placed with departments, not with new statutory authorities. If ever there is an example of a government not living up to the principles which it has enunciated, surely it is in the area of establishing statutory authorities. This Government has made an art form of them. What it tends to forget is that statutory authorities continually increase the level of the relative cost of government, on the one hand, and the impact of regulations, on the other.

I said earlier that in the area of regulation there are two basic problems: Firstly, the impact on the private sector and, secondly, the impact on the public sector. Referring to the latter, the constraints on efficient management, on allowing managers to manage, in the public sector are now controlled by the following organisations and policies: The Department of Finance regulations and procedures, the Public Service Board Acts and regulations, the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services procedures, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, Senate Estimates Committees, union staff associations, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, clients' rights, the Auditor-General, Attorney-General, accommodation controlled by the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services, work loads, technology, the Ombudsman, the Human Rights Commission, grievance processes for officers and employees, equal opportunity legislation, review avenues under the Public Service Regulations-even though they will be amended in this current legislation-the impact of the High Court of Australia, the Federal Court of Australia, and the whole administrative review machinery. Other initiatives which have constrained management are joint management reviews, joint staff reviews, management improvement plans, corporate plans, increasing mobility in the senior executive service, the automatic data processing strategic plan, staff associations and employment conditions.

Many of the changes which have taken place in recent years are intrinsically good and are based on recommendations made by the Public Accounts Committee when I was Chairman. The Opposition supports those initiatives. However, in many cases they have carried with them rafts of regulations which have controlled management in the Public Service: `Thou shalt do X, Y and Z'. Because it is usually a directive they have taken from management the capacity to determine to what extent efficiency and effectiveness will be neutralised or reduced by having to introduce changes which are dominated by outside bodies which are not direct parties to the decision making process. That is one of the greatest costs we are seeing in the public sector and one which I advise this Government to take very seriously indeed.

I turn to the question of business regulation. The Business Regulation Review Unit, established by the Hawke Government under the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, has estimated the total cost to the economy of business regulation to be between 9 per cent and 19 per cent of gross domestic product. It claims that some 16,400 public servants are involved in advising on, preparing and servicing business regulation. This does not include staff of the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Bureau of Statistics or various other departments of state. The salary cost to the Commonwealth, based on the low figure of 16,400, is about $700m per annum. In addition to that, there are State and local government personnel involved in regulation, probably constituting a figure more than double that of the Commonwealth personnel. Therefore, that would cost approximately $1.8 billion to $3.6 billion.

The effects of regulation distort the allocation of resources, reduce efficiency, distort consumer investor behaviour and thereby shift expenditure patterns, increase costs and cause lower productivity, which therefore makes overall management, both in the public and private sectors, that much more difficult. No one suggests that all regulation is bad per se. What I am saying is that it is the responsibility of the Government not just to take the evidence given to it by its own Business Regulation Review Unit but also to put in place effective management tools within departments and within this Parliament to ensure that regulation can be effectively reviewed from time to time. The Government should see that what we have on the statute books is relevant to the times and relevant to the problems facing Australia today.

The problem for which this Government is totally responsible is ensuring that we have a public sector, both in terms of departments of state and statutory authorities, which is lean while at the same time efficient and which is able to deliver the services expected and needed by the Government to encourage the private sector to fulfil its undoubted role of helping to pull Australia out of its current economic crisis, which has been created by, among other things, this Government, which took four Budgets to realise that, by consistently increasing the size of the public sector at the cost of the private sector, it has put in place an economic time bomb. We cannot run a country such as Australia where one in four members of the entire work force is paid for from the taxation of the people.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) talks about runs on the board. It is in this area of Public Service reform that the Hawke Labor Government definitely has runs on the board. As the honourable member for Bradfield has acknowledged, the reforms outlined in the legislation before us have the support of the Opposition. On behalf of the Government I thank the Opposition for its support and I thank the honourable member for Bradfield for some of the very constructive points that have been made in this debate. I may not agree with all the points, but at least it is a step forward to find legislators having constructive ideas about the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is part of the ongoing analysis that this Government is applying to the Public Service. The Government is looking at how the Public Service delivers services to the public and how it responds to the Government. The Public Service has the responsibility for implementing policies, and it is its effectiveness in this area that is examined in this legislation.

What we are seeing in the Public Service now is a managerial revolution. This Government, since it has been in government, has had a very constructive attitude towards the Public Service. It initially produced a White Paper which outlined many areas for Public Service reform. Legislation followed and from that legislation we have seen many changes. In the past few years we have put emphasis on the importance of top level management. We have provided training, rotated departmental heads after five years and developed a proper career senior executive service, free of political patronage, which places great emphasis on management ability, appraisal of performance and flexibility of deployment in accordance with Government priorities. The Government has also opened senior levels to outsiders and has brought in an equal opportunity program which I support.

It is essential that the Government is always looking for ways in which all sectors of the community can perform more efficiently, effectively and economically. It is therefore essential that we look at the Public Service. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said, we need a Public Service which is responsive to the needs of the Government and the community, and one which is cost effective at the same time as providing a high quality of service to the people and to the Government. When the Government is looking at the Public Service it does not do so in a critical way. It attempts to look constructively at the operations of the Public Service.

The Government does not look at the Public Service, as many members of the Opposition do, in terms of numbers but in terms of its functions, the roles it performs and how it carries our those roles. The Government acknowledges that the Public Service has an essential role to play in our community. It is critical that we do not simply get bogged down in numbers, but look at the essential question of who benefits and who loses by each proposal. If we are to cut back numbers in the Public Service, we need to look at who will benefit and who will lose. Many of the dries on the other side of the House see this question in very simple terms. They do not clearly define the role they see for the Public Service.

The Public Service has a very constructive role in this community. When we look at spurs to efficiency, we see that there are very many. It is difficult, when one is doing an analysis of the efficiency of the Public Service, to define exactly what efficiency is. There are many watch-dogs of how the Public Service goes about its work. There are not only the members in this Parliament, but we have also got the Auditor-General, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, freedom of information, judicial review, journalists writing stories about the Public Service, ministerial direction and the public being great critics of the Public Service. But basically the bottom line is always: Is the Public Service delivering what it should to the public? I think by and large it is. Most public servants are to be congratulated for the work they do in delivering services to the people.

I see that particularly in the Australian Capital Territory where we have a Commonwealth department that has to provide all local government and State government-type functions. Commonwealth public servants take responsibility for administering everything, from garbage to a state school system. By and large, they do it effectively. But it is essential that government continually monitor the role the Public Service is taking. When we look at the relative merits of public and private sector efficiency there is no clear empirical evidence that comes out really on one side or the other that the Public Service is more efficient or that the private sector is more efficient. A lot of research has been done. I will quote some of that research which has been outlined in a paper which has been presented recently by the Chairman of the Public Service Board. He states:
There is no clear evidence for either side.

This is in part for methodological reasons-it is hard to get like organisations to compare and even then the same facts can be read very differently. This is evident, for example in the repeated reinterpretations in the academic literature of the analysis of comparative efficiency of Ansett and TAA.
However, the overall findings of reviews of the factual research in this field all tend to reach similar conclusions.
A judgment just cannot be made one way or the other. He quotes various researchers' reports. He states:
Thus Millward and Parker draw together their extensive and thorough review of numerous case studies with this statement:

`. . . there is no systematic evidence that public enterprises are less cost effective than private firms. The poorer performance, in this respect, exhibited in studies of refuse collection'-and I might add in parenthesis that the study of garbage collection has a peculiar fascination for right wing economists-
I think we can endorse that-
`and water supply . . . has to be balanced against the absence of any significant difference in Canadian railways and Australian airways and the superior performance in US electric power.
That was from an article in 1983 by Millward and Parker. He continues:
Their only reservation in coming to this conclusion was the general narrowness of the data base in which most studies have been conducted.

A similar conclusion was reached . . . in a study of Canadian Crown Corporations carried out for the Royal Commission on Economic Union and Development Prospects for Canada. Parker in his review of the evidence is similarly inclined. Another reviewer, Goodsell, in his 1983 book states:

To summarise, available comparative data on the efficiency, costs, and quality of services in refuse collection, hospitals, transportation, utilities, and insurance show that whereas at some times business seems superior, at other times government appears to perform better. In still other instances the two surveys are mixed but by no means convincingly supportive of the common contention that the private sector always functions better, even according to economic criteria.

These reports do highlight a lot of the stupid comments that have been made about the relative inefficiencies of private and public sectors in our community. Quite obviously the public sector does perform very efficiently. The legislation before us today is in no way a criticism of the efficiency of the Public Service. What this legislation today is all about is adding to the efficiency of the Public Service. There is no doubt that the Public Service is becoming more output-oriented. The changes going on in the Public Service over the last few years have been quite incredible.

I have talked about a managerial revolution. I think that has, indeed, been the fact. Departments are developing much more clearly defined goals and strategies to achieve them. It is obviously very difficult to measure their achievement in social goals. The Public Service is now working on performance indicators to back up quantified evidence that considerable productivity gains are definitely being made. At the same time the Public Service is devolving responsibility and moving all unnecessary layers of hierarchy leading to much flatter structures that can be, therefore, much more responsive both to government and to the public.

This legislation is looking at areas of inefficiency. The processes the Government has gone through in bringing this legislation through are to be commended because the Government has consulted as fully as possible with public sector unions in the development of these initiatives. I would not say that all the union members support every one of the proposals before us today, but we have not seen any outright criticism. I thank members of the Public Service for the responsible attitude they have taken to the legislation. They have not been afraid to look at themselves and their own work practices.

Some of the highlights of the measures in the legislation before us today deal with the establishment, for example, of the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit, which is to be headed by David Block who is well known in the business community. He will undertake an extensive program of scrutiny of Public Service operations. That is already under way. I think it is important that we see his role as a constructive one. In the last decade so many reforms have been done of the Public Service that it is important that we actually get on with the job of running government and of delivering services to the people, but at the same time continuing to ensure that our work practices and the delivery of the services are up to scratch and are a very fine quality. That will be the theme that Mr Block pursues.

One of the other areas covered in this legislation is that departments and agencies will, in future, be required to cut administrative expenses each year for ongoing activities and to declare the savings so that the Government of the day can decide how they can best be utilised. It is important that we continue to look at the cost of running the Public Service. Inefficient public servants will be treated the same way as inefficient workers in well managed private sector firms. Special protection will be retained against arbitrary action, political interference and discrimination. I think that is a good balance.

One of the reforms that were highlighted by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), which I also endorse, is a simplification in the integration of a number of the classifications groups in the keyboard, the clerical assistant and clerical administrative areas to greatly reduce the number of separate work levels. Flexitime is to be reviewed to eliminate abuses but also to maintain advantages in the scheme. Also outlined in the legislation are ways of dealing with surplus staff and inefficiencies. I think inefficiency has to be looked at. Poor performers will be given a formal warning in writing and a three-month period in which to reach a necessary standard. If they do not do so, the Secretary will be able to reduce them to a lower level or retire them.

That is a great change in the operation of the Public Service. I do not think most public servants are opposed to such reform. Most public servants do work very hard and work very long hours and welcome this sort of assessment about their performance. The Secretary will be advised by an assessment committee of the performance of the individual. The officer will have one month's notice of reduction or retirement and a right of appeal to an independent committee under the Merit Protection and Review Agency. Superannuation benefits of those who will be retired will be for involuntary retrenchment.

It is important that supervisors also consider their responsibility in this role. They have to counsel staff whose work performance is not up to standard. The staff will be entitled to respond to an adverse report. We are trying to make individual public servants more responsive to the needs of the community, more aware that they have a responsibility to perform well and deliver a service. As I said, it is critical that we see this as a very constructive reform rather than a destructive one.

I would like to conclude by making some reference to the amendment put forward by the Opposition which again introduces the no work as directed no pay provision. We have seen a very constructive approach to this legislation from the response of individual public servants. I believe that this Government has had a very good working relationship with the Public Service and I believe that that will continue. I do not believe that it is necessary for this amendment to be approved by the House because I am very hopeful that the constructive relationship that we have had with the Public Service will continue.

Finally, there is no need for complacency in our look at the Public Service but, as the Chairman of the Public Service Board said, there is also no need for any apology. I would like to congratulate again the unions for their constructive attitude to the legislation that we have before this House. We have not seen any strikes in relation to it and we have not seen any critical resolutions coming from various meetings. Individual public servants have been very responsive, primarily because they are quite prepared to stand up and have their work analysed. Most of them know that, despite the bagging they consistently get from certain members of the Opposition, they perform well, they work very long hours and they deliver a very effective service to the people of this country. It is about time that members of this Parliament recognised the role of the Public Service. It has a very important role in this country and I think this legislation will make it more responsive to government and to the people of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly take the view, as I am sure do all honourable members of this House, that in many respects the Australian community has been very well served by its Public Service, particularly in policy areas. It ill becomes honourable members on the other side of the House to suggest that the Opposition constantly berates the Public Service for inefficiency and ineptitude. We certainly do not do that and have never done that. Of course we are much more concerned than the Government about the way taxpayers' money is used, so we are constantly advocating measures to improve the efficiency of the Public Service. Having said those things, let me say that there is no doubt, in our view, that Australia has been well served by its Public Service in the main policy areas. Indeed, a lot of the weaknesses that have developed in the Public Service have been as a result of political decisions. For example, the expansion of the Public Service is something that has been pressed on it by its political masters on occasions. There is no doubt that that has been the case since March 1983. The politicisation of the Public Service is something which has not been initiated by public servants themselves but by politicians from Parliament House. Again, that is something that is weakening the Public Service and I shall refer to it later.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation that the Government has introduced has been broadly welcomed by the Opposition. I certainly broadly welcome the thrust of what the Government has done in this legislation, but it is also true to say that it has done far too little and it has done that far too late. Nevertheless, there are some positives in the legislation and I want briefly to refer to those. The provision in the legislation for redeployment and retirement is something that is welcomed, certainly by honourable members on this side of the House. I think it is an improvement in the management techniques of the Public Service if it is made possible-as it is by this legislation-to demote or retire public servants, particularly where those public servants have been found to be inefficient. In the past it has not been easy to do that. This is an example of private sector management techniques at last being brought to bear on the Public Service. It is also part of the same provision that public servants can be transferred to lower levels in the Public Service-again something which is fairly common in the private sector and which I am glad to see has been introduced into the public sector.

The second positive aspect of this legislation is the change to the promotions and appeals provisions. I particularly welcome the decision by the Government to reduce the accessibility of the appeals system. The appeals system has become clogged up and is being used for a whole lot of reasons for which it was not originally designed. I am glad that the appeals process has been taken away from public servants in the range of class 9 to class 11. So I welcome the recognition by the Government of some of these management inefficiencies in the way the Public Service works but, as I said earlier, I believe that the Government has done far too little and it has done these things far too late.

I strongly support the amendment moved by the Opposition that a no work as directed no pay provision should be inserted into Public Service legislation. Again, that is something that would naturally apply in the private sector and there is absolutely no reason whatsoever why that same provision should not apply in the public sector. In fact, quite the reverse. There is all the more reason that that should apply in the public sector because the public sector is being financed by the taxpayers of Australia, who deserve every protection they can possibly get from their elected representatives in the Australian Parliament. Therefore, there is still a great deal for the Government to do in terms of improving and reforming the public sector.

The Opposition has referred at some length to the enormous growth in the Public Service since 1983. I would have hoped that this Government, if it had taken a responsible approach to public sector management, would have resisted the temptation to blow out the numbers in the public sector. But it has increased the size of the Public Service by some 15,000 since March 1983 and announced in September, through the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that it will reduce the size of the Public Service by 2,000. We still have a net gain of some 13,000 public servants at an enormous cost to the taxpayers with there being no evidence whatsoever that that growth in the public sector employment is leading to greater levels of efficiency-in fact, quite the contrary. There has been a decline in productivity in the Public Service through the substantial increases in numbers. So the decision by the Government to reduce numbers in the Public Service by just 2,000 is a cosmetic device designed to deceive the public into believing that the Government is doing something constructive about the size of the Public Service, whereas it should never be forgotten that the net increase is some 13,000. That contrasts quite dramatically with the performance of the Fraser Government where the size of the Public Service declined by 0.12 per cent per annum throughout the eight years of that Government's administration.

Quite apart from the need to restrain numbers in the Public Service-I think that is an extremely important priority for any government-there are three other key initiatives that I wish this Government had addressed, in both this legislation and in the Prime Minister's September statement, to reform the Public Service. First of all, I think the decision by the Tasmanian Government to set the pace in the community to abolish the 17 1/2 per cent holiday loading, in the case of Tasmania for just one year, is a very important initiative. If the Government were really serious about pay restraint, about reducing expenditure and about making the Australian economy competitive again, it would use the abolition of the 17 1/2 per cent leave loading as a way of setting the pace. Secondly, I think it is regrettable that the Government has still done nothing to tackle seriously the issue of workers compensation payments in the Public Service. I will come back to that later. Thirdly, the Government has done absolutely nothing to reverse the process of the politicisation of the Public Service; quite the contrary. This Government, more than any government we have had before, has quietly and subtly politicised the Australian Public Service to the detriment of ordinary public servants and to the detriment of the advice and efficiency of that institution.

Let me start by looking at the holiday loading issue and I will try to address some of the statistics there which could be beneficial to the Australian community. I have made the point already that, for any country to pay people 17 1/2 per cent more to go on holiday, is an utter absurdity. As far as I know, no other country in the world pursues such an utterly ridiculous policy. The Government has talked about the need to make Australia competitive; it has talked about the need to reduce public expenditure; yet it will not set an example to the private sector, to the broader Australian community in both the areas of reducing costs and reducing government expenditure, by abandoning this utterly absurd 17 1/2 per cent holiday loading.

If the Government were to do that-I suspect that many members of the Government believe it should but do not have the courage to say so because of opposition from their friends in the trade union movement and other vested interest groups to which this Government continually panders-it would save taxpayers a total in the vicinity of $500m a year. If it were to abolish the holiday loading in just the Federal Public Service and statutory authorities, which of course is all that the Federal Government could do, that alone would save about $130m a year. If all the States were to follow suit-if the Federal Government were to set an example it is likely that the States would, other than Tasmania, which has already done so-that would save the taxpayers, Federal and State combined, about $420m. If we added to that a similar move by local government, that would save a further $46m. In gross terms, if governments were to pursue this course of action, as they should, the taxpayers would be saved in the vicinity of half a billion dollars gross. If one took into consideration the tax loss that would inevitably flow from this, the savings would be less but would still be in the vicinity of $300m. I sincerely regret that the Government, whilst recognising that there may be a case for abolishing the 17 1/2 per cent leave loading in the public sector, has run away from that issue and done nothing about it. It has run away from it because of pressure from the trade union movement.

The second issue I want to address is that of compensation payments. It is important that people in the Australian community recognise the enormous burden that has been placed on them by workers compensation payments in the public sector. In the last financial year there were some 60,000 successful workers compensation claims in the public sector at a cost of $157m to the Australian taxpayer; of that $157m, $121m was spent on compensation to people who successfully claimed a total incapacity to work. When one goes through the statistics in more detail, the reality becomes even more frightening. One in nine members of the Australian Public Service made a successful claim for workers compensation. One in 12 members of the Australian Public Service made a successful claim for total incapacity.

When one breaks it down department by department, the full nature of the scandal evolves for all to see. Sixty per cent of the members of the Australian Capital Territory's Fire Brigade made successful workers compensation claims. Surely there is something suspicious about that. Over one-quarter of all employees of the Australian National Railways Commission made successful workers compensation claims. In the Department of Primary Industry, 25.4 per cent of employees made successful workers compensation claims, and 23.5 per cent of members of the Department of Housing and Construction. Contrast that with the compensation claims in a department such as the Department of Defence, whose personnel one would think are naturally under relatively high risk, even in peacetime. The level of claims as a percentage of total employees in that Department was just 3 1/2 per cent. Let us remember that in the Department of Primary Industry the figure is 25.4 per cent and in the Department of Defence 3.5 per cent. In the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, which operates in competition with the private sector and therefore has to take its responsibilities to consumers and to the community much more seriously, there were claims from just 3.4 per cent of its employees.

Something funny is going on; there is no question about that. Where the Government stands condemned is in its failure seriously to address this very real rort. Successful claims for workers compensation in the Public Service in Australia are up to 10 times higher than successful claims in the private sector. This legislation does something very minor to address this issue. It allows the transfer between departments of officers who have some disability. Of course, I welcome that. Instead of having to invalid those people out of the Public Service, they can be transferred. But what the Government has done is to duck the main issue of addressing this very real rort. It has done that for the same reason that it has avoided doing anything about the 17 1/2 per cent holiday loading issue-not because it challenges the figures I have put forward or because it does not know about those figures, but because its friends in the trade union movement and in the vested interest groups will not support any changes to the current rort. That is a pretty disgraceful indictment of the Government. I am sorry that it has not addressed that very important issue.

The third issue I want to address is the politicisation of the Public Service, which is a trend that has accelerated dramatically over the last three years. It has received relatively little publicity but it is a very real factor in the life of members of the Australian Public Service. In private conversations I have had with public servants at all levels, this is one of the messages continually being given. They are concerned about the politicisation of the Public Service. Senior jobs in the Public Service have been given to former politicians and, of course, to trade unionists. I suppose one would half expect any political party that is a political wing of the trade union movement to use the Public Service as a way of rewarding mates in the trade union movement. But friends of the Australian Labor Party, people who have served the Party either as ministerial staff or in some other capacity, have also been lucky winners in the lottery of Public Service jobs. Perhaps not worse but equally bad is the fact that there have been many examples over the last three years of public servants, well known for their support of the Australian Labor Party, who have received fast track advancement-something that is deeply resented by many people in the Public Service who are affiliated with neither of the major political parties but who are just committed to a professional Public Service career.

Let us look at some of the facts. I do not want to mention any names because that is unfair to the people involved, but let us just look at some of the statistics. Twenty-three current and former Federal Labor members of parliament have been given jobs in the public sector by this Government. Eight former members of State parliaments have also been given such positions, as have five members of Territory governments. There has been an extraordinary acceleration, in other words, in the politicisation of the Public Service. I am not denying for a minute that such positions were given by previous governments. The point I am making is that there has been an extraordinary acceleration in the politicisation of the Public Service over the last three years.

There have been fast track promotions through the device of the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act. That has been very much resented in a number of departments. For example, in the Department of Foreign Affairs there have been two particularly notorious examples of relatively junior officers suddenly finding themselves in senior positions, having previously been on the staff of Labor Ministers. The way that they have achieved that is through the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act, under which they have not had to apply for positions competitively with other public servants or go through the appeals process that other public servants have to face. That has been deeply resented in the Department of Foreign Affairs. There are similar instances in other departments such as the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment-there is one particularly notorious example in that Department. Ministers should realise that that has been deeply resented by ordinary hardworking career officers of those departments. That has helped to undermine the morale of those departments and it is regrettable that the Government has refused to recognise this.

There have also been examples of Labor Party camp followers. I do not want to mention these people by name but they are well known to most members of this House. Such people have received extremely senior positions in the Public Service, in some cases as permanent heads of departments. Again I think that is extremely regrettable. The simple fact is that this politicisation of the Public Service is undermining the whole concept of an impartial and fearless Public Service. Public servants are now asking themselves: `Whom should I please? Should I be pleasing my peers in the Public Service through a demonstration of my professionalism, or should I be trying to please people in the Australian Labor Party?'. `Whom should I serve?', they are asking; `Should I be serving the general public of Australia, the ordinary people of Australia, or should I be serving the Australian Labor Party?'. Even more seriously, junior officers in the Public Service are quite seriously now saying that it would be in their best career interests to hitch their wagon to one of the major political parties.

The traditional view of an impartial Public Service giving objective advice, and of that impartial Public Service being part of the checks and balances process of our system of government, is being thrown away by this Government. It is getting rid of professionalism at the top of the Public Service; it is getting rid of impartial advice. It is replacing the professionals and the impartial career public servants with yes men committed to the Australian Labor Party. Politicisation is also taking place through the unionisation of the Public Service, where again there is clear scope for a conflict of interests between public servants, asked to help with legislation on industrial relations matters, and their union membership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should begin my remarks by saying that of all the people in this House who would want to speak about impartiality and patronage, I found it quite distressing that it was the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) who made such comments because it is well known that his father was the recipient of the plummest job in London that could possibly go to a former politician from this place, and of course that patronage was applied by coalition governments and certainly was not supported by us. I found it most disagreeable that he of all people should be unctuous and talk about politicisation in the Public Service. We have heard from the honourable member for Mayo and the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) that the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Bill is all too little too late. They support our proposal, but say what a pity we did not do it earlier. I remind them that we have been in government for 3 1/2 years. I wonder why during the time of the Fraser Government they did nothing, why the coalition was not about reforming the Public Service in the way that this legislation is now doing. I return to the remarks of a former member of the Fraser Government, John Hyde, who said that he felt that this Government was doing a better job than the Fraser Government did. In March of last year the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) said of the Fraser Government:

SPEECH.PARA: But we never seemed to have time to talk about . . . how we could get rid of the dead hand of government, our Government, that was stifling initiative and taxing us into oblivion.

Indeed, these great deregulators, these champions of free enterprise and private enterprise on the other side of the House, found it too difficult in government to carry out these tasks. The honourable member for Menzies continued:
We actively and wrongly opposed the breaking up of the Telecom . . . did little to encourage deregulation or competition in the finance industry . . .

In all of these areas it has been this Government that has wrought the changes; it has been this Government that has looked at the Public Service and said that it needs to be more efficient and more effective. The honourable member for Bradfield suggested that growth in the Public Service per se was a terrible thing and therefore any government involved in a period of Public Service growth should be seen as terrible. One need only look at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report on economic studies of spring last year on the role of the public sector to see that during the 1960s and 1970s, during times of coalition governments, general government employment far exceeded non-government employment in this country. It was under coalition governments that we saw the great growth in the Public Service in this country and it is only in recent years that the jobs created by this Government have been largely in the private sector. We have seen significant growth in private sector employment. In 1984 this Government brought in the Public Service Reform Bill and this legislation is a further initiative which will develop our approach to Public Service efficiency and an improvement in Public Service mechanisms.

But what do these public servants do? They are employed principally to get things done, to administer programs of the Government, to provide services and to make sure that there is efficient provision of such services. There is a myth in this country, and it is one that has been provoked and supported by members on the other side today, that somehow the Public Service in Australia is some sort of monster and compared with other countries we have a massive Public Service, much greater than we need. One need only look at the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in September, in which he suggests that the percentage of workers in the public sector amounted to 15 or 16 per cent. Of course these figures depend on the criteria we use, how they are collected and the extent of privatisation of our economy. OECD figures suggest that 15 or 16 per cent of our work force is employed in general government activities. Those figures have not been disputed by members on the other side. If we look at figures for OECD countries with which we might compare ourselves we find that the figure in Austria is 19.2 per cent; in Belgium, 19.5 per cent; in Canada, 19.9 per cent; in Denmark, 31 per cent; in Finland, 18.9 per cent; in New Zealand, 19.1 per cent; in Norway, 22.9 per cent; in Sweden, 31.8 per cent; and, in the United Kingdom, where Margaret Thatcher is presently wielding the knife, 21.8 per cent of employees are employed in the government sector. So the figures for Australia compare very favourably with all of those countries. France has a figure of 16.1 per cent and the United States of America 16.7 per cent. So I do not think it is fair for us to say that Australia has some sort of monstrous, burgeoning Public Service. The coalition did not find it necessary in government to redress the balance significantly, and I think that perhaps Australia has a reasonable balance. If we look at other figures, as a percentage of population, we find that in Australia those employed in public utilities total 8.8 per cent of the population; in Canada, 8.7 per cent; in the United Kingdom, 9.5 per cent; and in the United States of America, 7.3 per cent. Again Australia compares favourably with those other countries.

Why, then, is this legislation important? It is important because any government must be accountable to the taxpayers and have an efficient public sector. We are not about bashing the public sector. It is understood that the majority of public servants in this country are hard working and efficient but it is necessary for there to be a realistic appraisal of their work. The inefficient work and management practices of the private sector have come under scrutiny recently. Even before the recent Peko dispute in the north of Western Australia the Government had shown a lead in this area. An integral part of our restructuring of the steel industry, heavy engineering, the motor vehicle industry and the shipbuilding industry was a consideration of inefficient work and management practices. Government, businesses and unions got together to see that those practices were eliminated. That is the sort of procedure that over time this Government will be involved in.

What does the Opposition want to do? I am sure that it wants an efficient expenditure of taxpayers' money. The honourable member for Mayo said that taxpayers' money must be used efficiently. Yet last week, in this House, we introduced legislation to produce a high integrity identity card in this country. Presently in the United States the public is screaming out for such a high integrity identity card. It is estimated that in the United States $15 billion is paid in social security overpayments every year. In Australia, our Government is trying to do something about it. What do we find from the Opposition? We find the Opposition opposing this suggestion, opposing the idea that in some way the Government should act in a more efficient way and make sure that taxpayers' money is spent efficiently. There must be accountability; there must he productivity in our Public Service, and it must be efficient. This legislation is directed towards improving that efficiency. It is directed towards streamlining procedures in the Australian Public Service.

The most significant part of the legislation contained in Part II of the Bill amends the Public Service Act 1922, and it relates to the redeployment and retirement arrangements and revised provisions relating to promotions and appeals. Indeed, the redeployment and retirement provisions apply principally in two situations. The first is in that of excess officers where there is a surplus of staff, where perhaps the functions of a particular department have changed and there is an excess of workers in that area. It is reasonable that any management in those circumstances should be able to offer voluntary retrenchment schemes to its workers. For the first time this is included in this legislation. With respect to involuntary retrenchment or reduction of class of officers, again a new mechanism is provided in an appeals system which will be much more efficient than that which has previously operated.

The second area in which the redeployment and retirement provisions operate is that concerning inefficient staff-staff who perhaps are not performing their functions, those who perhaps because of physical or mental incapacity are not able to perform their functions any more or those who have lost some essential qualifications. Management's ability to deal with such staff must be the same as in any big organisation, and therefore new provisions are made available. There will be a formal warning for any staff in such a situation, and after a three-month period if there is no improvement management will have the opportunity to redeploy or retire such staff. Again, such a move can be seen as being consistent with management practices in any private sector activity.

With regard to promotions and appeals, the direction of this legislation is towards the promotion of people on merit. The potential, flexibility and adaptability of people need to be considered. Good management, of course, requires judgments to be made-judgments which are not prejudiced and which are not subject to cronyism. Good judgments have to be made by management. Presently the promotions and appeals systems in the Public Service are effective but cumbersome. The figure that strikes one is that when there is an appeal against a promotion it takes 36 weeks to fill a vacancy. That is expensive, time consuming and inefficient. Changes in that procedure are necessary, and this legislation gives effect to them.

It contains other changes in relation to the promotions and appeals systems. For instance, there will be a decrease in the appeal period; a limited right of appeal only to those who were original applicants for positions; and exclusion of appeals for those of class 8 level and above. There are other aspects to this legislation, and I could go on for some time.
