Briefly, they relate to the delegation of the functions of the Public Service Board which has had increasing functions since the introduction of the Public Service Reform Act 1984.

I think it is important that there should and will be some review of flexitime procedures. Certainly flexitime offers the opportunity for many government departments to have more extended opening times for contact with the public. This is a desirable outcome of flexitime procedures but, of course, it is undesirable that flexitime should be accrued by workers so that they can have long weekends and extra time off. I suppose that just puts extra pressure on those staff members who are not taking advantage of flexitime in that way. Certainly the review of that procedure will be an important aspect of this legislation.

The other thing that deserves mention is that of the establishment early next year of the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit which will be similar to that which operated from 1979 to 1983 in the United Kingdom. Indeed, the Rayner scrutiny programs of that time in the United Kingdom were very effective in reducing the financial costs to government and increasing efficiency. The implementation of these decisions will be important in the financial management of various Public Service departments. I think this legislation has the support of the Opposition. It is part of our ongoing scrutiny of the Public Service. We are concerned that the Public Service should be accountable and that it should do the job for which it is there. This legislation is a further step in our move to achieve these aims. I support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We in the Opposition appreciate the job that is done for the people of Australia by those persons who are employed in the public services of this nation. We are not in the business of public service bashing, but we do not hesitate to criticise and comment when genuine reform is necessary. The Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Bill 1986 includes a number of machinery amendments which largely are non-contentious. The main thrust of the Bill constitutes changes to redeployment and retirement provisions and provisions in relation to inefficiency caused by invalidity or loss of essential qualifications and the promotions and appeals systems.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally we support the Bill, but our view is that it is too little too late. We in the National Party of Australia are concerned about the size of government in this country. We are concerned at the fact that the Bill before the House today makes absolutely no attempt to cut programs. This is a tragedy because in the current economic circumstances it is necessary for programs to be cut. The Bill does not propose to restore the situation in which we have `no work as directed no pay'. That is the reason that I support the amendment so ably moved by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). The earlier legislation that was introduced in 1977, the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act, contained provisions of this nature.

I would like to outline a situation set out in a letter from a constituent complaining about the approach of the Australian Labor Party to government and taxation. My constituent queried whether it had been brought to my attention that certain public employees are paid in full while on strike. He mentioned the situation of a person who worked for Telecom Australia on preparation work for the laying of cables. Technically Telecom employees may not be public servants, but the principle is exactly the same. I quote from my constituent's letter:

I have just become aware that last year for a period of nine weeks he, and about 100 colleagues were `in dispute' with Telecom. Apparently such workers are not allowed to strike so if they have a `dispute' with their employer, they do not work but are paid in full!
If I go on strike, I do not get paid and neither should I, so how is it that we (the legitimate tax payers of this country) have to pay public servants while in fact they are on strike?

That is a very fair question, Mr Deputy Speaker, as I am sure you will agree. I wrote to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) because I shared my constituent's concern. I thought it was ridiculous that people who failed to carry out work as directed were funded by the Australian taxpayer. In the Minister's reply he said:
You wrote to me on 13 June 1986 concerning a letter you had received which suggested that Telecom paid some of its employees while they were engaged in industrial action.

Although the letter did not identify the date or location of this action, Telecom has informed me that it may refer to a union selective ban on the installation of optical fibre cable during 1985. The ban was in support of a work value claim associated with the introduction of optical fibre cable. That claim was subsequently granted by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
Further on in the letter the Minister added:

Telecom did consider seeking stand down orders from the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in respect of this group of employees. That option was however rejected because of the delicate progress being achieved in negotiations and the almost certain escalation of the dispute to the stage where it would have seriously impacted on service to Telecom customers. In adopting this approach Telecom also took into account the recommendation of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that negotiations be conducted in an industrially free climate.

How could there be an industrially free climate? People were on strike; people were failing to carry out their duties. In any event, everyone knows that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is not neutral. Everyone knows that the Commission has, in recent years, simply tended to act as an enforcer for the trade unions. In this situation people were on strike; people were failing to carry out their rostered duties. What was this Government's response? The employees involved got full pay, despite industrial action. In other words, people who would not work as directed still got wages. Is that satisfactory? Do honourable members opposite think that the people of Australia would agree that the position taken by the Government was in any way reasonable? That situation I have outlined is proof that this Government is the captive of the trade union movement. We have in Australia government of the unions, by the unions and for the unions. It is a tragedy that the Government's weakness in this matter, as in so many others, is absolutely pathetic.

Labor had a golden opportunity with this Bill to prevent a recurrence of the situation I have outlined in relation to Telecom. What has it done? It has completely failed to take up that opportunity. It could have reintroduced the no work as directed no pay provisions, but it has left it to the Opposition to move the amendment to the Bill before the House. I hope that honourable members opposite will be persuaded by the very strong arguments which we have. It would be nice if some of them were honest and came across to this side of the chamber and voted for our amendment.

Public Service reform is necessary. Public Service reform is not contained to any substantial extent in this Bill. The changes which are sought to be made are, generally speaking, superficial. They merely scratch the surface. It is unfortunate that there has not been any attempt to reduce the duplication of governmental responsibilities in Australia. We have various Federal departments overseeing the work of State departments and also local authorities. We have one group of public servants in, say, the Federal Department of Health trying to influence and manipulate State departments. The result is the duplication of governmental responsibility at tremendously excessive cost to the Australian taxpayer.

In 1901 when the States of Australia federated to become the Commonwealth, certain functions were transferred from the colonial parliaments, as they then were, to the Federal Parliament. Since that time the Commonwealth has continued to expand its area of governmental responsibility, partly through referenda-although this has not been a major means by which the Commonwealth's powers have been extended. Commonwealth powers have been extended rather more through judicial interpretation and, more recently, through the Commonwealth entering into international treaties and claiming to use the external affairs power to grab powers which were previously in the hands of the States. So we find in Australia today that the Federal Parliament is carrying out responsibilities infinitely greater than those which were contemplated in 1901. What the Commonwealth should be doing to reduce the size of the public sector is looking at the Constitution to see what are the true and proper responsibilities of the Federal Parliament and, when that exercise is done, functions should be transferred back to the States, because the State parliaments are closer to the people.

Do we find in this Bill provisions to prevent disruption of essential services? Of course we do not, because this Government does not believe that essential services should be protected for the benefit of the citizens of Australia. We have to compare this Government's weak-kneed attitude with the very strong approach of the Queensland National Party Government in 1985, when it ensured that the lights were turned on. The Nationals made sure that militant trade unions would not hold the people of Queensland to ransom-and the electricity has stayed on. What we need is for this Federal Government to acquire a bit of backbone and to follow the sterling example of the Queensland National Party Government so that the people of Australia do in fact have a guarantee that their essential services will be maintained.

Have deregulation measures been set out in this Bill? No, the Government has largely walked away from this, despite the reports of the Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit. Are there changes to the hiring processes? No. Are there any changes to the Budget cycle? No. Do we find that there is reform of some of the working conditions which Australia can no longer afford? The answer to that also is no. Has the Government talked about the need for or desirability of repealing the 17 1/2 per cent holiday loading? Has it talked about flexitime? Has it talked about restrictive work practices in the public sector? The answers, again, are no.

The Government's stated intention is to reduce the Public Service by 2,000 people. We in the Opposition would certainly support any move to reduce the size of the public services of this country. But the Government is imposing extra burdens on the Public Service. On the one hand it tells us that it is going to cut the Public Service by 2,000 people. Yet, on the other hand, it has brought in the disastrous fringe benefits tax and the disastrous identity card proposal, which will require nearly 4,000 new staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgraceful.

—These two measures are disgraceful, as the honourable member for Gilmore quite correctly points out. The Government's proposed reduction of 2,000 in the Public Service is shown to be a shallow prediction because, since this Government was elected in 1983, we have had an increase in the size of the Public Service of an average of 3.5 per cent per year, compared with the sterling example of the Fraser-Anthony Government, when there was negative growth. I think that the people of Australia will see through this Government masquerading as a government which is trying to reduce costs. How on earth can this Government pretend to be reducing Public Service numbers by 2,000 when it is bringing in legislation such as the fringe benefits tax legislation, its identity card or Australia Card proposal, its legislation for an assets test on pensions and so many other pieces of legislation which require a greater rather than a lesser number of public servants? The number of people on the Public Service payroll has increased from 408,300 in June 1983 to 442,400 in May 1986. As I mentioned previously, that is an increase of an average of 3.5 per cent per year.
—The Government is sending us broke.

—The country is broke and the Government should take steps to redress the situation. This Bill, sadly, does not meet the expectations of the people of Australia. The National Party is not in the business of attacking public servants, the vast majority of whom carry out their duties diligently and to the best of their ability. In respect of my own electorate of Fisher, I have nothing but the utmost respect for those public servants. They work very hard to ensure that necessary government services are brought to the people of Fisher. But what we need is genuine reform, not tokenism. We need to cut our cloth to suit our measure. Australia is no longer a wealthy country. We must trim our costs to meet our newly reduced circumstances. The banana republic of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is fast becoming a reality. The Public Service cannot be immune from the economies necessary for our nation's economic well-being. What is needed-what is needed now-is genuine Public Service reform to ensure that the Public Service meets the needs of contemporary Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Bill gives effect to the announcement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of 25 September. The purpose of the Bill is to streamline the Public Service and encourage a more efficient and productive Public Service. In speaking to this Bill, the first thing I want to say is that, like many people in this Parliament, I have worked with many public servants over the considerable number of years that I was in the Services and the majority of them are efficient and hard working. I am not in any way attempting to carry out an assault on the Public Service. But, like any large organisation, there are obviously areas which should be looked at and which can be improved. This Bill is an attempt to do this. But I must say that it seems to me to be a rather timid attempt, given the Prime Minister's rather grand statement in September about what he was going to do to the Public Service. If this is the best that he can do to reform the Public Service, God help us all.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point to make is that the Government has still not restored the no-work no-pay provisions into any Public Service legislation. It is absolutely crazy that in 1986, given the economic conditions under which this country is labouring, we find that public servants can go on strike and be paid. I shall return to that point in a moment. Public servants have-and they realise this-a priceless asset in difficult economic times. That asset is a secure job and a pension at the end of it. There are many Australians who do not have that. Given that asset, there must be areas of the Public Service which should be looked at closely to see what improvements can be made. I would have thought that the majority of hard working and efficient public servants would welcome these reviews and reforms and the introduction of a no-work no-pay provision because this would increase the professionalism of the Public Service and the standing of public servants in the community. We all know that from time to time the Public Service is a good old chopping block for just about everyone who is not in it. As an example of some of the more extreme views that are held by public servants-I presume by the more radical Left-an advertisement appeared in yesterday's Courier-Mail for a big rally in Brisbane. The advertisement said:
Aren't you fed up with lies?
Australia's public sector Workers protect the average Australian.
Yet we are under attack from those who distort the truth!
Working conditions eroded. Tasmania leave loading suspended-
that is a step in the right direction-
Jobs abolished. Deregulation and undermining awards. `Flexitime' at risk. Selling off government agencies.

They are all sensible things that any government would want to do, yet public servants in Brisbane have a rally about these things. I do not know how many people went to that rally but I would not have thought it would be well attended. By promoting that sort of nonsense, the public servants who called that rally are bringing the whole of the Public Service and the best elements of it into disrepute because there is no way in the world that the public sector in this country cannot be expected to be asked to take its share of the cuts that the economic conditions dictate.

The Prime Minister is on record as saying last September that he would get rid of 2,000 public servants. Big deal! He has put 15,000 on in the last three years and he says now that he will take off 2,000. He makes that statement at the very time when he brings forward the Australia Card Bill, which will require at least another 2,000 public servants by the Government's own reckoning. God knows how many more people will have to be put on in the private sector to cope with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is job creation.

—As the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment well knows, it is nonsense to talk about this Government reducing the Public Service numbers by 2,000 when before it has even put those public servants off it has put on another 2,000 to look after the ID card, plus the 15,000 that it has put on in the last three years. It has been said before in this debate, and it should be said again, that the Fraser Government had negative growth in the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government were serious, it would have addressed in this Bill some of the real issues that should be addressed in any Public Service review. For example, the 17.5 per cent holiday loading in the Public Service should have been reviewed in order to set an example to the private sector. If the numbers of public servants are to be reduced, government programs must be looked at and reduced also. The Government should look at the functions that could be transferred to the States. It should introduce-and we are determined to do this-a no-work no-pay provision into the Public Service Act. It must have some mechanism to prevent the disruption of essential services, and the contracting out of existing government services must be looked at if the Government is serious about reducing the size of the Public Service. None of those provisions are being tackled in this legislation. It is no wonder that the credibility of the Prime Minister's statement in September is very low indeed. In this Bill the Government does not address the major problems. There are superficial changes, but they are seen for what they are. It is true that this is a big government, despite what it might say. Thirty-two extra politicians came in at the last election-32 for God's sake, in a country which already has something like 850 politicians. The Government puts on another 32 and then has the hide to say it is small government. The Government knows that extra politicians, apart from the expense they incur, mean extra--

TALK.START.PARA: —You blokes supported it.

—We did not support it. The Minister knows very well that we did not support it. The Liberal Party of Australia did not support that particular provision. Ministers should not come in here and tell us that they stand for small government when at the last election the Government put on another 32 politicians. More politicians, more programs and another 15,000 public servants.

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult to understand why some provision has not already been made for the return of the no-work no-pay principle. This requirement was abolished by this Government when it came to office in 1983. How any government could claim that it is streamlining the Public Service and making it more efficient when it does not address that problem is beyond understanding. The public servants have a privileged position and most of them are the first to admit it. They have a secure job, a pension and, generally speaking, comfortable working conditions. Most public servants I know would welcome the return of the no-work no-pay provision in order to ensure that their professional standing in the community is increased. We will ensure that this provision is returned to Public Service legislation. I know that that will be welcomed by the majority of public servants.

The question of duplication of functions throughout this country must be addressed, whatever government is in power. We cannot allow the States and the Federal Government to continue paralleling services, whether it be in education, housing, or a whole host of other functions. There is no doubt that that will be a difficult operation, as we have seen, for example, with the meat inspectors. However, it is a problem that must be addressed. I believe that in the end the simple approach must be that the Commonwealth return to the States those things they do best and get out of those areas altogether in which there is no real need for it to be. Obviously in that way we would have a major effect on the number of public servants in this country.

There is also the question of the expansion of numbers in the Public Service. In the area for which I am responsible, tourism and sport, we have seen an increase in the number of senior officers in the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism from five to 23 in three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many was that?

—An increase from five to 23 in a very small Department. In that same area we have seen growth of statutory authorities which is being paralleled in other departments while this Government has been in power. If the Government is not serious about addressing the growth of statutory authorities and senior officers in the Public Service, how can we expect it to be taken seriously in addressing some of these other issues? The question of the 17.5 per cent holiday loading is not addressed in this Bill. The Premier of Western Australia has got it right, as has the Premier of South Australia. This is not an attack on the take home pay of public servants; it is an attempt to face the reality that the country simply cannot afford at a time when we have these economic problems to continue paying people for work that is not being done. We are paying people more to go on leave or on holiday than to actually work. Its removal is not an attempt to cut wages. That would be a stupid approach because if we start to cut wages we cut the spending power of people and that is reflected through the whole of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the 17.5 per cent loading was given at a time when economic conditions were much better, and I would have thought that the Public Service, where people have secure jobs, is the most sensible place to start to do away with the controversial and, in some cases, delicate area of the 17.5 per cent holiday loading. In this way the Government and the Public Service will be seen to be setting an example. The way in which we will tackle this on return to government is simply to let employers and employees talk to each other and set their own wages and conditions based on an hourly rate. If an employer then offers a job to somebody and there are no penalty rates or holiday pay involved that is a matter between the employer and the employee.

The Bill addresses the question of surplus staff in the Public Service, and I am very pleased to see that. Up to two years to finalise the surplus staff situation in the Public Service, as explained by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Industrial Matters (Mr Willis) when introducing this Bill, is ridiculous. No wonder the private sector laughs. It will also be easier for inefficient staff to be removed. I would think that that is particularly welcomed by the Public Service because inefficient staff mean that someone has to work much harder. Disciplinary provisions are to be tightened up. There will be a review of flexitime. The best review that could take place would be to come to the conclusion that it should be abolished altogether because there is no justification or requirement for it at a time when the country is facing the economic problems that it is facing. In respect of invalidity and the generous provisions available to the Public Service, there is no doubt, when one looks at the figures that have been brought forward by the Waste Watch Committee, that a racket is being perpetrated in some departments; and I am very pleased to see that the Government is addressing that problem.

I want to mention in conclusion the question of annual reports, which the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) raised during his speech on this Bill. There is no doubt that a system of regular annual reports would go a long way towards achieving efficiency in the Public Service. A system whereby senior officers, as a matter of course, report on their juniors has been applied in the Services with great success over many years. It not only leads to an annual review of that person's work but is a record of his employment during the time he is in the Services or, as I am suggesting, in the Public Service. If it comes to trying to judge someone's efficiency, the total record of that man's work and how he is judged by his superiors is there to be seen by those who wish to make a decision. I strongly commend that efficiency provision to the Government and hope that it will be looked at. An annual review of all public servants is a very simple mechanism and a very effective one for increasing the efficiency of the Public Service.

Finally, there is no doubt that under this Government the politicisation of the Public Service has proceeded apace. In this respect one has to look only at the statement of the Taxation Commissioner in the recent week when he intruded into the political debate. With every justification, he said: `We would take an opposing view'. The point is that he was encouraged into that debate by the politicisation that has taken place in the Public Service in the last three years. We welcome the start that has been made in this Bill to improve the efficiency and productivity of the Public Service. We look forward to the review by Mr David Block, which will be a wide-ranging review, and hope that it will come up with some substance and that that substance will be taken up by the Government. We hope that the unions will co-operate in whatever that review produces and that the Government would then put some substance into the sort of legislation it brings forward to review the Public Service. The fear we have is that, given the influence and, in some cases, the control of the Australian Council of Trade Unions over this Government, what we on this side of the House hope for will be somewhat futile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it can be said that a good deal of thought has gone into the legislation before the House and, taking into account the 1984 legislation, I believe that there is also the presence of some imagination. The title of the Bill, the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Bill, holds out more hope than the actuality of the Bill itself. The legislation touches up the major legislation, opening the door wider for more direct authority of the departmental secretary to be used to command personnel. There will be a certain cost to be paid for these changes, particularly in the policy making echelons where there is a scope for personality pressures to develop excessively without restraint and there is no easy parallel with private enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: The test for executive performance in private enterprise is the annual profit and loss account. Bad management is exposed on an annual basis. If bad management results from mistaken actions, for example, from authoritarian management souring relationships with supporting staff, that eventually relays its own message to responsible authority through the balance sheet. Institutional wisdom is thus built into a successful business enterprise and this element is a force which is a constraint over management. The profit and loss account is not the element of test for a Public Service performance. There are the obvious tests of smooth efficiency, for example, in the administration of a department of social security or a department of public works; elementary tests of performance are clearly observable. What are broadly described as the policy departments or the policy echelons of the system-and I am talking about such departments as Treasury, Trade, Finance, Community Services, Defence and Foreign Affairs-do not lend themselves to obvious tests of efficiency. Rather, they are significant sources of intellectual input into the advising of government. The allocation of national resources or the enterprise of national prosperity or international involvement cannot be easily tested for efficiency. Here the judgments of performance are more subjective as the element of policy making is a dominant one and the relationship with the political leadership of government is crucial.

Australia, since Federation, has slowly built a public service system which is a primary functionary in the transaction of major decisions affecting the prosperity of the nation. The system has relied heavily on the notion that the Public Service develops its own powers of institutional wisdom, its special sense of institutional behaviour and a poise, a strength and a confidence in its role. Prior to World War II the nation worked with a small public service based in Canberra. During the war Canberra acquired special income tax powers and a process of redistribution to State governments was built up. The traditions of a politically neutral public service were well maintained during the war under Prime Minister Curtin. They were strengthened by the public skill of Prime Minister Chifley and they were sustained by Prime Minister Sir Robert Menzies.

I believe it is important to note that the major traditions were set during the war and the post-war period under two Labor Prime Ministers and one coalition Prime Minister. I say that because I believe it is sad to recall that due respect for this achievement was weakened by some of Prime Minister Whitlam's Ministers. A habit of mind developed that assumed that public servants who had served a long period under the coalition had disqualified themselves from service under a Labor government. The Government made numerous consultant appointments and all too often these inexperienced political appointees were at pains to belabour the Public Service. Then Mr Whitlam did something else. He developed a great flair for creating non-departmental bodies, always preceded, of course, by an inquiry. This inevitably led to the creation of a new statutory body outside the departmental structure and the structure of public enterprise swelled to meet these new demands. At the same time the nation has been accumulating a growth of Public Service functions concentrated in Canberra. It is debatable whether the evacuation of State capitals in favour of inflation in Canberra has been desirable and, more importantly, whether it has produced more efficient government. There has thus been a very strong and sustained public reaction which sees the public sector as inflated and the growth of the national capital as an unnecessary incubus.

We should remind ourselves that this legislation deals with departments; those bodies under the control of the Public Service Board. It does not deal with the large structures outside the departments. In that area the proliferation is very great and there has been a tendency to blame the Public Service for inflating itself. Parkinson's law operates, but not to the degree which explains the growth of the public sector to its current dimensions. The explanation is centrally to be found in the bidding that takes place at election time to deliver services at public expense to special interest groups significant to the election process. Hopefully, the process has at last taken a check.

This Government made the mistake of inflating government expenditure in 1984 and a very heavy price is now being paid by everyone for that frightful Budget. The Australian Labor Party has at last realised that money does not grow on trees. The day of any party riding to power by treating the public purse as a bottomless pit has passed. It is important to be fair and to recognise that growth in the Public Service is not the fruit of scheming by the Public Service but the fruit of promises and responses by governments to public demands.

Every government, however, owes a public duty to the need to minimise growth and overhaul and reshape its administration. As has already been noted, this Government has recently appointed the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit headed by David Block, who is a distinguished business and financial personality. He is ably supported by one of our most skilful public servants, Mr Tony Ayers. I do not think there can be any doubt that their work will test the system. Mr Block will see his job in the most practical terms. It is rather ironic that the idea is modelled on a Margaret Thatcher initiative, when she called in the managing director of Marks and Spencer to inaugurate such a review in the United Kingdom.

One of the complexities of Public Service administration is that accountability is a primary test of administrative achievement. Large sums are involved in the daily work of large numbers of people. The task is to ensure that money and resources which are requested and allocated are adequate to the task and that there is no perfidy involved in either process. It is possible to play safe and overendow the system with checks and balances, accounting and authorising systems. This might seem to be the way to go if we are to avoid wastage, but it has to be realised that surveillance procedures cost money and personnel, so the problem is to find the right balance between the risk of misuse of resources by officers feathering their own nests and 100 per cent fail-safe accountability. There have been numerous cost cutting exercises-review upon review-many of which have been in-house processes. The exposure of the departmental administration to the skills of a David Block will have the effect, I believe, of producing a good housekeeping seal of approval for the departments so scrutinised.

This legislation, and the Public Service Reform Act 1984 in like manner, takes risks by increasing the power of departmental secretaries to act independently of the Public Service Board. Their powers over staff will be considerably enlarged. There is the risk-it should not be minimised-that, once appointed, departmental heads will act too liberally in pursuit of their own inclinations. Contrary to what this Bill might attempt to say, there will be more scope for idiosyncratic behaviour by the departmental secretaries and more scope for political patronage. I believe that this is so and that it can be contained only by the selection of career public servants to the position of head of the Public Service Board.

The appointment of people prominent in the life of any political party to this key position seems to me to be most undesirable. It remains one of the oddities that membership of the Labor Party has not been a barrier to a Public Service career. Instead, it has assisted in many cases. However, members of other political parties are not so favoured by the workings of the system. The new arrangements have led to a spate of early retirements which have not been voluntary but have been forced on the individuals affected. On the whole, that has not reduced numbers and it is doubtful whether it has increased efficiency. Indeed, it has the appearance of the very nepotism which this legislation affects to discourage.

I have said that the growth of the Public Service owes much less to Parkinson's law than to policy programs emerging from the competing political parties at election times. It is undesirable to conduct a campaign of put-down against the Public Service or in other ways to diminish its stature. There is a need for a review of the system and I believe that Mr David Block is a good choice. I have already made the point that policy development is a central area which eludes the obvious test of efficiency.

The central policy direction of government is the responsibility of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It is this process which engages the Public Service at its most sensitive point. The history of the central department, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, reflects the growth of power and the role accorded to the Prime Minister as leader of government. There are those who say that Australia is producing a quasi-presidential system. All heads of government are more in public demand today than at any other time in history. Television has created the expectation that all national problems are within the capacity and range of powers of the Prime Minister. In these circumstances the advisory system around the Prime Minister is of paramount importance. There was a time when great reliance could be placed on the assumption that advice from the Minister responsible was always effectively on tap, yet there is a practical situation where both the Prime Minister and the Minister have different obligations and the immediacy of public pressure places great demands on both. Clearly, staffing of adequate people to satisfy the liaison needs of both is necessary. At the political level there is the political staff, but in the transaction of public administration the Public Service has to interrelate efficiently.

The Prime Minister, as head of government, is also chairman of Cabinet, which is the central policy-making body. The resources of the Public Service are vital in the preparation of the Cabinet program, its processes and the post-Cabinet decision tasks of legislation and administrative direction. The Prime Minister, as chairman of the group, has special needs. He alone is not directly responsible for a single area of government activity, yet he has to be sure of the discharge of his Government's administration. Clearly, as chairman of Cabinet, he needs and gets assistance in the questions he poses to his colleagues and even on the way in which he should react to the advice he receives. Thus the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet came into existence. It is important that it functions so as to facilitate, but not to intervene in, the relationship between the Prime Minister and his Ministers.

The role of the permanent public servant with developed experience and wisdom is vital. I believe that the present Government has shown some good sense in the balance it has struck between the Prime Minister's roles and needs and those of his Cabinet colleagues. I believe it is vital that this stability in our institutional development be retained. It can be destabilised by an excess of zeal by the Government to promote politically motivated personnel to central positions in the Public Service. The present Government is not entirely free from question marks in this area.

Secondly, the process can be destabilised by efforts to denigrate Public Service traditions of political neutrality by appointing politically favoured officers. Whatever may be the results of the administrative reviews on the structure of government which come forward from time to time, I believe very firmly that all of us, no matter on which side of the political fence we sit, should bend all our efforts to maintaining a politically unbiased Public Service. I believe the people of Australia must and should rely on disinterested advice going forward to the government of the day no matter what the political persuasion of that government is. If the Public Service is politicised to any great degree, disinterested advice does not go forward and the whole administration suffers if that situation comes to pass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable members who have taken part in this debate on the matter of streamlining the Australian Public Service. I would like to emphasise the description of the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Bill that is now before the House because I think to some extent some honourable members opposite have seen it as an opportunity to perhaps put forward their views not so much on streamlining the Public Service but perhaps on having a direct relationship in the industrial relations field which we do not believe has any place in a debate of this nature.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the headings of the matters that are covered by this legislation. We find simplification of office classification structures, redundancy, invalidity, inefficiency, loss of qualifications, promotions, higher duties, delegation of central personnel functions, recruitment, discipline, flexitime and other miscellaneous amendments. It is very much in keeping with what the Government has been saying ought to have happened and has indeed happened in the private sector. By our own intervention, particularly in the steel and automotive industries, the Government has played a primary role in doing away with a lot of old work practices and by making both of those major Australian industries far more efficient and far more viable than they were when we came to office in 1983. The jobs of people in those industries and the money invested by others in those industries are far more secure than they were when we became the Government. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has indicated to the House, we cannot take one attitude in the private sector and another in the public sector. It is not for this Government to discriminate in our attitudes between these two sectors. It is for that reason that we continue down the path of echoing the same sentiments to the public sector as we have demonstrated outside. I refer to the words of the Prime Minister when he delivered this speech to the House on 25 September to put into context what this debate is really all about. He stated:
This is not a Public Service bashing exercise.

The Government did not embark on this as a matter of denigrating or, indeed, in any way bashing the Public Service. What we are saying to the Public Service is that we are going to take exactly the same attitude to the operations within government employment that we would take to employment outside. There are practices, procedures, problems and hiccups in the administration within the Public Service and we have got to free them up. We have got to facilitate a great deal more efficiency in many of the areas of Public Service administration and that is what we intend to do.

My colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), on whose behalf I act today, has had a long series of consultations with the Public Service unions over these matters. It is also true to say-I put this on record-that not all the Public Service unions and their representatives are happy with the measures being taken by the Government. They had some other ideas in these fields that they felt would have been more beneficial from their point of view as representing the employees. But the Government has to make decisions as to what it sees as being best in the organisation and the conduct of affairs within the public sector. That is what we have done. But we have not embarked on it without consultation. We have not imposed these things without consultation and without a great deal of consideration between the parties that will be affected by it and, indeed, within Cabinet. It is not the first measure that we have taken since we came to government; it is just part of a parcel of measures which is certainly going to give us a far more efficient and, as the Bill says, a far greater streamlining of the Public Service. When the Prime Minister spoke to the House on 25 September, he made the following points, which I reiterate:
The Government has decided:
Firstly, to establish an efficiency scrutiny unit, to be headed by a senior private sector representative, to undertake an extensive program of scrutiny of public sector operations.

As the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) says, Mr David Block has been selected and has the unanimous support of this House. He will look into those operations. The Prime Minister continued:

secondly, departments and agencies will, in future, be required to cut their administrative expenses each year for ongoing activities and they will be required to declare the savings so that the government of the day can decide how they can best be utilised-
that is, rather than be hypothecated by the departments themselves-

thirdly, there will be major changes in the arrangements for the redeployment or retrenchment of inefficient and surplus staff. Special protection will be retained against political victimisation. But inefficient public servants will be treated the same way as are inefficient workers in the private sector. In short, public servants are no longer immune from dismissal.

fourthly, the Government will proceed within a few months to simplify and integrate the complex job classification distinctions which currently exist in the Public Service office structure. New technology has made these distinctions obsolete. The review might well become the largest single restructuring of occupations ever undertaken in the Public Service;
fifthly, there will be a number of management changes designed to make Public Service personnel management more efficient and effective; and
sixthly, flextime will be reviewed, with the objective of eliminating abuses but maintaining the advantages of the system for both departments and employees.

They are six major factors which lie behind and which motivate the Government in the presentation of the legislation before the House today. I will turn to one factor which gives an indication of how overdue some of these measures are. In the simplification of office classification structures there are currently 71,000 keyboard, clerical assistant and clerical officers in the Australian Public Service. They are employed in 48 distinct classifications which have over 160 separate pay points. Many jobs in these structures are narrowly defined and specialised with rigid distinctions between classification groups. Some classifications are related to the operation of particular types of equipment. Departments must organise their work using only the classifications approved by the Public Service Board.

That gives honourable members a slight idea of the many problems which this Bill is aimed at overcoming. This should have the support of all honourable members of this House. There has been consultation with the unions involved, but there has not been total agreement. It is in keeping with what has motivated the Government since we came to power in March 1983; that is, to treat the public sector in exactly the same way as we treat the private sector. On that point, members of the Opposition used the opportunity they have been given today in this Bill to, once again, move on this no work as directed, no pay provision which was repealed by this Government in 1983. The moves made by this Government in any of the industrial relations field or in any of the efficiency aiming legislation such as that today is not based on confrontation. We do not see the best results emanating from any of these measures being brought about by having a total confrontation between the Government and the Public Service unions or, indeed, outside between the Government and the unions that might operate in the private sector. Unfortunately, the Opposition again sees this as an opportunity to raise this point. I will refer to the words of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations in 1983 when this measure was repealed. He stated:

The justification for such legislation was to give the Commonwealth rights which, according to the then Minister, applied generally to employers in the private sector. In reality, however, the legislation placed Commonwealth employees in a different position to private sector employees. The common law rights of private employers to exercise no work as directed, no pay powers are not clear cut, particularly where employment is covered by an award of an industrial tribunal. For example, in 1980-the same year as the decision in Bennett's case-the Full Bench of the Federal Court held in what became knows as Gapes case that this power was not available to a major banking company as it was not consistent with the award concerned.

It is therefore clear that in the private sector, the ability of employers to apply the no work as directed no pay principle is constrained by the terms of applicable awards. In essence, then, this legislation created a situation where the then Government provided itself with sanctions against its own employees which were not necessarily available to all sections of the private sector and in addition it put itself in the position where its powers could not be overridden by a decision of an industrial tribunal.
Mr Willis also said in 1983:
The Government rejects such a confrontationist approach towards its own employees.

I reiterate that and repeat today on his behalf that we again reject such a confrontationist approach to industrial relations within the public sector. In addition to the matter raised by the Opposition spokesman, one other speaker in the debate raised the question of the holiday leave loading and said that perhaps this was an opportunity to put forward a view that Australians would all be better off if we did away with the 17 1/2 per cent leave loading. At the moment we are in the midst of some very important and urgent negotiations with the trade union movement in this country regarding wages. They are an extremely important arm of the economic management of this country. One would not have thought so under the Fraser Government because it allowed wages to blow out by 17 per cent in 1982. If such a situation were to emerge in 1986 we would face an inflation rate and an unemployment rate that would be totally unacceptable to the Australian people. Yet while these negotiations are under way and while it appears that we might be entering a period of adopting a totally new wage system in 1987-88, people opposite still put forward the view that one of the great saviours of this country could be the abolition of the annual leave loading. Such claims at such a time are idiotic.

Without going into all the details, the other feature of the leave loading is this: People opposite speak as though it is something completely unique to Australia, that it does not apply outside this country and, for no better reason than that, they believe its abolition is substantiated. Let me very quickly give some examples of the leave loadings that apply in other countries. Belgium has a 90 per cent leave loading, Denmark 30 per cent, France 30 per cent, Greece 50 per cent, the Netherlands 30 per cent, Norway 32 per cent, Sweden 25 per cent and Finland 50 per cent. So for some honourable members opposite to believe, as they do, that perhaps there is some great saviour in taking away the annual leave loading from the working people of this country is both economically ludicrous and politically suicidal at a time when negotiations are going on with organised labour in this country to maintain a sensible wage outcome which will allow us to put Australian industry back on its feet. So I ask honourable members opposite to rethink the stands that they are making on these questions.

In all these matters one has to make a judgment between the approach of this Government and the approach of the Opposition. If the approach of the Opposition were correct-one can only judge from its period in office between 1975 and 1983-days lost in industrial disputation under the previous Government would not have reached three times the days lost under this Government. So we had a great deal more industrial disputation under the Fraser Government with its industrial relations policy than we have under this Government. That is one way to judge it. We have less unemployment under this Government than we had under the Fraser Government. We have less inflation under this Government than we had under the Fraser Government. If honourable members opposite want a signal as to what is the key to the success of industrial relations, surely those matters are pertinent to the points that have been made?

People talked today about the growth in the Public Service and said: `This is terrible. What has happened under this Government?'. The largest growth we had recently was in the last year of the Fraser Government when the Public Service grew by over 5 per cent between June 1982 and June 1983. Most of that growth took place in the last nine months of the Fraser Government. I will tell honourable members opposite why the Public Service grew. The previous Government put 250,000 additional people out of work in its last year of office. If the Opposition, when in government, put 250,000 people out of work, it would put a lot more people back into work in the Commonwealth Employment Service and in the social security offices in trying to service the wants of the unemployed. So honourable members opposite should not talk to us about the size of the Public Service.

Indeed, the Prime Minister in his statement to the House told us that it is the aim of the Government, this financial year, to reduce the size of the Public Service by up to 2,000 people. So in every way this Bill is aimed at expressing the sentiment in the public sector that we have insisted on in the private sector. It is another move to bring greater credit to the Public Service in the way it operates, in its efficiency and in its ability. I am sure that we will be able to do just that. As I have said, perhaps in some ways this legislation goes further than a lot of the employees in the Public Service would like. But the Government has a responsibility to the Australian people, not just the Public Service. We believe that, in the long run, what we are doing in this Bill will be of considerable assistance to the Australian people.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Connolly's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Young) read a third time.
