TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to advise the House of the following ministerial arrangements: The Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) will be absent from Australia on Government business from 19 to 22 November. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) will act as Minister for Trade during his absence. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) will not be present in the House today. The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) will answer questions which would normally be directed to the Attorney-General.

—My question is addressed to the Acting Treasurer. Is it proposed to change the reporting requirements under the taxation legislation for banks, financial institutions, real estate agents, stockbrokers and others who are required to record new information under the identity card Bill? If so, how, and what will be the extra compliance costs for these organisations?

—The Minister for Health has been wiping the floor with the Opposition on the subject of the Australia Card. He is the Minister responsible for the Australia Card, and that question should have been addressed to him.
—Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the Government's wages policy following its recent discussions with the peak business councils and the Australian Council of Trade Unions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to be able to answer a question on economic policy, which naturally enough would come from this side of the House. The Government believes that in the current economic circumstances it is necessary and desirable to revamp the system of wages fixation which has served this country so well in the past three years.

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: I draw your attention to standing order 144. We have here a request for an announcement of Government policy. Paragraph (b) of the second part of standing order 144 says that questions should not ask Ministers to announce Government policy.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Prime Minister has been asked for information. He is giving it.
—Madam Speaker, on a further point of order, if the Prime Minister would sit down--
—The Chair will direct the Prime Minister, not the honourable member for O'Connor.
—Madam Speaker, the question requested that Government policy be announced. If the questioner cannot get it right, that is not my fault. He did not ask for information.
—The question is in order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—In seeking to get a revamping of the system of wages fixation, the Government will seek to continue to get modest wage outcomes consistent with the capacity of the economy to pay, the need to preserve our international competitiveness and our need to maintain growth in jobs. But it is also important that it be understood that in seeking those outcomes we will be seeking a fair wages system which protects lower paid workers and their families. So in those circumstances it can be seen that the wages policy of this Government is fair, responsible and realistic.

ANSWER.PARA: In all those respects it stands in stark contrast to the wages policy of the Leader of the Opposition. That wages policy is nothing more nor less than hocus-pocus. It is a further example of the absolute bankruptcy of the Leader of the Opposition when it comes to economic policy. He peddles this conjurer's potion, at one and the same time talking about a decentralised wages system and a wages freeze.

The Leader of the Opposition is simply insulting the intelligence of the Australian people by believing that he can con them into accepting a proposition which talks at the same time about a decentralised wage fixing system and a wage freeze. But even more insulting than that is the fact that he is peddling himself as the champion of Australian families, when he is talking about no pay rise for Australian families for a period of 18 months. How can he be talking about himself as a champion of Australian families when he wants a wages freeze for 18 months?

I suggest to those who are looking at the Leader of the Opposition as the champion of the families that they might recall that in the past decade he has opposed any wage increase in 18 out of 20 national wage cases. On only two occasions in the past 10 years has he supported any increase in wages.

In not one area of economic management does the Leader of the Opposition have a policy which adds up. His wages policy does not add up, his fiscal policy does not add up and his family policy does not add up. I think one could say that the only thing on the Opposition side that is beginning to add up is the numbers against the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make an explanation to the honourable member for O'Connor so that the matter he raised is clear. Standing order 144 says that questions should not ask Ministers to announce government policy but may seek an explanation regarding the policy of the Government.

—I inform the House that we have present in the Gallery this afternoon a delegation from the United Kingdom branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association led by Sir Reginald Eyre, MP. On behalf of the House I extend to the delegation a very warm welcome.

—My question, which is addressed to the Prime Minister, relates to the taxation position of Australian families. Is it a fact that even after the so-called income tax cuts on 1 December virtually every single income family in this country will be paying a higher proportion of its income in pay as you earn income tax than it was in March 1983 when his Government was first elected to office? Specifically, is it a fact that because of the increased average tax burden during the period of this Government, single income families on average weekly earnings are paying an additional $23 a week in tax but will receive back only $8 a week on 1 December? Is this not a reflection of this Government's record as Australia's biggest taxing peacetime Government and its disregard for the taxation impact on families? Does it not also reflect the inherent failure of the Prime Minister's attempt at taxation reform, since he has failed to lower the overall tax burden on families and the economy more generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I go to the tax aspect, let me make the point that follows from my answer to the previous question from this side of the House. If we are to talk about the disposable income of people in Australia, it is relevant to suggest that people should look not only at tax policies but also at wages policies. I find it difficult to believe that any Australian family will derive any comfort from a position put by a Leader of the Opposition who has the record of having on only two occasions in the past 10 years said that there was any justification for an increase in wages. That is a clear nailing of what concern the Leader of the Opposition and those behind him have for the real welfare of the people of this country. If we are to talk about the welfare of Australian families, we should also address ourselves to the fundamental question of whether Australian families will be in a position to pay any tax at all.

ANSWER.PARA: What was the outcome of the policies of the Leader of the Opposition when he had the responsibility for the economic management of this country? He threw hundreds of thousands of people out of work. In the last 12 months of his occupancy of the treasurership of this country an additional one-quarter of a million Australians were thrown out of work. They did not have the option at all of paying any tax because he threw them out of work. If Opposition members look at their wages policy and their overall economic policy, like an increasing number of their supporters they will be turning away from the Leader of the Opposition in droves.

Let me go through this question of tax and remind the Leader of the Opposition that the Government has already cut the lowest marginal tax rate from 30c to 25c in the dollar and, as is well known, further tax cuts will be delivered from 1 December this year and, as is embodied in legislation, from 1 July next year. In regard to the question of tax cuts, let us have it on the record once and for all that the Leader of the Opposition had some five years as Treasurer of this country and his legacy in walking out of office was to leave the highest marginal tax rates. The best he could do was to leave a top tax rate of 60c in the dollar. Under this Government it is a matter of pride that from 1 July next year the top tax rate will be 49c in the dollar and there will be significant tax rate cuts further through the schedules.

We do not deny that under the tax regime that will come in under this Government some people will be worse off. Some people will be worse off as a result of the taxation changes that we have made. The people who will be worse off should be identified. They are the people who were making greater than average use of the tax shelters and other tax avoidance devices that flourished under the Government of the Leader of the Opposition. I remind the House and I remind the Leader of the Opposition again, as I have had cause to say in this House, that it was not our royal commissioner but his royal commissioner who brought down his report in 1981 in which he said that in the previous five years the fastest growing industry in this country was the tax avoidance industry. Not only did he say that but also he went on to ask who paid the price for that. He said it was the ordinary Australians who paid the price for that because the then Government did not have the guts, the wit, the courage or the wisdom to face up to the fact that it allowed tax avoidance to flourish.

The Leader of the Opposition tried to make some comparison between the tax rates at the end of his period in government and those under our Government. The Leader of the Opposition conveniently, as he does these days in relation to all matters of economic policy, overlooks an essential point in talking about changes in tax rates; that is, he deliberately overlooks the relative roles of public sector borrowing versus taxes in funding expenditure. The clear fact is that average tax rate figures at the end of the period of the Fraser Government were artificially low.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—The Leader of the Opposition can laugh his hollow laugh. We know that all he has left is his hollow laugh; he has nothing else. The fact is that those tax rates were artificially low because of the $10 billion projected deficit that the then Treasurer chose to hand over to the incoming Government. If this Government were irresponsible, it could produce significantly lower tax rates. It could slash tax rates by another $6 1/2 billion and produce lower tax rates if it were prepared to have the same deficit with which the Opposition left this country. The simple fact is that this Government is not prepared to fund the levels of government expenditure by having an irresponsible Budget deficit blow-out like that. It has brought down the Budget deficit from the near $10 billion that Treasurer Howard bequeathed to this country to $3 1/2 billion in the 1986-87 Budget, and in the same process it has reduced the marginal tax rate from that of 60c in the dollar which he bequeathed to this country.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. In view of the inaccurate, hyperbolic and at times hysterical claims and assertions of the Opposition, and indeed for the edification of honourable members opposite, can the Minister inform the House as to what safeguards will be introduced to ensure the proper protection of civil liberties in the protection of the rights of the individuals in relation to the Australia Card program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the question from the honourable member for Perth, I think it is ironic to note that the sudden converts to the privacy principle on the Opposition benches have not in any single speech on the Australia Card Bill or in any question asked in this House concerned themselves once with the privacy protections embedded in the Australia Card Bill and the associated privacy legislation.
—That is a lie.
—Order! The honourable member for Barker will withdraw that comment.
—I withdraw.

—In the Australia Card Bill we have tried to secure a balance between the need to protect the interests of the community by preventing tax evasion and welfare fraud and the need to preserve the rights of the individual to privacy and civil liberties.

ANSWER.PARA: In the measures that came before the House-as I said, on which we had no discussion-there are three elements to that protection: Firstly, the Data Protection Agency; secondly, the accompanying privacy legislation; and, thirdly, the actual safeguards written into the Australia Card Bill. The establishment of a Data Protection Agency is to provide for the first time an effective monitor not only of the activities of the authority in relation to the Australia Card but also of the use of all databanks by government in this society. That Agency will have the power to review the decisions taken by the Health Insurance Commission in its role as the Australia Card authority. It will have the power to issue guidelines to ensure that information that is kept on the Register is accurate and confidential. It will have the power to inquire into complaints that the guidelines have been breached. It will have the power to supervise the way in which the authority keeps the Register. It will have the power to publish a record of all Commonwealth databanks containing personal information; that is, it will have a series of major functions, to monitor not just the Australia Card but also the databanks held by government.

In addition, accompanying the Australia Card legislation was the privacy legislation which is the first comprehensive regulation in Australia for handling personal information to protect privacy. Though proposals were before the previous Government, in eight years nothing was done to bring forward privacy legislation. This privacy legislation of the Commonwealth will give the lead to the States. It will substantially implement the important recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission which are published in its privacy report, and it will provide a practical and workable code for protecting privacy principles in this country.

But that is not the end of the protections provided. In the Australia Card Bill particular protections in relation to privacy are enshrined. The Bill makes quite clear what are the details of the Australia Card and the only material that will be permitted on the Australia Card Register. In addition, every citizen of this country will have free access once every year to the information contained on him within that Register. The users of the Australia Card and all those eligible to make requests of it are defined in the Bill. The Bill makes it clear that there is no obligation to carry the card.

Furthermore, the Bill makes it quite clear that no further use for the Australia Card can be introduced except with the approval of both Houses of Parliament. Clear offences are prescribed in the legislation. Any unauthorised request for the card leads to a $5,000 fine, or two years imprisonment, or both. Any unauthorised access to the Register leads to a $5,000 fine or imprisonment for two years, or both; and any unauthorised disclosure of information from the Register involves the same penalty. Again, specifically built into the Bill are those particular provisions. Thus we believe that, with minimal comment from anyone on the other side, we have introduced the most broad-ranging and effective safeguards ever in this country to protect the individual's privacy. I will quote again because these people on the other side are not prepared to listen to the comments of those who are really interested in this issue-

TALK.START.PARA: —No one believes you; not a soul believes you.
—Order! The honourable member for Barker will cease interjecting.

—The credibility of the honourable member for Barker on this issue is so shot to pieces that I am surprised that he even bothers to interject. But I will quote to him what Professor Whalan said about what we were doing. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: If we do have an Australia Card, it is vital I believe that we have both very carefully circumscribed limits on its use and a protective body with similar independence to that possessed by the Ombudsman.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was on the Privacy Committee.
—Professor Whalan went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps one irony would be that if we do have an Australia Card with all those protections . . . our privacy may be better protected than it is now.

The honourable member for North Sydney has interjected about membership of the Privacy Committee. I would point out that Professor Robert Hayes, who is a member of the Law Reform Commission inquiring into privacy, supports the protections embedded in this Bill. Professor Whalan went on to say:
On the one hand a person's privacy ought to be protected, but on the other hand-
and I suggest the Opposition listen to this-
an individual citizen ought not to be able to use the shield of privacy to defraud the state or anyone else.

That is precisely the position the Opposition has now taken up, because it refuses to make a balance between the needs of the community and the needs of the individual. The Opposition, led by the Leader of the Opposition, in fact is claiming that people have a right to defraud the community. Honourable members opposite are cynically distorting the language of civil libertarians for that particular purpose. In seven years they did nothing about privacy legislation and they now pretend to be the great advocates of privacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the comments made last week by Mr Bob White, the Managing Director of the Westpac Banking Corporation and the former chairman of the Business Council of Australia, that the Australian economy is in more serious trouble now than at any time during the 46 years of his working life and that this situation will be made worse by the Government's additional tax imposts and its high interest rate policies. In view of the fact that the present level of the Australian dollar is essentially underpinned by the action of the Reserve Bank of Australia and our appallingly high interest rate structure, I ask the Prime Minister: When will the Government's professed Budget strategy of achieving a substantial and sustained reduction in Australian interest rates, including home loan interest rates, be achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that this question has been asked by the Leader of the Opposition. It puts any criticism of this Government in the mouth of Mr Bob White and therefore it is interesting to look at the position of the banks in Australia. Before the decision that was taken by this Government-a decision which honourable members opposite would have taken if they had had any commitment to principle at all and any courage to open up and make a more competitive position; they never had the guts, the courage, the wit or the wisdom to do so-honourable members opposite allowed to flourish in this country the most sheltered banking system anywhere in the Western world, with the highest profit rates of any banking system in the world, and they did not have the courage to do anything about it. Now what has happened is that the cosseted, comforted, confined, protected banking industry in this country has now been opened up to the severe wind of competition, and it does not particularly like it. Now that Australian banks are forced to live in a more competitive environment they are blaming this Government for their relatively static performance. It simply does not wash.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at the criticisms that Mr White made. He made a criticism about the interest rate ceiling on the pre-package home loans. In regard to that particular part of his criticisms the facts are simple, straightforward and not capable of being argued with. There was a discussion, a negotiation, between this Government and the banks, including Mr White's bank, and the banks were compensated by a subsidy to the tune of $140m as part of that housing package. They criticise it now, but at the time-I believe, quite understandably-that package with its $140m subsidy was perfectly acceptable to the banks. It was agreed to; it was welcomed by them. Now they criticise it to some extent. May I say that the regular information which has been provided by the banks since the package does not show any reduction in margins with respect to housing loans. The same gentleman, Mr White, went on to make criticisms of the fringe benefits tax. Let me say simply that this Government will not be diverted from bringing equity, fairness and economic efficiency into the tax system of this country by the whinges and the whines of the Bob Whites of this world. We simply do not accept the criticism of Mr White about the fringe benefits tax because, as an increasing proportion of the people of this country are coming to realise, the fringe benefits tax is a vital element of the tax reform package aimed at remedying the disastrous situation which honourable members opposite inflicted on this country, and we will not be moving away from it.

It is a pity that, in the process of criticising this Government's tax reform package, Mr White did not have the common decency to refer to the very significant advantages that the business community stands to gain from the tax reform package. I refer particularly to full imputation. Full imputation was something that the business community, including the banking community, had been talking about for years in this country. But it never looked like getting that sensible reform from that pathetic mob opposite. Full imputation, which we have brought in in regard to company tax, is one of the most far-reaching measures of assistance to business ever introduced in this country.

Let me say in regard to the question of interest rates that the Leader of the Opposition knows, when he lapses into the occasional moments of realism and departs from the almost total cynicism and opportunism which characterises his conduct these days, that because of the massive turnaround in the terms of trade that was inflicted on this country, responsible economic management required a monetary policy which was relevant to that condition. No government likes to have a monetary policy regime which means high interest rates. But, in the circumstances inflicted upon this country, such a regime, such a policy, was necessary to protect and advance the interests of this country. What is increasingly becoming evident is that that range of economic policies is having its impact. There has been some decline in interest rates in the last two months. We will not interrupt that flow of forces which we believe, if allowed to operate, will mean that as we go through into 1987 there will be a gradual lowering in the interest rate regime in this country. But we will not prejudice that outcome by artificially speculating on timetables on what we consider will inevitably happen in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether Australia recently put forward to the General Assembly of the United Nations a proposal for a comprehensive test ban treaty. What support or opposition did that proposal receive? Could the Minister evaluate the outcome of the initiative?

—The Government certainly did put forward such a proposal. In association with New Zealand we promoted a resolution for a comprehensive test ban treaty. This Australia-New Zealand resolution received the highest number of positive votes of all five resolutions put forward on that subject. It received 117 votes and its supporters included the majority of Western non-nuclear states, as well as the Soviet Union and its allies. Twenty-six countries co-sponsored the Australian text, including Sweden, Canada, Japan and Papua New Guinea. Only one country voted against it and that was France. The second Australian resolution called on the nuclear testing states to make public each test and provide certain data, including the size of the test and the geology of the test site. This was a new initiative and the resolution received 107 positive votes. Only one country-France-opposed the resolution. In short, the Australian Government has demonstrated once again that it is taking a lead in the area of arms control and disarmament and that it is able to mobilise extensive international support for the initiatives it is taking. As a consequence, Australia is a voice that is respected and listened to-in fact it is regarded as a leading voice on the issue of arms control and disarmament internationally.

—The Minister for Health has laid great emphasis on the role that the digitised strip will play in maintaining the integrity of the ID card. But the Minister has now made it clear that clause 36 certificates will be a substitute in many transactions for the ID card. Will the Minister confirm that these certificates will not have a photograph or a digitised strip on them and as a mere piece of paper they will be easily forged or duplicated? How then will the integrity of the certificate be maintained?

—If the honourable member for Barker would bother to read the Bill he would see the outline of the details in relation to the verification certificates. Of course such certificates will not contain a photograph. They will simply be verification by a responsible member of the community that that person has seen the photograph and identified the person and the number. This question illustrates the confusion of the Opposition. We have the honourable member for Gwydir running around the countryside saying that things will be so terrible for farmers that they will have to take their cows, sheep and dogs and have them certified in Sydney. On the other hand the honourable member for Barker is saying that things will be so loose that any farmer can easily collect this kind of certificate.

—When the barking has stopped I will re-emphasise the point that I have made throughout in responding to the sorts of questions put by the honourable member for Barker and the rather silly comments made by the honourable member for Gwydir. I suppose he has to prove the dedication of his conversion to opposition to the Australia Card. Between these extreme statements made by the honourable member for Barker and the honourable member for Gwydir, the Government has to take a reasonable position which will ensure security but at the same time make it possible for people who find it difficult--
—What security is there in a piece of paper?
—I warn the honourable member for Barker; I will not put up with his ceaseless interjections.
—While maintaining the security of the card we must deal with those very real problems faced by some people who have difficulties of mobility or distance.

—Has the Acting Treasurer seen reports that the Opposition intends to abolish the Prices Surveillance Authority? Would he inform the House of the effect of such a move on price restraint in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen these reports; they are incredible, but I believe them to be true. I suppose it is not surprising that, in one of the few areas that the Opposition has given the Australian people the courtesy of announcing a policy, it is such a stupid one which runs against the interests of all Australians, including Australian families. The policy deserves to be totally rejected and the Australian people will totally reject it. As our Government undertakes the fundamental changes for the greater competitiveness that is needed if we are to stay on the job growth path, then restraint is vital. Restraint to the Opposition is only restraint for wages and salaries. I make it clear that restraint for the Government is restraint across the board-it is restraint in dividends and it applies to price makers as well, those who have the power of setting prices.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prices Surveillance Authority does very valuable work in restraining prices. Its work is mainly to ensure that there is real competition because true competition achieves the objective of the lowest possible prices. However, there are areas in which there are monopolies and oligopolies, and those situations need to be further examined. That is where the Authority's work is also effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, you are putting the Gallery to sleep.
—The Gallery does not need to learn what a monopoly is; only dummies like you need to learn that.
—You hopeless idiot!
—I warn the honourable member for Denison. If he continues to interject the Chair will deal with him.

—To abolish this valuable tool of fairness and restraint would be scandalous. Like the Opposition's wages policy, this proposal is an invitation to further inflation. I wish to thank Mrs Hilda Rolfe, the chairperson of the Prices Surveillance Authority, and other members and staff for the very good work they are doing. There are numerous examples of the Authority restraining prices. In the last few months it has linked with the Trade Practices Commission and built up a complaints mechanism recording complaints about prices. Mrs Rolfe and her colleagues have lifted the profile of the Authority enormously over those months. Such is the demand for information from the Authority that Mrs Rolfe now speaks to two million Australians on talkback radio each week.
—What about you, Scoop?

—I am speaking to many of them regularly as well-and very valuably, too. I tell honourable members that it is better to be a big scoop than a little twerp! This exchange of information about prices is very valuable indeed and it helps to make the work of price restraint much more effective. In that context I wish to thank the honourable member for Canning and many of his colleagues on this side of the House for the work that they are doing in setting up price watch committees. I also wish to thank them for their interest in the Prices Surveillance Authority, because, through the work of the Caucus prices task force, we are also lifting the profile of the Prices Surveillance Authority. I also wish to thank the honourable member for Capricornia for the work that he does on the Caucus consumer affairs committee. He is also helping to get value for money and he is a valuable part of the fight against inflation.

—Honourable members opposite do not like hearing this. I will let the House into a secret. I would like price restraint work to be parliamentary work and not just Caucus work. We would all like it to be effective parliamentary work, but how can that be when we have this myopic attitude to this beneficial work on prices that is being done at present? All we get from the Opposition is a pathetic Press release on prices from the Leader of the Opposition last weekend, and we cannot put any credibility on that because members of the Opposition have no policy at all to address prices. I condemn them for not joining us in this anti-inflationary work and I condemn them for their policy of abolishing the Prices Surveillance Authority.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. I remind him of the many distinguished and knowledgeable Australians such as Mr Justice Kirby and Mr Frank Costigan, QC-the latter dedicated to the elimination of tax evasion in all its forms-who have come out in opposition to the Australia Card. Will the Minister agree that these individuals, particularly the two I have just named, are as well placed as he is to make a judgment on the utility of the card and the dangers inherent in it? In fact, will the Minister not concede that Mr Costigan's understanding of the use and misuse of a computerised system for identification purposes would far exceed his own and that indeed Mr Costigan's knowledge on this subject is unique in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would prefer in fact to rely on the members of this House, on both sides, who have actively supported the need for a national identification system and on the Commissioner of Taxation who has to make that system work. We are now in the position of having had a select committee report from all parties in this Parliament which, while it did not support the particular proposals of the Government, did support a national identification system based on tax file numbers. That group supported a national identification system.

ANSWER.PARA: The Standing Committee on Expenditure, which recently reviewed the Australian Taxation Office, concluded that the Australian Taxation Office needed to take steps to establish a high integrity identification system which would ensure maximum taxpayer compliance. So, a second body of this Parliament believes in the need for a national identification system, at least in relation to the tax system.

Of course, there are the comments of the man who actually has to work the system, that is, the Commissioner, and I value those very highly indeed as coming from somebody who really understands the problems of taxation in this society. What the Opposition at some time has to tell the people of Australia is why it has turned its back on all those proposals-not just the Australia Card, but every proposal for an effective taxation identification system in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. Is the Government about to sell the existing rifle range at Malabar? If so, will the Government make another site available suitable to be used by the many thousands of shooters in the Sydney area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has made a decision that the rifle range at Malabar is surplus to its requirements, and the decision was to dispose of it in this financial year. Arising out of that decision, I wrote to the New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment, Bob Carr, asking him to prepare a land use plan for the area. The land use plan is under way. There has been an interim verbal report.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister said that there are problems with the site in that there has been a great deal of infill because it was used as a garbage tip many years ago and that, therefore, there will be problems with construction on the site. Also, in October I was notified by the Australian Heritage Commission that, of the 140 hectare site, 80 hectares to the east and west of the rifle range had been nominated for a place on the Register of the National Estate.

I am awaiting the land use report from the New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment. When we get that report the Australian Government, together with the New South Wales Government, local government, community groups and, I might say, the local member, who is the Deputy Prime Minister, will discuss the final disposal of that property.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware that a variety of false identity cards with photographs can be purchased in Times Square in New York for just $6 each and that there are already claims in Australia that the Australian identity card could be forged adequately for as little as $20 a card? With that information, and knowing that the digital strip will be illegible to the private sector, on what basis does the Minister disagree with the United States Justice Department's view that `organised crime would take advantage of any national identity system because of the presumption of validity surrounding such a large system'?

—If the honourable member for Mayo had really devoted his researches into the particular identification card problems of the United States he would recognise that that country's problem, which is admitted, is that it has a de facto identification card-it has developed out of its social security number essentially-and, therefore, has never had built in the security protections that are being proposed for the Australia Card number. I can say with complete confidence that the Australia Card, incorporating state of the art technology, will be incomparably more secure than any financial or identity card currently in use in Australia, and it is our belief that it will be more secure than the cards used in any other national identification system in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented.
—You should seek leave to make a personal explanation, then I ask you whether you claim to have been misrepresented.

—Madam Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented by the Minister for Health in one of his more excitable moments. I did not say that every time a farmer has to sell a consignment of cattle or whatever, he will have to identify himself in Sydney. To put the record straight, I will quote what I did say. Do you mind if I quote to put the record straight?
—So long as it is not a page and a half.
—My Press release said:

SPEECH.PARA: The card would have to be presented when a farmer sold produce to a marketing authority or agency.
In the presence of the Minister, I said here last week:

Primary producers will need to present the card before they can deal with marketing authorities or agencies. When farmers realise this they will go off their heads. This will be an incredible bureaucratic problem for agents and farmers and, if I am any judge, we will see an increase in commission by agents to try to cope with the bureaucratic requirements in this clause of the Bill.
That is clause 43 (1).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, again, by the Minister for Health.
—Please proceed.

—I raise with you, firstly, that the Minister for Health continually misrepresents a number of my colleagues on this side and me. He seems to be unable to tell the truth. Is there any action we can take at the time at which he makes-

—No. Would you mind resuming your seat for a moment? You have risen to make a personal explanation and I will hear that in just a moment. When someone in this House has the call and is debating, answering a question or whatever, there is no way in which you can make a personal explanation then. You must wait until after the presentation of papers or, if it is urgent, the nearest possible time.
—Even if he is telling lies?

—Would you stop interjecting? That is what I am getting to. You cannot sit in your seat consistently interjecting on whoever has the call from the Chair, because in doing so you put yourself outside the Standing Orders under which you are supposed to heed the Chair. Would you like to proceed with your personal explanation?
—I would, thank you. It is just that when one is so grossly misrepresented one seeks a way to try to remedy the problem at the time.
—You have the floor now.
—On two occasions during Question Time the Minister for Health misrepresented a number of my colleagues and me.
—You must speak only for yourself.
—And all members of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. The recommendations, firstly, of the Joint Select Committee referred to a national--

—Could I just interrupt for a moment? You must tell the House where you personally were misrepresented, not where your colleagues or your Committee were misrepresented-only where you, the honourable member for Barker, were personally misrepresented.

—I have been personally misrepresented by the Minister for Health, who has stated that I, in signing the Joint Select Committee report on the identification card, supported a national identification system. The recommendation relating to tax file numbers related only to tax file numbers for the purposes of the Australian Taxation Office and did not relate to a national identification system. Secondly, the Minister claimed in an earlier answer during Question Time that I and a number of honourable members on this side of the House had not raised the grave civil liberties concerns that we have in relation to the ID card. I quote only two sentences of my speech last Thursday, when I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this system provides unparalleled opportunities for government abuse of personal confidential information.
I went on to say:
These are significant issues which are of enormous concern, not only to the Opposition but also to many Government members who obviously oppose the ID card.
We dealt in detail with the civil liberties concerns that the Opposition and many members of the public have. It is quite wrong for the Minister to come in here--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not debate the issue, please. You have already pointed out--
—And mislead the House by suggesting that we had not done so.
—You must not debate the issue. You have already pointed out where you have been misrepresented, that is enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—Please proceed.
—The Minister for Health, in answer to a question from the honourable member for Perth (Mr Charlesworth), said this:

SPEECH.PARA: In responding to the question from the honourable member for Perth, I think it is ironic to note that the sudden converts to the privacy principle on the Opposition benches have not in any single speech on the Australia Card Bill--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Where is the honourable member personally misrepresented?
—I am coming to that. I have to put it in context so it can be understood. The quote continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . or in any question asked in this House concerned themselves once with the privacy protections embedded in the Australia Card Bill and the associated privacy legislation.
This is untrue and it is known to the Minister to be untrue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The Minister for Health did not personally attack the honourable member for North Sydney.
—He misrepresented my speech.
—It was a general comment he made. The honourable member for North Sydney was not mentioned by the Minister for Health.
—He said that none of us had raised this question.
—The honourable member will resume his seat. The honourable member was not personally misrepresented.

—I take a point of order. The point of order is that he has said: `Not one of the speakers'. I was one of the speakers on the Australia Card Bill and I was the lead speaker for the Opposition on the other Bill.
—You were not personally misrepresented. You will please resume your seat.
—He misrepresented my statement, and he did so deliberately knowing that it was quite untrue.
—Resume your seat, please. The honourable member has not been personally misrepresented.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. Are you saying that one can generalise when one lies, but one cannot lie specifically?

—Order! What I am saying is what is clearly expressed within the Standing Orders. Would you like me to read them to the House? The honourable member must show where he or she personally has been misrepresented.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. What redress does an honourable member have when there is a general smear, and inaccurate remarks are made by a Minister in this manner?

—The honourable member has been in this House long enough to know that people from either side of the House consistently attack politics and policies of the parties. The only alternative you have is to reply in the next debate. It has applied in this House for over 50 years that in a personal explanation you must show where you personally have been misrepresented, not where your party or the Opposition has been misrepresented; it is where you personally have been misrepresented. If you want something different from that, I suggest you go to the Standing Committee on Procedure and put the matter before it. It is no good expecting the Chair always to sort out the problems into which the House gets itself, when it does not have the courage to alter its Standing Orders and to make them more precise.

—I suggest to the House that there will be a three hour debate on the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure next Tuesday night. I tell all the wimps opposite to get up next Tuesday night and give us their views and I will take them into very serious consideration.

—I hope that the members of the House do this. If you go back to your rooms and read the standing order and House of Representatives Practice explaining the standing order, you will find that a misrepresentation must be personal. There are probably occasions when it has not been-if fact, I know of occasions when I have sat here myself-but on the whole you must stick to where you personally have been misrepresented.
—Madam Speaker, with respect, the Minister did not say `the Opposition', he said: `No single speaker who has spoken in the debate'.
—He did not mention a name.
—That singled out a series of people individually. I personally was offended by that. It was untrue and he should not be allowed to get away with it.
—I understand your problem, but you must put into effect Standing Orders to cover these eventualities.
—Madam Speaker, I seek your guidance. Is it therefore permissible for me to call these people a mob of liars, but not to call an honourable member a liar?
—No, that is unparliamentary language, so you would not get away with it.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; BURR; CAMERON; CARLTON; EDWARDS; HAWKER
PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office Agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Burr,Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Carlton,Dr Harry Edwards and Mr Hawker.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BLUNT; CARLTON; COWAN; FIFE; HICKS; PUNCH
PETITION.NAMEIDS: WE4; DF4; VF4; CG4; AH4; SI4
PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.
Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Carlton,Mr Cowan,Mr Fife,Mr Hicks and Mr Punch.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hollis,Ms Jakobsen,Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Fife.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
5. We also feel it is morally wrong for one person to be forced to pay the taxes for another.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are seriously concerned about the impact of the Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. It is unjust for any person to be liable for tax on benefits received by another person.
2. Compliance with FBT will increase administrative costs for all employers including Local, State and Federal government departments.
3. FBT is an inefficient tax, which will require the Tax Office to employ an army of bureaucrats.
4. FBT is inequitable because liability arises regardless of capacity to pay.
5. The FBT laws are extremely complex.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That the anomalous Fringe Benefits tax is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair on the grounds that-
it adversely affects business throughout Australia, including farms,
by creating a further tax burden it destroys incentive,
it has caused unemployment,
it is costly to administer and its complexities have caused confusion and widespread anger.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Fringe Benefits tax legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled, we the undersigned citizens call upon all Members to pay due respect to pensioners and concessional card holders and cease the constant erosion of our entitlements by the Hawke Government.
The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:

That we strenuously object to the Government's decision to delete 45 commonly prescribed drugs (including analgesics, anti-histamines, cough mixtures and expectorants) from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme;

That we strenuously object to the Health Minister's assertion that the health problems for which these medications are prescribed (e.g. arthritis and allergic rhinitis) are `relatively minor, self-limiting illnesses'.
That we beg the House to reconsider these deletions from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Fife and Mr Wilson.

PETITION.TITLE: Glen Waverley Rehabilitation Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that the phasing down and eventual closure of the services of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Centre at Glen Waverley will be detrimental to the rehabilitation of disabled Australian citizens;
(2) that the Glen Waverley Rehabilitation Centre is `purpose' built and its loss would deprive disabled Australian citizens of a unique multi-million dollar facility;
(3) that the essential accommodation for disabled Australian citizens will no longer be available.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) that the phasing down of the services of the Glen Waverley Rehabilitation Centre be reversed immediately;
(2) that the one-hundred-and-four-bed residential facility be fully utilised immediately;
(3) that sufficient funding is provided by the Commonwealth Department of Community Services to operate the Centre at full capacity.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Peaceful Relations with People
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled to Petition of Peace your Petitioners therefore pray that the Government is more committed in establishing peaceful relations with the People within and outside of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Textile, Clothing and Footwear Industries
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, members of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Unions, shows:
We believe that Australia needs a strong and vigorous manufacturing industry. The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Industries make up 10% of our manufacturing industry.
Manufacturing needs TCF.
Your petitioners therefore pray, that you reject the IAC's recommendations for the TCF Industries and accept the TCF Unions Alternative Plan.

PETITION.TITLE: Textile, Clothing and Footwear Industries
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, members of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Unions, shows-
we reject the proposal of the IAC to cut protection to a 50% tariff
we reject the IAC's projection that 20,000 jobs will be lost. We say it will be more like 60,000 jobs.
we reject the IAC's view that we will find new jobs without assistance to retrain
we reject the IAC's finding that 60,000 jobs will be created in mining, agriculture and elsewhere
Your petitioners therefore pray, that you will reject the IAC's recommendations for the TCF Industries and accept the TCF Unions Alternative Plan.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should;
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices;
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes, and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That Labor's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tax on lump sum superannuation and assets test are an unwarranted burden on the people of Australia, have contributed to the national economic crisis and the anomalies in the legislation and are causing confusion and anger amongst all sections of the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Assets Test, Labor's Capital Gains Tax, Labor's Fringe Benefits Tax and Labor's tax on lump sum superannuation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
in this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a Nuclear Test Moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers
that such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
that such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would
be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament
impede the development of new nuclear weapons
decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy
inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Summerland Point Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Summerland Point Post Office recently closed at short notice by Australia Post should be reopened.
2. This Post Office has serviced a community consisting mainly of the aged and young families with small children who are now faced with a five kilometre journey to the nearest Post Office.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should ask the Minister for Communications not to deny the 800 permanent residents of Summerland Point on Lake Macquarie the use of a Post Office.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Give speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Constitution
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Leader and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with mismanagement of the Otway forests in Victoria, and we pray that:
The Constitution of Australia be reformed to recognise significant public expressions of concern, e.g. petitions by some action, e.g. referendums or committees of inquiry.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-

(1) A cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons would break the cycle of research, development and deployment of nuclear weapons and prevent the acquisition of new and ever more lethal weapons of mass destruction. It would thus be a major and significant step towards ending the arms race and beginning the disarmament process; and
(2) The Soviet Union has extended its unilateral moratorium on nuclear weapons testing until 6 August this year and has again invited the United States to cease its nuclear testing program.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Australian Government to put the strongest pressure on the United States Government to join the Soviet Union's nuclear test ban.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operation Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions on a reasonable sliding scale
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investment.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: First International Earth Repair Year
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will: Propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Conditions of Service and the Remuneration for Australian Defence Forces Personnel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. that serving members of the Australian Defence Forces are frustrated and disillusioned at the continuing erosion of their conditions of employment, benefits and entitlements traditionally provided in recognition of the burdens placed on themselves and their families by service in the Defence Forces;

2. that the Government's decision to discount by 2 per cent the retirement benefits of members of the Australian Defence Forces has broken a trust that should exist between servicemen and the Government concerning the financial security of themselves and their families in retirement;

3. that the Government's decision to discount the retirement benefits of members of the Australian Defence Forces has seriously lowered the morale and commitment of servicemen and will further increase the number of experienced servicemen leaving the Defence Forces.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you establish or expedite reviews of conditions, salary, allowances, entitlements and benefits for servicemen and reverse the decision to discount by 2% retirement benefits for servicemen.

PETITION.TITLE: Secondary Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of Western Australia call on the Commonwealth Government to reverse recent decisions which deny Secondary Allowances to Year 11 Students under the age of 16 years and make such allowances directly payable to students on attaining the age of 16.
This request is made on the basis that:
(i) Education benefits as part of income support benefits generally are a Commonwealth responsibility under the constitution.

(ii) It is the right of parents with children in Year 11 in Western Australia to receive the same benefits as parents with children at the equivalent stage of their education in other parts of Australia irrespective of their age.
(iii) This decision by the Commonwealth Government will impact most unfairly on the capacity of low income families in Western Australia to keep their children at school in Years 11 and 12.

(iv) Direct payment of the allowance to 16 years olds will make it easier for young people to leave home and bring more pressure on State Authorities to find alternative accommodation for them at the community and taxpayers' expense.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal its anti-business anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Regional Stations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Maranoa respectfully showeth that:
The ABC proposes to abolish certain country programmes from regional stations.
Such action will disadvantage those country listeners who only have the benefit of one radio station.

Regional stations broadcast entertainment and topics of local interest and any reduction in these programmes will undoubtedly inconvenience those listeners in the more remote and isolated areas of the state.
Talk back shows and the Hospital Hour are only two such programmes which it is thought are to be abolished.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Approach the ABC requesting that they reconsider their proposal to adopt the above and that commonsense prevail in ensuring that those listeners who reside in country areas are not disregarded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Parkes electorate respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has announced its intention to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, currently the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985.

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government had no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in this manner.

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but is handing over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia.

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia.
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to prevent this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the assembled Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.
We the humble petitioners at Warrnambool Institute Student Union, in the Federal electorate of Wannon respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of an Administration Charge of $250 for higher education students in Appropriation Bill 1986-87 (Volume-1, Page-98) is a regressive step for the Education system;
That the introduction of an Administration Charge will force students to withdraw from studies and thereby destroy the opportunity for them to complete their education;
That the Administration Charge is a form of Tuition Fees and as such destroys the principle of free education for all;
We the humble petitioners hereby request you to amend the Appropriation Bill 1986-87, so that the system of free education for all students will continue.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Sales to France
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned, respectfully showeth that we, the people of Victoria would like to remind you of your moral duty in regard to your decision to sell Uranium to France, against ALP policy.
The French are still nuclear testing in the South Pacific, despite world wide protests. We therefore call on you to reverse the decision to sell uranium to France.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Staff Elected Director
