PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned who are staff of the ABC and the SBS respectfully showeth that: The proposed legislation to amalgamate the ABC and the SBS, together with certain existing provisions of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 (as amended), would have the effect of removing the present Staff Elected Director of the ABC from office before the end of his elected term, and of barring him from standing for re-election. This offends basic democratic principle.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that: The Government will remedy this situation by either, continuing the current Staff Elected Director in office until the normal expiration of his term on 15 December 1987 or, making such amendments as are necessary to the Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Act 1986, to enable the current Staff Elected Director to contest an early election after amalgamation, whilst preventing him from seeking a further term immediately following the one for which the early election is held.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT'S HOUSING, INTEREST RATE AND TAXATION POLICIES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The impact on living standards for hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians caused by the failure of the Government's housing, interest rate and relevant taxation policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's housing, interest rate and taxation policies have failed. The failure of these policies is now causing hardship and affecting the living standards of hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians. The failure of these policies is causing hardship to ordinary Australians in the following ways: Firstly, it has meant that housing interest rates have climbed sharply and hence home loan repayments are significantly higher than before; secondly, the rental market in Australia has deteriorated sharply with rents increasing at an alarming rate and vacancy levels going down; and thirdly, there has been the massive increase in public housing waiting lists around Australia. The increase in public housing waiting lists from about 125,000 at the end of June 1985 to 151,000 at the end of June 1986 is a savage indictment of the Government's inability to deal with our nationwide housing crisis and yet another example of how this Government's policies are affecting the disadvantaged in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) will speak in this matter of public importance on the crisis in the rental market. But I now want to return to the failure of the Government's interest rate policy and the impact it is having on the living standards of hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has for months been saying that the direction that housing takes will depend on the direction of interest rates. Let us take for example, what he said on the Today program this morning. He said:
I am also as certain as I can be that we have got the economic parameters in place which will be conducive to a fall in general interest rates over the next few quarters.
He went on to say:
Now, of course, there is a small blip here and there.

Whatever that means. But the Minister acknowledges that the level of housing interest rates is the key factor in determining the future of housing. What has happened to home loan interest rates since the Hawke Government came to power? I regret that today is not tomorrow because it was two years ago tomorrow when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said to the nation:
Australia and Australians will during 1985 reap the interest rate rewards that are flowing from the successful policies of the past 20 months.
We've ploughed the fields and sown the seeds, in the very near future we will harvest the crop.

What has happened to home loan interest rates since then? They were at 11 1/2 per cent when the current Government came to power; by March 1985 they had climbed to 12 per cent; by October of that year they were up 13 1/2 per cent; when the April package came out they were up to 15 1/2 per cent; and yesterday, when the National Australia Bank Ltd announced it would increase home loan interest rates for certain customers, they went up to 17 1/2 per cent. So much for harvesting the crop. In two miserable, horrible years home loan interest rates have risen from 11 1/2 per cent to 17 1/2 per cent. No wonder the coalition brings this matter of public importance to the House today.

But what does this increase in interest rates mean for the living standards of hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians? It means simply that ordinary Australians have to pay more in home loan repayments than they did two years ago. Let us take, for example, an average $50,000 loan necessary to buy a modest house in suburban Australia. The monthly repayments on a $50,000 loan two years ago were $510 a month; by October they had climbed to $550 a month; by February 1986 they had climbed to $580 a month; when the April package came out they had gone to $660 a month; and today they are at $740 a month. Home loan repayments on a $50,000 loan repayable over 25 years have increased from $510 a month two years ago to $740 a month today. What a disaster for hundreds and thousands of ordinary Australians. This increase of $230 a month over that two- year period is an increase of 45 per cent. The Minister should not say `Oh, well, only a few people are affected by this', because for older home loans the increase has gone from $510 a month to $580 a month. That 12 per cent increase occurred in one year. Not only the Minister thinks that the future of housing is totally bound up with the future of interest rates. In this morning's Age the Chief Manager of the Westpac Banking Corporation said:
High interest rates in the economy have made it difficult for savings banks to attract deposits.
The Executive Director of the Australian Bankers Association said:
There would need to be a major review (of arrangements for housing finance) if market rates-
market interest rates-
did not fall by around 4 per cent by early 1987.

What will happen to the level of interest rates over the coming months? When can hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians expect some relief from the vice-like grip that exists on home loan repayments? Let me tell honourable members what the Minister thinks about this. He said, again in this morning's Today program, that the conditions necessary for a fall in interest rates would be to `exercise restraint in expenditure', and for the trade unions to `exercise restraint with regard to wage claims which have, on both measures, been truly met'. The Minister said that this morning. He said that restraint in expenditure and restraint on wage claims had been truly met.

If the Minister thinks that his Government is exercising the necessary expenditure restraint, perhaps he has not read the deficit figures that were released yesterday for the first four months of the current financial year. The deficit for the first four months was $6.2 billion compared with a full year deficit estimate of $3.5 billion. The Minister will say that, for a variety of reasons, outlays in the first few months of any financial year tend to run a little ahead of receipts and it is quite normal for that kind of Budget figure-that is, the $6.2 billion-to occur in the first four months of the year. But I say to the Minister: If that number were to be consistent with what happened last year, the number that should have been published yesterday would not have been $6.2 billion, it would have been $3.4 billion. Government expenditure is now running $2.8 billion above the forecast in the Budget. There is no way that the Government will bring in a Budget deficit as low as $3.5 billion this year. The deficit for this year is currently running at a level of $6 billion.

The sleight of hand which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) used to demonstrate the Budget deficit for this financial year of $3.5 billion was made in an atmosphere where hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians would have been prepared to exercise restraint. But the Budget deficit figure, just like the 2 April housing package, has been blown out of the water by this latest release and it is now abundantly clear that the Government, to quote the Minister, has not truly met the necessary expenditure restraint. In these circumstances the Government will have to go to the money markets to raise what is necessary to fund the increasing deficit and this will keep upward pressure on interest rates.

There is also a deliberate Government policy of keeping interest rates at a high level in order to attract the funds from abroad necessary to cover our seemingly ever increasing current account deficit. The trade figures for last month, when our current account deficit showed a level of nearly $1.75 billion, was the worst in Australia's history. The only way in which we can become more competitive internationally is to introduce more flexibility into our wages market; more flexibility for necessary adjustment to international competitive situations; more flexibility so that employers and employees can work together to be more productive and more competitive for their mutual benefit; and more flexibility so that we can move towards the elimination of unnecessary and costly restrictive work practices. The Government has shown no interest in creating the appropriate climate that would allow us to compete abroad. The evidence that the Government's policies have failed is clear for everyone to see in our increasing balance of payments problem.

The Budget estimate for our balance of payments deficit this year is $14 billion but already, for the first four months, it is $6 billion. That means that, to meet the Budget forecast, the deficit for the next eight months will have to be $1 billion a month. Does the Government seriously believe that it can average $1 billion a month for the next eight months when last month the figure was $1.73 billion and the average for the last four months has been $1.5 billion? The Government is in fairyland and there is no way that the Minister can say that the Government has truly met restraint with regard to wage claims. I have to tell the House that today the Australian Council of Trade Unions went before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on the national wage case and guess what it asked for? It asked for full indexation of 6.7 per cent in line with the consumer price index increase.

What of the other thousands of ordinary Australians who will be affected by the failure of the Government's housing interest rates and taxation policies and who will lose their jobs? On the night of 2 April this year-the night the Government introduced its increasingly irrelevant housing package-the Prime Minister stood before the nation and promised that there would be 135,000 housing starts in the 1986-87 year. Furthermore, the Treasurer, on 22 September in this House, said:
I have no basis for altering the assumption of 135,000 starts across the year.
So there we have the Prime Minister on 2 April and the Treasurer less than two months ago promising that there would be 135,000 new housing starts in the current financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Telling fibs.

—That is right, because the Prime Minister also said on 2 April that each 10,000 housing starts represents 15,000 jobs. Part of the rationale for the introduction of the package and the financing availability that would flow from it was to be on the basis of the jobs that would not be lost. In June the Indicative Planning Council, the Government's own advisory body, told the Government that it expected that housing starts for the year would be around 130,000. In its report prepared for the Australian Housing Research Council on 3 October it said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the recovery over the course of the year is weaker than forecast . . . and as a consequence total commencements . . . are forecast to be lower at 122,500.

According to the Government's own advisory body, that means that there will be 12,500 fewer housing starts in the current year than the Prime Minister said on 2 April and the Treasurer confirmed two months ago. This is even fewer than the 147,000 starts, which is the underlying demand. Twelve thousand five hundred fewer housing starts means a loss of 20,000 jobs in the housing industry. What about the impact on the living standards of those 20,000 ordinary Australians who have been put out of work by the Government's policy failures?

This Government's policies have failed. The failure of the Government's policies has meant that hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians are being subjected to significantly higher home loan interest rates than they were 12 months ago. The failure of the Government's policies has meant that housing loan repayments, on an average size new loan, have increased by 45 per cent over the past two years. The Government's failure to carry out the appropriate expenditure restraint and establish a framework for appropriate wage restraint means that interest rates will continue at high levels. The failure of the Government's policies has adversely affected the living standards of hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians who will never forget the way in which their lives have been affected and they will empty this Government out of office at the next Federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time today members of the Opposition were flat and the Opposition spokesman on housing and construction, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), was flat in the speech he has just made. Members of the Opposition say that this is a matter of public importance but they had no questions at all to ask at Question Time today. The reason is that the Opposition has no policy on housing, and no policy on anything at all for that matter. It had a bad housing record in government and it has a confused non-policy in opposition. The Opposition proposes to abolish the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement tied programs, for instance. This would abolish the crisis accommodation program, the local government and community housing program, the pensioners rental program, the mortgage and rent relief scheme and the Aboriginal rental program. All of these programs would go if the Opposition had its way. It also says that it wants to abolish the first home owners scheme. I will deal with the merits of that scheme later in my contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look right across the board at housing policy, it would be very difficult to design a policy that would inflict more damage and hardship on first home seekers and on those in special housing need in the community than would the Opposition's proposals. It is no wonder there is no support for the Opposition's housing policy from anywhere in Australia. There is no support from industry organisations such as the Housing Industry Association or the Master Builders Federation of Australia. There is no support from the social welfare lobbies in the housing area, such as shelter, and no support from the trade unions.

The honourable member for Deakin mentioned housing starts in the industry. Let us look at the record. In 1982-83 the previous Government had the miserable effort of 105,000 commencements. In every year since we came to office we have achieved a vast number of housing starts above that miserable figure. In 1983-84 we achieved 137,000 starts, in 1984-85 we achieved 153,000 starts and in 1985-86 we achieved 136,000 starts. Even if the figure goes down as far as 130,000 in this 1986-87 year, the Opposition would have the gall to turn around and say that that was a major slump; yet in its last year in office it achieved a miserable total of 105,000 starts.

Let us look at employment in the industry. In the middle of 1983 there were 387,000 people employed in housing and construction in this country. In August of 1986, just three years later, over 100,000 more people are employed in the housing and construction industry-a total of 491,000. That is the record that this Government has with regard to employment in the housing and construction industry and industry activity measured through the level of commencements.

Let us look at interest rates because they were mentioned and I certainly agree that they are a key issue with regard to the future level of housing activity and lending for housing. Firstly, as I made clear yesterday and again this morning in the media, we will not renege on the 13 1/2 per cent pegged rate for those people who took out their savings bank loans prior to 2 April this year. There are 800,000 to one million of these loans, which means that about two million Australians would be affected. I say to these two million Australians that the Opposition could not be trusted to hold that 13 1/2 per cent rate, but this Government can be trusted to do so. People cannot trust the coalition in government. It has no housing record in government and it has no policy. No one can find out what it would do. The Opposition is simply leaderless.

With regard to lending, it has been said that the April housing package is a failure. Let us look at the current housing lending figures. In the month of September lending was at a rate in excess of $12 billion a year. The annual rate for the savings banks was $8.5 billion, with lending of $710m during the month of September. That is a good record in anyone's language. Savings bank lending has almost doubled since March this year. Furthermore, it is underpinned by a reasonably strong situation for savings bank deposits. In the six months to September the growth in savings bank deposits was 12 1/2 per cent. I know that that cannot continue at that rate, but we are reasonably confident that savings bank deposit growth will still be able to underpin the very strong lending performance overall by the savings banks.

As it was alluded to during the contribution of the honourable member for Deakin, let us look at the position of the National Australia Bank Ltd. I have said that we will hold the 13 1/2 per cent pre-April rate. I now say that there is no need for savings banks to increase the new post-April housing loan rate of 15 1/2 per cent. The National Australia Bank has increased its rate for new loans for non-customers to 17 1/2 per cent. As I said yesterday, the bank states that more than 80 per cent of its loans, which are to its existing customers, are still at the rate of 15 1/2 per cent. That is okay; good on it. The bank did not need to lift the other rate to 17 1/2 per cent. Clearly, it just does not want to lend any money to non-customers. As I said yesterday, who would walk in off the street and take a loan at 17 1/2 per cent when one can go to the other savings banks, say, the Commonwealth Bank, or building societies in New South Wales, and get a loan at 15 1/2 per cent?

I do not say this in a vindictive way but I repeat that the workers of Australia are exercising restraint, the Government is exercising restraint in its outlays and its public sector borrowing commitments and the States are being asked to exercise restraint. Public servants are being asked to exercise restraint. Why can the banks not exercise restraint? I am sure that, apart from the National Australia Bank, most of them will. In fact, I say to people who are looking for housing loans: `Shop around; see what the market has to offer; see what the free market has to offer. You will probably find that you will be most welcome at some of the other savings banks'. I note what was said on radio last night, and quoted again in the newspapers today, by the Executive Director of the Australian Bankers Association. He was asked whether the 17 1/2 per cent hike by the National Australia Bank might lead the way to a hike in rates by the other banks. Mr Cullen was quoted as follows:
The executive director of the Australian Bankers' Association, Mr Alan Cullen, agreed that the National Australia decision did not signal rate rises across the board.

He also said on radio last night that generally the banks are in agreement-without being too bullish about it, I should say-that the general interest rates should continue to fall over the next few quarters.

Let us just see what the position is with interest rates. The honourable member for Deakin talked about the bank bill rates and seemed to get some humour out of the fact that I said that the important thing was to watch the downward trend and to disregard the minor blips along the way. That would be true if rates were surging upwards too, but they are not; they are coming down. In late August the 90-day bill rate was 17.7 per cent. Today, the rate is 16.2 per cent. The rate for commercial 180-day bills is now just under 16 per cent. If the Opposition wants to talk about interest rates, let us look at the situation in the middle of June 1982 when those rates were 18.75 per cent and 18.35 per cent respectively. So much for the previous Government's performance on interest rates.

I now turn to measures that can assist first home buyers. First of all, in a time of very stringent economic circumstances and during a very tight Budget period, we have been able to retain the first home owners scheme. That has been a very good scheme. Almost 220,000 households have already been assisted through that scheme. A billion dollars has been or will be paid out as a result of the ongoing commitment to subsidise people's interest rates through the scheme. The previous Government's home deposit assistance scheme did not do that. It simply offered people a lump sum and said: `Goodbye. We don't want to see you any more'. The first home owners scheme offers a lump sum to help bridge the deposit gap and provides an ongoing interest rate subsidy. By June next year another 41,000 people will be added to the 220,000 who have already benefited from this scheme.

Unlike the Opposition, I am not being duplicitous about the housing situation. We want to be helpful and we want to tell the story as it is. That is what I am doing. I am saying, quite freely, that the future of the housing industry is bound up with interest rates, obviously, but I am also saying that this Government has in place measures to help. We have put our housing package in place and that has underpinned strong lending growth. I have already proved that. We have the first home owners scheme in place. We have ensured that the banks are in a position to offer low start loans. Let us look at what they are doing, across the board. With an interest rate of 15 1/2 per cent on a $50,000 loan, repayments amount to $676 a month. On a low start loan with the Commonwealth Bank with a reference rate of 9 1/2 per cent, monthly repayments on a $50,000 loan amount to $522. That means a reduction of $150 a month with a low start loan from the Commonwealth Bank. Most of the other banks are doing the same thing. I will not go through all the figures, but that is a typical starting rate for a low start loan.

Let us now deal with the private rental market, which I agree is tight. I hope we can do better. We need more investment in the private rental market. The Opposition is trying to make a big run about the tightness of the private rental market but back in June 1982, getting towards the end of the present Opposition's six years in Government, what was the position? In Sydney the vacancy rate was 2 per cent. What is it today? It is 0.9 per cent. That is tight, and so is Perth. But wait a minute, look at Brisbane. In the middle of 1982 the vacancy rate was 0.5 per cent; today it is 3.9 per cent. In Adelaide it was 0.9 per cent and today it is 2.7 per cent. So without seeking to downgrade the problem, despite the tax changes, the position in the private rental market is no more serious in any capital city, with the exception of Sydney and Perth, than it was in the middle of 1982.

This dispirited, divided and dozy Opposition does not care about policy and is more inclined to go chasing after its own leader than getting on with the job of offering a housing policy to the people of Australia. It would bring back the tax rorts. Never mind the depreciation allowance we introduced for the private rental market; what about the tax rorts? Members of the Opposition want to bring back full write-offs for negative gearing and do away with the capital gains tax. What would be the cost of that? It would cost $170m. `Do in the fringe benefits tax', they say. `Let the exploiters of that sort of system get $100,000 a year and pay an average tax rate of about 20 per cent, the same as that paid by someone on about $15,000 a year. Let us bring back that', they say. We say no, because apart from questions of equity, it would cost $700m. Opposition members would do away with the Australia Card, so they would lose another billion dollars. All up, that is nearly $2 billion. Where will they make the cuts to outlays? That is what they will not say. Will they rely on huge increases in consumer taxes, in indirect taxes? Will they go for the broadly based consumption tax or not? It is about time that they told us.

I do not have time to deal with our splendid record in public housing; suffice it to say that the States through our funding policies are allowing the various public housing authorities to acquire and build rental housing for low income earners at more than double the rate that the previous Government enabled back in 1982-83. Almost $2 billion all up will be expended on public housing this year. This is not a serious matter of public importance. It fools no one. The Opposition has no policies. Its front bench is divided and its members are fighting viciously amongst themselves over the leadership. They will not and cannot address the issues. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) is now threatening to pull out of the coalition, and half of the Liberal Party is intent on viciously putting its own leader to death by the death of a thousand cuts. The people of Australia will not listen to a divided party. I will tell the House what will happen-the Government will forge ahead over the next few months and when we come back the coalition will be doing in its own Leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always enjoy listening to the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West). He reels off these statistics and one comes away with a warm feeling inside that somehow everything in the housing industry is under control. We all know that that is absolute nonsense. We do not have to listen to the statistics put forward in this House, we do not have to listen to the blandishments and insults of people like the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or the quite unremarkable rhetoric of the Minister for Housing and Construction as he closed his speech. All we have to do is go out into the real world and start talking to the people out there. All we have to do is ask the people who are affected by the housing and economic policies of this disreputable Government. I was interested to read a media release by the then Minister for Housing and Construction announcing a change to the first home owners scheme on Tuesday, 21 August 1984. Let me quote the opening statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Against a background of falling interest rates, and a level of housing construction activity which is close to resource availability, the income limits for the First Home Owners Scheme . . . have been reviewed for those who contract to buy or build a house after tonight . . .

Listen to those words: `A background of falling interest rates and a level of housing construction activity which is close to resource availability'. Let us not just consider the words of the Minister at the table but look at what is actually happening in the housing sector. The housing sector has contracted sharply during the past 12 months. The number of new housing starts has fallen in each of the past four quarters. The 12 per cent decline in the June quarter was the largest quarter decline in over a decade. This sharp contraction is expected to continue. Of concern to us is not the blandishments of the Minister at the table, but the reality of what is occurring in the real world. What are the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer saying? They say they will have an increase to 135,000 starts this year. What does the Government's chief advisory body say? No way-122,500 starts, and probably less; 20 per cent below 1984-85, and this with an expanded population. In case it has escaped the Minister, the fact is that the population of Australia is growing so we have a greater need. Therefore we cannot rely simply on the statistics of years gone by. We have to look at what the demand is at present. A falling rate in housing starts is a very serious thing indeed. My colleague the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) has pointed out clearly just how serious this decline is. The Minister has been advised by his own advisory body that the statements that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have made are simply not in accord with the advice that the Government is receiving.

So the Minister can say that the Government has done a great job, look at all these starts; the fact is that the industry is contracting. That has been going on for a year now, and a whole lot of people out there are looking for assistance in a situation which is becoming daily more desperate. Why is this so? It is so because of the absolutely stupid economic policies that this Government has put in place and insists on pursuing. The effect of the capital gains tax has been written off by the Minister as being of no consequence to the housing industry and rental housing. Again that is simply not true. I refer to the impact of the Government's negative gearing decision. The Minister writes negative gearing off as a rort. What is happening out there in the market-place? I am interested that the Minister said we need more investment in the private rental market. How true. That was about the only truthful thing the Minister really said during his contribution. We need more investment in the private rental market. Has the Minister asked himself why he does not have more investment in the private rental market? Has he asked himself why the degree of tightness in the private rental market has been reported in the Australian Financial Review and other papers? Why has that happened? Could it be that the policies that the Government has put in place are wrong, that it is a positive disincentive for investment in the private rental market?

Could it be due to the Government's decisions about the capital gains tax which, as I remind the Minister and all the members of his Party, their Prime Minister said would not occur? `There will be no capital gains tax', he said. We all remember that. We all know about the much vaunted integrity of this Prime Minister who said: `There will be no capital gains tax'. There is a capital gains tax and it is having a decided impact on investment in all sorts of areas, including housing and the rental market. What about the negative gearing decision? `It will not really matter', the Minister and the Government said. Let us look at what is taking place. People are not investing, and they are not investing for a very good reason. It is not worth their while to invest. Why is it not worth their while to invest? It is because of the policies that the Minister and his Government have put in place. He should not go around and say: `It is not our fault. It is all right out there'. It is the Government's fault, and it is not all right out there.

Let us look at some other areas. The Minister mentioned interest rates. We can all use figures, but let us get down to the reality of what interest rates mean to the person who is paying off a loan. They mean an extra $8,000 per year. That is $8,000 a year out of disposable income, and that is in a climate in which inflation is rising at a startling rate. Housewives who are battling to cope with the rising tide of prices go into the supermarkets around Australia and find the costs of goods and services going up week by week. They have to find an additional $8,000-plus a year out of their disposable incomes to pay for the increase caused by the rising interest rates. The Government can say that that is not its fault. The fact is that the economic policies pursued by this Government have brought this situation about, and it cannot escape the responsibility for those economic policies. Even the Minister, who is a not a senior Minister but who, nevertheless, is in the Cabinet, has the responsibility as part of that Cabinet for the policies that the Government has pursued.

We all know that rents have gone up very significantly-in Victoria, by something like $10 a week-because of the policies of this Government. There have been great increases in other areas. We know about increased unemployment in housing and related industries. We know that more young families are unable to afford homes. If the Minister does not believe this, he should start talking to people at private dinner parties--

TALK.START.PARA: —He goes to restaurants in Queanbeyan.

—He probably goes to restaurants in Queanbeyan. Nevertheless, he should give himself the exercise of getting out into the real world and asking people what they think of the prospects of young people renting or buying homes. Quite frankly, I hear it said in all situations: `I simply do not understand how young people today can look forward to realising that dream'. The desire to own one's home has been part of the fabric of Australian society. The Minister should put himself in the position of young people today who are faced with rising costs, rising inflation rates and rising interest rates. He should put himself in the position of those young people who have to lay out the deposit and meet the payments associated with buying their own homes or even renting places. It is becoming almost impossible for a significantly greater number of people all the time. That is the reality of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister does not believe me, he should look at what was said yesterday in the Melbourne Herald under the heading of `The balance of compassion'. It states:
. . . one of the constant problems they face is housing-particularly those on lower incomes-whether they can get it; whether they can afford it.

It talks about a deserted wife with two young kids having to spend the night in a car in Victoria because of the absence of proper housing accommodation. Public housing requirements have increased by a staggering 20 per cent in Victoria in the last year. That is the reality of the housing situation in Australia today. For people, including women and children, it is impossible to get proper housing accommodation. Young people are finding it impossible to realise their dream. More and more people throughout this community are finding it impossible to pay rent and the costs of moving into their homes. It is a disgrace, and the Government is responsible for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is just a phoney matter of public importance put forward by an Opposition which has absolutely no understanding of the needs of the hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians whom it alleges it represents. Fancy telling us that we ought to find out more about what is going on by listening to young people at dinner parties! The young people to whom we listen have their interests expressed by the Inner City Regional Council for Social Development Co-op. Ltd. I have here a document from the Housing Information and Referral Service which really understands the needs of young people. It knows that this Government is trying harder than any government in history to solve the housing needs of Australians, the people who need government help. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has already spent a deal of time talking about the first home owners scheme and the help that we are giving young people in relation to home ownership. This document from the Inner City Regional Council talks about what we have done for public housing. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a massive increase in public housing funding through the CSHA, and also an openness to experimental developments like co-operative housing and the development of community housing alternatives. Public housing construction is now at record levels, and there are early indications that at last the exponential increase in waiting lists and waiting times is beginning to be overhauled. Before long, and for the first time since the Chifley Government, we will begin to reach the point where public housing will have a genuine impact on the housing sector.

The Liberals just do not understand that that is where the real need is. In total, with State contribution, this Australian Government has put in nearly $2 billion for public housing funding for 1986-87. That is the highest ever. Opposition members ask what this has to do with the matter. We are talking about the housing needs of the thousands of ordinary Australians who are referred to in the matter of public importance. The Liberals, of course, know nothing of this.

We might look at some of the Liberals' policies for housing. They have put forward some proposals to which we will have to refer as their policy; they have nothing else. It just shows their callous disregard for the people to whom this matter of public importance refers. In public housing it shows a clear ignorance of the overall housing problems and the situation of people with housing needs in Australia today. In relation to public housing the Liberals propose the elimination of tied grants. These grants currently go to those people who are in real need. The whole reason for tied grants is to ensure that those who are most needy get priority help. Their proposal means an end to public housing programs that are funded by the grants. Never forget the 70 per cent wind-down in Federal government financial commitment during the dark years of the Fraser Government. This proposal would be worse, much worse. People without money cannot be forced into home ownership, especially not in a deregulated market. The present massive disproportion in subsidy levels for home owners, as distinct from private and public tenants, will begin to look like a paradise in comparison with what the Liberals are proposing. They propose to renegotiate the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement which, as I have just said, is receiving such support from those who are really interested in housing.

The Liberals also propose to incorporate the first home owners scheme in public housing funds to the States. That would effectively abolish the scheme and would force the States to have to decide to help either first home buyers or those who need public housing. Where would the money from the first home owners scheme go under their scheme? What would happen to that money if it were put into general State housing grants? It does not necessarily follow that the money, or even the bulk of it, would go into public housing, which is where we are putting the emphasis, especially if the overall housing sector is privatised by a hostile Liberal-National Party government. Certainly under those parties people with housing needs would have a hostile government.

They also propose to enable the sale of public housing. It just shows their ignorance. It can happen already under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, but with conditions which ensure that if a dwelling is sold it is able to be replaced with the proceeds from the sale. Otherwise, the public rental stock is reduced. Any policy that sold off public housing stock would seriously harm the chances of those in need getting help. It is easy to see how honourable members opposite thought up that one. It matches squarely with the Thatcher policy of recent years. The people who put out this publication say:
Have a yarn some time with English housing workers and activists about what that's meant for low income families in grotty, run-down bed and breakfasts in London.

That is what the Liberals propose. It is also at peace with the long term practices of Liberal governments in this country-the major reason for the massive housing crisis for low income people being faced by the current Federal and State governments. Honourable members opposite have given us this problem. Putting all one's eggs in the home ownership basket might be all right for middle income earners, but it can be poison for low income earners. It is really just another way of shifting resources from the poor to the not so poor.

There are no indications of funding in any of the Opposition's proposals or in anything honourable members on the other side have said. Based on the Liberals' record we can guess what they would do. Their record is appalling in public housing funding. For instance, by 1980-81 the Liberals had cut public housing funding to $264m-only 40 per cent of the level in the last year of the Whitlam Government. In the first year of the Hawke Government we had increased it by 40 per cent and there have been very significant increases since. In 1986-87 the total funding for public housing, as I said previously, combining the Commonwealth and the State contributions, will be nearly $2 billion-the highest ever in real terms. Australians should be in no doubt that if the Liberals' policy is ever implemented there will be an appalling impact on housing and, of course, public housing in particular.

Another of the Opposition's proposals is the creation of a new department of housing and community services. Honourable members can imagine what the Minister for that particular department would have to do. There would be no public housing and no government involvement left for him to administer. The idea, equally obviously, links public housing firmly with welfare-for which, with the Liberals, one can read `charity'. That is the housing model which has consistently been espoused by the conservatives. Given the low priority conservatives traditionally assign governments in welfare activities, it does not take a crystal ball to guess how well that would be resourced.

So what does the Opposition propose? I will tell honourable members what the Opposition proposes. The Opposition proposes the continuing of the rorts, such as negative gearing-and it is a rort. This Government gives a high priority to overall tax reform, including the treatment of capital gains and negative gearing. As a broad principle, if these tax reforms are seen to generate problems in some areas, surely the appropriate course would be to examine ways to overcome those problems, rather than to abandon the reforms and continue the rorts. The Government's social objectives cannot and should not be sustained by an inequitable taxation system. Where concessions exist they must relate to social priorities. It is not acceptable that tax avoidance measures are necessary to stimulate legitimate investment.

Negative gearing on rental properties by high income earners has cost the taxpayers of Australia approximately $175m a year. The draft White Paper on the reform of the Australian tax system identified negative gearing of rental property investments as one of the better known tax shelters. This Government believes that it is not economically or socially justified to continue such blatant tax shelters. Rather, we will eradicate the shelters and examine legitimate means of stimulating investment. One of these, of course, is our 4 per cent depreciation allowance.

If one cannot look to the Liberals and the Opposition for help for housing, can one perhaps look to the banks? What are the banks doing to help the housing needs of the people referred to in the matter of public importance? We have heard what the National Australia Bank is doing today. Banks generally move in concert, and the National Bank was the first this time. It is part of the systematic change in strategy of the private banking sector. What it wants to do is to get out of housing. Like the Liberals opposite, the banks want to get out of housing. They want to get into loans to the business sector and those loans are tax deductible. This trend, the recent explosion in the debt financing of the business sector, is placing enormous pressure on the public purse.

The Liberals want more and more deregulation, They are not offering any solution except trusting the free market. The only responses then are more and more drains on government revenue, more and more tax concessions to the private rental market, more and more tax concessions to those who want to make a profit out of the housing market. Why do honourable members think that the banks want to take over the building societies? If lending for housing is such bad business, why are they clamouring to get on to the building societies? It is to gain access to the building societies' low cost deposits-and it is not to put money into housing. As I have said before in this House, it is these low cost deposits that have traditionally been channelled into providing housing.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW WHARF AND SEAMANSHIP SCHOOL AT HMAS CERBERUS, CRIB POINT, VICTORIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keogh Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the eleventh report for 1986 of the Committee, relating to the construction of a new wharf and seamanship school at HMAS Cerberus, Crib Point, Victoria, and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —HMAS Cerberus is the Royal Australian Navy's largest training establishment. It occupies a site of some 1,500 hectares at Crib Point, near Westernport Bay in Victoria. The base has been developed over many years and contains instructional facilities for a number of schools, including the seamanship school. The major components of the proposal which the Committee examined included the construction of a new building to house the seamanship school and wharf, including a marina. The Committee found that existing facilities and arrangements for training sailors in seamanship, survival at sea and ship husbandry are substantially under standard and antiquated. The Committee concluded that the proposed new seamanship school building will meet the Navy's functional requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: The report draws attention to two matters which should be further examined by the Department of Defence and the Department of Housing and Construction. The first is the provision of storage space for paints and other flammable products in the ship husbandry section of the building. The Committee believes the location of this storage space should be reviewed and, if necessary, an alternative location found. The second is the amount of space available for instructors-65 square metres for 10 instructors. The Committee believes the space allocation provided should be reviewed.

Another component of the proposed work is the construction of a wharf for assigned and visiting craft, such as patrol boats, and seamanship training, and a floating marina for training and support craft. The need for these facilities was clearly demonstrated and the extent and the design of the proposed facilities will enable practical seamanship training to be carried out and operational training and support vessels to be adequately moored and maintained. Dredging of the turning basin adjacent to the wharf and of the channel into Hanns Inlet is also proposed. The Committee is conscious of the need to ensure that the effects of the dredging on the environment are minimised. On the basis of assurances given by departmental officials, the Committee is satisfied that every precaution will be taken to minimise the effects of the dredging.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF HMAS ALBATROSS, NOWRA, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keogh Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works--
—A busy Committee.

—It is a very busy Committee on which my colleague the honourable member for Throsby works extremely hard-I present the twelfth report for 1986 of the Committee, relating to the development of HMAS Albatross, Nowra, New South Wales (Stage 1), and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —HMAS Albatross is located approximately eight kilometres south-west of Nowra, New South Wales. The base provides operational maintenance, logistic and administrative support for the aircraft. That area, until the last redistribution, was very effectively and capably represented by my colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), who is present in the chamber at this stage. The equipment and personnel of resident squadrons and the Royal Australian Navy ships' helicopter flights, when disembarked, are also located there. In addition the base provides a port for the Royal Australian Air Force, the Army and civilian aircraft operating in the area in support of the fleet or on other tasks. A squadron of Sea Hawk helicopters is to be deployed at the base, the first Sea Hawks being delivered in March 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal is for the provision of facilities to service and maintain the Sea Hawk helicopters, the development of new facilities and the upgrading of existing facilities for the efficient and effective operation of the base. The Committee concludes that the works proposed will be adequate to support the development of the Sea Hawks and will also improve the overall efficiency of the base. Attention has been drawn in the report to possible future urban development and whether this may hinder the operations of the base. The Committee concludes that continuing discussions should take place between the Department of Defence and the Shoalhaven City Council to ensure that this will not occur. Attention is also drawn to the possibility of a future cycleway from Nowra to the base. The Committee believes that there is merit in the Department of Defence having discussions with the Shoalhaven City Council and the various community groups that are concerned about that. Finally, the Committee has recommended that consultations should take place with relevant State and local government bodies prior to its consideration of a proposal. The Committee recommends construction of the work in this reference.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the Committee's report on proposals for variations of the plan of layout of the City of Canberra and its environs, the eighty-eighth series, together with copies of minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report that I have just tabled deals with the 14 items of the eighty-eighth series of variations to the plan of layout of the city of Canberra. The Committee recommends approval of all but one of these variations. In its consideration of items in this series, the Committee took evidence from 10 witnesses appearing as individuals and representing various organisations. The cost involved in the proposals in this report total approximately $7.5m, with another $45m estimated for completion of all stages of the eastern parkway. I wish to comment on only two of these variations.

SPEECH.PARA: Joint Committee on the ACT

Variation 4 provides for the deletion of part of the road reservation in Kaye Place, Yarralumla, to allow the area to be included in the lease for the Hotel Canberra and the construction of a rear entrance for that hotel. This forms part of the construction program for the hotel which should be completed by 1987. An objection to the variation was received from the proprietor of the nearby service station. Various representations have been made by that man over the years, including approaches to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who is sitting at the table today. The man claimed that the increased traffic generated by the hotel entrance would jeopardise his business and make access to his service station difficult. At the public hearing, when questioned about his intentions regarding the continued operation of the service station, the proprietor assured the Committee that he would like to carry on as a service station operator. In response to a question regarding the state of negotiations and the potential purchase of the service station site by the Hyatt Hotel group, the Committee was told that although some discussions had taken place, no conclusion had been reached and all negotiations had ceased. Eleven days after the public hearing the Committee was informed that the service station site had in fact been sold to the hotel group, and the Committee is not satisified that it was made fully aware of the circumstances surrounding the sale. However, as the objection to the variation was withdrawn, the Committee does not see any reason not to approve the variation.

The one item not agreed to by the Committee relates to the construction of the preliminary stages of the eastern parkway, which will provide a parkway access system to Tuggeranong comparable to that existing for the rest of Canberra. The parkway will also have benefits for traffic between Queanbeyan and Canberra and for regional traffic travelling between the Monaro Highway and locations to the north. The estimated cost of the construction is $50m at present prices with that work being carried out in stages over a number of years. Whilst the Committee was provided with some details of the shape and the construction of the road system, it is not satisfied that it was briefed adequately on the costing components or estimates of traffic flows in particular sections of the road. The Committee has further doubts about the extent to which this road is a priority in the present economic climate and therefore it recommends that this item be deferred pending a full briefing and overview of the proposal at a later date by the National Capital Development Commission.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Mr Hurford:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which is before the House this afternoon, is in fact a significant piece of legislation because it demonstrates yet again how this Government prefers to make amendments to legislation rather than try to make that which is already on the statute books work effectively. The problem we are facing was identified by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in a statement he tabled in the Senate on 17 April 1986 when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may be aware that last year I established a working party to report to me on the causes and incidence of invalidity retirement from Commonwealth employment.
He went on to say:
I am concerned that the rate of invalidity retirement, which has been relatively stable for a few years following a dramatic upsurge in the late 1970s, shows signs of increasing again.

Having read that profound statement to the House, I think two points are worth making. First, no evidence has been put forward by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who is at the table, or by the Government as to the outcome of this working party. Having therefore introduced legislation in what could best be described as an administrative vacuum, the Government now expects us to debate the issue without telling us why the existing legislation is unsatisfactory. Because of that I will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government has failed to adequately apply the provisions of the Superannuation Act relating to the payment of invalidity pensions thus causing a significant loss of revenue to the Commonwealth'.

I am indebted to the work of my colleague in the other place, Senator Michael Baume, who, through the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee, has done some excellent work in identifying the implications of this problem. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table from the Department of Social Security which outlines the impact of medical examinations-or lack of them-over the period from 1982-83 to 1985-86.
Leave granted.
