TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier, the problem we are facing is that we are, in a sense, debating this Bill in an administrative vacuum. The only evidence we have is that contained in the report of the Commissioner for Superannuation in these matters and the information that was tabled in the Senate Estimates Committee. The table which I have just incorporated shows two things: First, that the number of medical examinations during the period of the previous Government was 936-those were examinations required under the previous legislation for people who claimed that they wished to retire from the Public Service due to invalidity. The significant point is that since 1982-83 the number of medical examinations has steadily declined and in the latest year was down to 356. That is about one-third of the total number under the previous Government. Equally, the number of people found fit for re-employment has declined. It is a provision of the legislation that people judged to be unfit are able to go out on a pension and can be later reabsorbed into the Public Service. This number has declined from 126 in the last year of the previous Government, 1982-83, to only 27 last year, a substantial reduction. The number re-employed by the Commonwealth Public Service or an approved authority has also gone down-from 29 to 15-and the number of pensions cancelled has declined from 35 to 17.

SPEECH.PARA: Those figures bear out without any shadow of doubt the fact that the regulations under the earlier Act are clearly not being applied. The Opposition has a right to ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Industrial Matters (Mr Willis) or the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, who is at the table, to explain to the House why this Government has to change the regulations and make significant amendments to a Bill without being able to demonstrate conclusively why there is a need for those changes.

Many honourable members would have received correspondence from individuals who have retired from the Public Service on invalidity grounds. Some of those people are ex-servicemen and some of them may be totally and permanently incapacitated ex-servicemen. They are genuinely concerned that under these provisions they may find themselves financially disadvantaged. We have made inquiries of the Minister for Finance about this matter and I am pleased to be able to place on the record that it is our understanding that the provisions in these amendments relate only to the supplementary income which pensioners may gain by self-exertion. In other words, it is not based on capital invested previously, on the one hand, or access to TPI, invalidity or war-type pensions on the other. I hope that the Minister, when he has the opportunity to explain this legislation, will spell that out quite clearly, because people are concerned. They are writing letters to their members of parliament. Clearly this Government has failed utterly to explain the purposes and the thrust of its legislation in that particular field.

Another important point which I think is worth looking at is that the incidence of cases of invalidity retirement varies from department to department. This matter was covered most adequately by my colleague Senator Michael Baume in relation to work he has previously done on the Waste Watch Committee. That Committee showed that last financial year the number of people who retired on the grounds of invalidity was greater than the number of people who retired from the Public Service by reaching retirement age. That in itself is an extraordinary situation. If one relates that again to this consistent reduction in standards over the years 1982 to the present, one can conclude only one of two things: Either those in the Public Service are getting sicker--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the doctors are rough.

—Or, as has been suggested by the honourable member, the doctors are rough. I do not know quite what he means by `rough'. Perhaps he will explain it to us later. I would go a step further. I would suggest that departments are not applying the regulations as they stand and are expecting the Commonwealth Medical Officers to equally apply those standards because, if that were not so, one would have to ask: Why is there such a variation from department to department? Why is it that in some cases two-thirds or more of people retiring are retiring on invalidity grounds whereas this is not the case elsewhere? Why is it that two-thirds more public servants are retiring on invalidity grounds than in the private sector? These are the issues which the Opposition is putting to the Government. These are the questions which the Australian people deserve to have answered.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation clearly has not worked. Is it because of a fundamental weakness in the legislation or is it because the regulations have not been applied? Until I hear something to the contrary from members of the Government I am prepared to accept that it is the latter and not the former. It is precisely for that reason that we are sceptical of the need to make these changes at this stage when there is no evidence that the current legislation is necessarily being applied adequately. The evidence which bears this out is the tremendous variation between the number of people applying for and gaining access to early retirement on invalidity grounds under the Fraser Government and the figures we have seen in the last four years of the Hawke Government.

As I said earlier, the Minister has also appointed a working party and, because of the outstanding work of the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee, he made that statement in the House. However, we wait to see the outcome of its efforts. If we are to be told that the outcome of its efforts is these amendments, so be it. But what we have not received and what does not appear in the Minister's second reading speech is any really adequate explanation as to why that should be so. One thing that is clear-this again the Government has not really grasped, in my opinion-is that there is substantial financial advantage in public servants going out on the grounds of invalidity when they get 50 per cent of pension compared with about 35 per cent of pension received by those who retire through normal age processes. In addition, of course, they get a lump sum payment. That, of course, is an incentive for anyone.

The Government's response to that is quite straightforward. It says: `Fine, we will introduce an indexed arrangement by which people who gain above a certain level of wage through personal exertion in addition to their pension will be expected to pay back on a dollar for dollar basis'. The Opposition does not object to that proposal and we are, therefore, supporting the general thrust of this legislation. But one has to be very careful in introducing changes of this nature that one is not creating additional administrative criteria which cannot necessarily of themselves have any real impact on the size or scope of the problem in hand. That is why I and the Opposition are sceptical of the way in which the Government has handled the situation to date and why we believe it leaves much to be desired.

The issue is a complex one. There are many people outside in the electorate at large who rightly say: `Why should we have to pay people to retire on higher pensions just because they are public servants when they claim that they are going out on invalidity grounds and we see them mowing the lawn next week, or we see them working elsewhere and in some cases they have even been known to be earning higher salaries, including their pensions, than they were gaining before?'. Clearly that cannot be accepted, and the Opposition, as I said earlier, is supporting these proposals, but what we are concerned about is the manner in which this situation over the last four years was allowed to deteriorate so far. No evidence has been brought forward to this Parliament in this debate or in another place by Senator Walsh in his statement, which tells us no more than that he is concerned about the issue and proposes to solve it not at the source-that is the important thing-which is departmental level, but by simply saying: `Okay, you can still get your pensions but we are going to have our watchdogs out watching to see how much additional salary you earn and, if you do earn additional salary, you have to be prepared to pay it back'.

TALK.START.PARA: —More public servants.
—In other words, more public servants, more administration, more bureaucracy and more efforts being made to make sure that everybody does the right thing.
—Why do you hate public servants?

—The Minister knows full well that what he is facing is the fact that the Australian taxpayer wants to get value for his dollar. He is fed up with a government which in the last four years has done everything it possibly can to solve the problems by creating larger bureaucracies and which has created over 60 new statutory authorities. I look at the Minister opposite, and he of course is a standing example of a lover of bureaucracies and bureaucrats.
—An outstanding example.

—A sterling example. The fact of the matter is that it is the people out there paying the bills who know that a minimum of one in four people in the work force is being supported by their incomes, and they do not necessarily see any real benefit from it. The people are rightly saying to us: `How can you be sure that the administration of these programs and policies by this Labor Government is cost effective?'. It is clear from the evidence I have put forward and the evidence put forward in the Senate by my colleague Senator Michael Baume that the position is far from satisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go through a few more facts on this matter. Under this legislation the Commissioner for Superannuation will be empowered by section 74 of the Superannuation Act to require invalid pensioners who have not attained the age of 65 to provide information about employment and to undergo medical examinations. If the Commissioner concludes that an invalid pensioner is sufficiently restored to health to resume duty, he is supposed to notify the relevant employing authority and any subsequent re-employment action becomes the responsibility of that department or instrumentality. If re-employment takes place in circumstances in which the pensioner becomes an eligible employee for the purposes of the Superannuation Act, again the employer is to be informed and the pension cancelled. The pension is cancelled also if a pensioner unreasonably refuses to accept an offer of re-employment. All those requirements were in the Act, yet there is abundant evidence from the figures I have quoted to show that the Act has not been policed.

The proposals in these amendments do not demonstrate any suggestion that those difficulties will be faced at the source. We are simply told that people who are double dipping, for all intents and purposes, will be told that they will have to pay back the money. That is fine, we are not disputing that, but I want to hear Ministers and honourable members opposite explain to the House and the Australian people why the regulations were not properly applied in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were in government.

—The honourable member says that we were in government. The simple facts are there. The statistics are clear; I have tabled them in the House. I quote the figures again, for the benefit of the honourable member, who has some difficulty with his hearing these days. In 1982-83, 936 people had medical examinations. Of those people, 126 were found fit for re-employment, 29 were re-employed by the Public Service or an approved authority, and 35 pensions were cancelled. It is extraordinary that those are the highest figures in all of the years since the Hawke Government has been elected. The year 1982-83 was the last year of the Fraser Government. In 1985-86 the number of medical examinations has fallen from 936 to 356; the number of people found fit for re-employment has fallen from 126 to 27; the number of people re-employed has fallen from 29 to 15; and the number of pensions cancelled has fallen from 35 to 17. Surely the Opposition can rest its case on that. The evidence is abundantly clear that the regulations have not been applied. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, on so many other aspects of social security relevant to him, is an acknowledged expert.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) has pointed out, in so many areas of social security and social welfare, fraud in this nation has become an art form. We have a government which says to the people: `We will give you more information about how to get access to your benefits'. Having made access available, the Government says: `We will not apply any test.' One has only to look in the area of unemployment benefits, where the work test is not being applied, and at the fact that public servants are effectively encouraged to take early retirement because public servants were not able to be removed by any reasonable system until this morning when legislation finally-four years after this Government came to power-was introduced to make it possible now to make officers redundant and to remove them on the ground of inefficiency. I find it extraordinary that this Government has been so lax for so long. It has had so many opportunities and it has let them pass it by, over the shoulder, because it believed incorrectly that the Australian people indefinitely, in their supreme and ultimate patience, were prepared to pay the bill. Well, they are not and the day has quite clearly come when the average Australian family is saying: `Enough is enough'.

The Government has talked about reducing taxation. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the dispatch box in Question Time today told us how the maximum marginal rate of tax will be reduced to 49c in the dollar. It sounds marvellous in theory, but if one looks at the consequences, the fact is that the level of tax under this Government over the past four years has been higher than it was under the previous administration of the Fraser Government. That is how the facts stand, yet this Government consistently tries to imagine that it is an efficient and effective public administrator. It could not administrate a paper bag, whether or not it was in the hands of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) with his lunch in it.

I turn to some other points made by the Waste Watch Committee. As I have said, there has clearly been inadequate supervision and in some cases collusion between senior management and public servants. The collusion was caused by weaknesses in the legislation which made it easier for management to say to an employee: `Look, fellow, we will look the other way'-nod nod, wink wink-`take early retirement, go out on invalidity grounds or get a better pension, but we do not want you around here any more'. What an admission of administrative chaos that this Government has allowed this to be in place for so long. The cost of invalid pensions rose by some $350m of taxpayers' money over that period.

A leaked internal discussion paper produced recently by the Department of Finance and the Public Service Board has confirmed the Waste Watch Committee allegations about compensation rip-offs by calling for a complete overhaul of the `bottomless pit' of compensation claims. Many invalid pensions appear to have been granted, particularly in Victoria, through collusive practices between managers who are keen to get rid of unproductive workers, especially long-serving ones, and the workers themselves were happy to be classified as invalids so that they were able to retire on a pension of 50 per cent compared with a maximum of 36 per cent. This rip-off of the Australian taxpayers-that is what it is-has been concentrated in the areas of alleged invalidity which have been difficult to diagnose and measure. Of the total invalid retirements last year of 3001, almost 40 per cent were made up of a combination of 792 mental disorders and 395 back problems. The most extraordinary thing is that Victoria seems to have more people with mental disorders and back problems than any other place in Australia.

As the Waste Watch Committee reported last April, the rip-off was heaviest in Victoria, where twice as many Commonwealth public servants were invalided out as in New South Wales, although the latter State employs some 10,000 more public servants than Victoria. In addition, about twice as many Commonwealth public servants in New South Wales retired as were invalided out-that is, 975 retired and 530 were invalided out-yet in Victoria twice as many were invalided out as retired; 1,051 were invalided out and 516 retired. Surely that indicates that an unjustifiable discrepancy has been revealed by the latest report of the Commissioner for Superannuation. The figures are from a statutory authority; they are not just a figment of my imagination or the imagination of the Opposition. The figures are the reported figures tabled in this Parliament by a statutory officer.

The Commissioner states also that almost 60 per cent of invalidity retirements take place at age 55 or over, which indicates a clear need for tighter procedures, especially in view of the fact that this Government has introduced a provision for voluntary early retirement. We do not object to that-it has merit and sense-but it seems rather odd to be able to combine voluntary early retirement with access to a supplementary pension by virtue of a person's ability, apparently ad nauseam, without any real control up to now, to approach the whole issue of retirement on the basis of invalidity. One way to fix up this rip-off is to improve the capacity of the Government to dismiss surplus or unproductive employees, which will be achieved on the basis of the legislation which passed through the Parliament this morning. Surely there is a need to control the administration of both the existing Act and the amendment provisions which we are now passing this afternoon.

Unfortunately this rip-off has existed for many years. I am not prepared to say that it just happened for the first time under the Hawke Government, but what I am saying is that whatever the trends may have been in the early 1970s-Senator Walsh made this point in his statement to the Senate-the undeniable fact is that over the last four years of the Hawke Labor Government the situation has gone from bad to worse. The result is that the Australian taxpayers have had to pay at least a further $350m per annum which may well have been saved for more worthwhile and useful purposes. We want a Public Service in which its members are able to feel that they get a worthwhile return in terms of personal satisfaction from the work that they do. The very fact that so many career officers, who have been there for most of their adult lives, believe that they want to get out and they have the opportunity to cheat because there is no future for them in the Public Service, I believe, is a very serious indictment on the manner in which the Government has run the public administration of the Commonwealth of Australia.

The Government's job is to make people do worthwhile work. Its job is not to create more public servants and thus result in higher costs and lower productivity. It is lower productivity, it is a sense of lack of achievement that one has nothing worth while to give as an individual which so often causes these people to try to get out earlier. When they are offered a wide open door and a difference between a 36 per cent pension against a 50 per cent pension, of course they will take it. Collusion from senior management is often built in and the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) made the point about alleged shonky doctors. That may be the position; I do not know. I have never been in the situation of having to be invalided out of the Public Service and presumably neither has he. I have raised these issues here this afternoon because the Government of the day is responsible for defending in this Parliament why its stewardship of legislation such as this has been so loose that its own Commissioner for Superannuation has had to admit that it has lost a minimum of $350m per annum for the Australian taxpayer in the time that it has been in power.

I merely reiterate my earlier comment. The Government has much to answer for. We are supporting these amendments in the hope that we will see an end to what has become an obvious public scandal and rip-off. But the responsibility to defend the administration of the existing Act and a need for these changes to demonstrate that it will improve upon its system of administration rest squarely with the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes, I second the amendment and I reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). He is a great thespian. We, on this side of the House, take great delight at his performance. I do not know what school of acting he went to, but he spent 20 minutes talking about nothing and looked very good in doing it. When we analyse exactly what the honourable gentleman said, he did not say anything. He made lots of allegations, but the interesting thing is that when we examine exactly what he said it is all false.

SPEECH.PARA: He made the claim that under the Hawke Government we have had a massive increase in the number of retirements due to illness of public servants. The record shows that that is clearly not true. Let us take the Fraser years and have a look at the incidence of retirement due to mental illness. It is a fascinating statistic. In 1977-78, 1,332 public servants were retired for causes put down to mental ill health; in 1978-79 there were 1,113; in 1979-80 there were 1,143; in 1983-84 it is down to 684; and in 1984-85 it is 792. We must draw the conclusion that under the Fraser Government many public servants could not stand the mental strain.

Let us look at other problems such as digestion. We know digestion problems are often related to mental strain and stress and problems caused from working. We find that under the Fraser Government in 1977-78 there were 133 cases and in 1979-80 there were 105. When the Hawke Government came to office in 1983-84 there were only 73 cases and in 1984-85 there were 83 cases. So the figures clearly demonstrate that under the Fraser Administration our public servants had a great deal more mental stress and certainly their stomachs were not working as well as they were under the Hawke Government. Like many other people, they could not stomach the Fraser Government.

The honourable gentleman did not really tackle any solid criticism of the Superannuation Legislation (Amendment) Bill (No. 2). What the Government is doing by this Bill, among many other changes to superannuation legislation, is removing the very problem he spent 20 minutes complaining about. It is a remarkable performance. Let us look at some of the other things he said. The honourable gentleman said: `Fraud under this Government has become an art form'. Is that not a remarkable statement from any member of the Opposition?

TALK.START.PARA: —They should talk! How about their bottom of the harbour scheme?

—Yes, we could talk about bottom of the harbour schemes. But let us have a look at the context of what he said. He said: `Fraud has become an art form'. This is the first Government to tackle seriously any sort of fraud with the taxation system and the social security system. Our tax package, together with the Australia Card, will tackle that problem. Yet the honourable gentleman says that we are not concerned with fraud. This Bill is concerned with potential fraud. That is why the Government is bringing it forward today.

SPEECH.PARA: Then he says there is collusion between senior public servants and there is weakness in the legislation. Whose legislation are we looking at? It was legislation brought down by a Liberal Government. If there are weaknesses in the current legislation and if there is a need to reform the current legislation, it is because the former Liberal and conservative governments made a mess of it. He sits back and says it has taken us 3 1/2 years to change it. Good heavens! Those opposite have been in government for over 30 years in post-war years. What changes have they brought to the system? Nothing they can be proud of. They were just a government concerned with tax fraud cheats and they did nothing to stop it.

I will not attack public servants who, for a variety of reasons, are forced to retire through ill health. That is not my role or the Government's role. It is clear that in recent years there has been an increase in the number of public servants who, for a variety of reasons, have found themselves unfit for service with the Commonwealth. On that basis they receive a beneficial payment from the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund upon their retirement. It is most probable that on many occasions after the pressure of working for the Commonwealth has ceased and they have had a bit of time to devote to their garden and other activities their health improves somewhat. Suffering from boredom it is quite reasonable and proper that they go out and try to find some other activity to occupy their time rather than lazing around the house doing nothing. I do not find that critical and I do not criticise them for doing that, rather I commend them for becoming more active again after the cause for their first retirement has been repaired and remedied. It is not right and proper that someone who finds himself fit and able to work again after a recuperative period should then get the benefit of a Commonwealth pension at an attractive rate and still be able to work and, in fact, double dip. It is not proper that that should occur and so it is reasonable for the Government to amend the legislation to ensure that it does not happen and to ensure that those people who are disadvantaged by illness and who are forced to retire from the Public Service do so properly and are adequately covered.

The honourable member for Bradfield, in his attack, said the Opposition was not going to oppose the Bill; it supports the Bill. If it is going to support the Bill, why then would it move an amendment in relation to it? What would be the purpose? The only solid reason why it would move an amendment would be that it does not like it. That follows, does it not? If it supports the Bill in the first place why did it spend 20 minutes, as an Opposition, talking about nothing, because nothing is what we heard? If the Opposition is going to support the Bill, why would it move an amendment? If it is going to support the Bill, why would it have a list of four or five speakers who, no doubt, will all oppose the Government in this action?

Honourable members opposite should not come into this House and stand up and try to justify their inadequacies as an Opposition, their inadequacies as a former Government and their total lack of principle and policy, because they will not fool the Australian people. They can stand up and say to me that the Australian people will not be fooled by us but I can tell them that, at the next election, the Australian people will not be fooled by them. There is no doubt that the Hawke Government will be returned with an increased majority when it goes to the next election because we have heard nothing but opportunism and nothing but sham from this policy-lacking Opposition which is spending all its time in-fighting, counting numbers and trying to find some reasons why it should put up one leader or another. It is not concerned with the nuts and bolts issues of Australian politics, it is not concerned with the representation of the Australian family and it is not concerned with the ordinary work force in this country.

When we look at superannuation, which is what we are talking about, we see that this Government has recognised the fact that only 40 per cent of Australians have superannuation benefits available to them, despite the fact that the taxation system makes superannuation benefits and investment exceedingly attractive and does so quite deliberately. In fact, the fringe benefits tax and the tax changes by this Government have made it even more attractive as all insurance consultants, taxation advisers and the insurance industry well know. This Government is introducing industrial superannuation to ensure that every Australian-it is families we are talking about; honourable members opposite can well talk about families so I will talk about them-will in the future be covered by portable and proper superannuation.

The Opposition should be ashamed of its stewardship over the last 30-odd years because, in government, it never once established a sinking fund, never once provided an investment yield portfolio that would provide for the future retired of this country, and never once considered what would happen when the demographically aging society we now have reached that retiring age and there was not enough money in the bickie tin to pay for the pensions. The Opposition, when in government, did not plan and it did not think and it left this country darned near bankrupt in terms of providing for pensions in the future and it knows it. The Hawke Government has taken the bit between its teeth. The Hawke Government is concerned about families. The Hawke Government has made a real strong move towards ensuring that Australian families in the future will be protected and covered by superannuation.

I do not know of one Opposition speaker today-I forecast now that not one will stand up-who will support industrial superannuation. Not one of the speakers on the other side will stand up and support the proposal to provide the family with a proper retirement income in future years. Not one of the speakers on the other side will support any of those programs. Instead, they will talk, mealy-mouthed, about what is wrong with this Bill. If they are fair dinkum and if they are an honest and serious Opposition they should not oppose it. They should not even suggest that they are going to oppose it. They should just forget about speaking on the Bill and let the Government carry it and get it over and done with. They should not waste the time of the House and the time of all of us. They should support the Bill. They cannot have their options.

I support the Bill, which is not just about one aspect of superannuation or the invalid pensioner. It is a wide-ranging Bill which I guess could properly be described as an omnibus Bill, in that it changes many aspects of the current superannuation law of Australia, a law which was put up by the previous Government, which was found to be defective and which the Government is now repairing. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) who has just spoken--
—A good member.

—Yes, a good member, but a very bad speech. The honourable member is a very good member but, on this occasion, he made a very disappointing speech because he had the opportunity to spell out in simple language, as I will now spell out to this House, why this Government has, by a deliberate policy decision, made it less attractive for Australians to plan for their retirement and, in particular, to plan in the area of superannuation. The honourable member for McEwen was quite correct. It is a very extensive piece of legislation and it is far broader in its impact than one would possibly have guessed from the speech of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) who represents the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in this House. He made a short 2 1/2 page speech, supposedly covering the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which has no less than 91 clauses. The honourable member for McEwen was quite correct when he said that the Bill does not just deal with the question of invalidity pensions: It is far broader than that.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address some remarks to the position of superannuation generally and then turn specifically to the legislation and, in particular, to the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) on behalf of the Opposition. I think it has to be said that the question of superannuation has been a subject of keen debate in national politics since before I was born. Indeed, it is credited with having been one of the reasons for the fall from grace of Mr R. G. Menzies and his demise as Leader of the then United Australia Party, contemporaneous with the death of Prime Minister Joseph Aloysius Lyons. Honourable members can go back to the old Hansards-indeed I have-and read with interest discussions about a national superannuation scheme. As I have said, that was being discussed nearly 50 years ago and it has still not come to fruition today. As the honourable member for McEwen, who spoke a moment ago, has just said, currently only 40 per cent of Australians are covered by superannuation. Forty per cent of Australians are part of a superannuation scheme which will provide for their retirement and, at the same time, relieve both the Commonwealth and the taxpayers of the Commonwealth of the obligation for caring, in a financial sense, for their last years.

This Government has now made superannuation positively unattractive to many millions of Australians because it determined to substantially increase the lump sum superannuation tax. Worse still, this Government got into bed with the life offices because it was in the interests of the life offices that more people took annuities rather than the lump sum payment. Honourable members opposite, members of the Hawke socialist Government, cannot get away from the fact that this massive increase in lump sum superannuation to the outrageous 30 per cent, almost Moscow-like in its monumentality, has had the effect of making the provision for one's own retirement less and less attractive. Well may the honourable member for McEwen flee the chamber. It is a very wrong decision that the Government made and it is a decision which this Opposition will repeal upon election to government at the next Federal election. The plain fact is that we recognise that such excessive, draconian taxation is counter to the interests of Australia because people will not take out superannuation if they are effectively deprived of the option of the lump sum payment.

The plain fact is that this Government wants people who have superannuation to be forced, through fiscal pressure, into taking annuities. I am sad to say that it found the life insurance offices only too willing to go along with that proposal. Is it not better to encourage Australians to plan for their retirement, to put money aside so that they will be independent, both financially and personally, when they come to the end of their working career? The motto today is: `Don't plan for your retirement. The Hawke socialist Government exhorts the people of Australia to spend up, dissipate their assets and we will look after you'.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the employer will have to look after you.

—I am coming to that in a moment. The Government tells people to dissipate their assets and the state will pick up the tab. In a country which has an increasingly aging population and which by the year 2005 will have as many persons on benefits as income earners, in a country where self-esteem and private incentive should be encouraged and exhorted, we have a socialist Government, through deliberate taxation measures, applying to the community a strict and firm dictum: `Don't you prepare for your retirement. We will look after you'.

SPEECH.PARA: Conversely-this comes to the point of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield-the Government, in its superannuation scheme, has been quite prepared to see a flood of waste of revenue to an extent that almost defies description.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three hundred and fifty million dollars a year.

—The honourable member for Bradfield says $350m a year. I was going to say almost $1m a day. Inadequate supervision-and in some cases collusion between senior management and public servants-has resulted in a retirement rip-off that has boosted the cost of Commonwealth employees' invalidity pensions to $350m a year. That did not rate a mention in the Minister's second reading speech. Not one word did he say about $350m being ripped off. He spoke blandly about proposed new section 73a of the Superannuation Act 1976 which, as I think honourable members have already mentioned, provides that invalidity pensions payable under that Act and the Superannuation Act 1922 would be reduced on a dollar for dollar basis where the aggregate amount of pension and income from personal exertion of the person concerned exceeded a limit to be prescribed in regulations under the Superannuation Act 1976. The Minister went on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: In setting that limit the Government will have regard to the position of persons in receipt of low pensions.

He went on to say-effectively, this was the substance of his speech-that, instead of doing this by prescription in the regulations, it would be put in the Act. That was the extent of the second reading speech on a Bill containing 91 clauses and which runs into 52 pages of technical, legal jargon. Not one word did he say about the $350m. The honourable member for McEwen, the last speaker for the Government, had the hide to chide the Opposition and the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bradfield, for daring to bring up the subject. Honourable members should look at the words of the honourable member for Bradfield's amendment:

whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government has failed to adequately apply the provisions of the Superannuation Act relating to the payment of invalidity pensions thus causing a significant loss of revenue to the Commonwealth.

That is short, to the point and fundamentally correct. There are 350 million reasons why that amendment is a proper amendment. There are 350 million reasons why the taxpayers of Australia would want Her Majesty's loyal Opposition to raise this matter in the Parliament in this second reading debate. There are 350 million reasons why it was correct, prudent and wise for the Opposition to put on record its view at this time. It seems that the previous speaker is unaware of the fact that, whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Opposition has every right to invite the House to accept additional words which place on record a grievance-in this case, a $350m grievance.

In accordance with the arrangements, regrettably, my time has nearly concluded. In conclusion, I want to say that, if ever there is a government which has declared war on the grandparents of Australia, it is this wretched Hawke socialist Government. Almost every legislative provision that one brings to mind has taken it out on the elderly, our senior citizens. The lump sum superannuation tax at 30 per cent is a blow to those people who have been prudent and provident. It hits them, particularly in their latter years, when, for a number of reasons, a lump sum would be a far more attractive alternative than an annuity. The vicious Hawke assets test has caused extreme hardship and suffering to the grandmothers and grandfathers of Australia. It is about time that this granny bashing Government laid off the elderly and started picking on somebody its own age. I can assure the House that there are many superannuitants and pensioners in this country who for many years have voted in the hope and belief that they would get a fair deal from the Australian Labor Party. That has now gone. That is now destroyed. It will be the grandparents of Australia who will throw out the Hawke socialist Government neck and crop as it goes to its well deserved political grave at the next Federal election. The day cannot come soon enough for the member for Denison and the grandfathers and grandmothers in his electorate, whom he represents to the utmost of his ability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and thereby oppose the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). It is amusing to note the way that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) uses the House to bring up election issues. I imagine that, with his numbers in Tasmania, he is the one who has to worry about numbers, not me. For the benefit of the honourable member for Denison, I remind the House who was in power in 1976 when the present legislation was introduced. It was in 1976 that the massive increase in the number of invalidity retirements occurred. Earlier this year it was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the Government intended to introduce measures to contain the rate of invalidity retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the provisions in the Bill requires invalid pensioners to report any employment that occurs during the taxation year. The Bill also addresses the associated costs of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. One can easily see why the Government is worried about costs when one realises that, out of the 74,000 Commonwealth pensioners in the scheme, 28,000 or 38 per cent are invalid pensioners. Of course, that is one of the main reasons why the Government has seen fit to introduce amendments to the Superannuation Act. The fact is that invalid pensions offer higher benefits than those otherwise obtainable at an early retirement. It is obvious that a tightening up of the scheme was required. I agree with the honourable member for Bradfield that that was required. But it was also required prior to 1983, but the previous Government did not grasp the nettle and make some amendments to the Act.

The requirement to report is very valid because statistics indicate that 12.4 per cent of invalid pensioners under the age of 65 were employed in the workforce in 1985. These statistics show that, on top of the average amount paid to invalid pensioners, which is $15,200, they also earned in the region of $4,540. The figures also indicate that 1.3 per cent of these pensioners earned in excess of the amount that they would have earned had they remained in their jobs. So one does not need to be an Einstein to work out that there were loopholes in the system. I reiterate that those loopholes existed prior to 1983. They existed right back to 1976 when the legislation was first introduced.

Invalidity pensions are based on the premise that the recipient is not able to work, or not able to perform his normal duties, so why should the invalidity provisions of the scheme provide that the Government, or the taxpayer, should provide a financial supplement to those who engage in employment? It is a ridiculous situation. I can assure the House that that does not impress-I would be surprised if it did-the constituents in my electorate, and I am confident that it would not impress the constituents of most of my colleagues on both sides of the House. I refer especially to the great majority of Australians-60 per cent, as pointed out by the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland)-who do not have the pleasure of being on any pension scheme whatsoever.

I realise, and everybody should realise, that there are mechanisms for the return to Commonwealth employment for pension recipients when they return to good health but I am sorry to say, and I am sure honourable members would agree, that mechanisms are not always effective. Consequently, this Bill contains provisions which will tighten up the mechanisms and therefore will put an end to the abuse of the scheme. The new provisions will also ensure that genuine recipients who are not able to return to full employment can top up their pension with part time work. It is not the purpose of the amendments in the Bill to displace those people.

In essence, the bulk of the changes anticipated in the Public Service reforms announced by the Prime Minister on 25 September are backed up by solid statistics. It is this Government that is doing something about the problem. As I pointed out before, the introduction of the present scheme took place in 1976. I remind the House once again that the Hawke socialist Government, as the honourable member for Denison refers to us, was not in office in 1976. What was done about the problem then? In 1980-81, for instance, 50.6 per cent of all Commonwealth superannuation scheme retirements took place on the ground of invalidity. Who was in power in 1980 and 1981? The honourable member for Bradfield said that then everything was going so right, and he plucked out of the air a figure of $350m. It is the first time I have heard that figure mentioned by anybody. It certainly was not mentioned by the Minister representing the Minister for Finance in this House, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). I notice also that it must be a reasonably bodgie figure, to use a colloquialism, because it has not been included in the Opposition's amendment. The amendment finishes by saying `thus causing a significant loss of revenue to the Commonwealth'. We are already conceding that. The figure of $350m cited by the honourable member for Denison to my mind needs substantiation.
By 1984-85 the figure had crept up to 42.1 per cent, representing 3,000 new invalidity pensions. In October 1984 the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Expenditure observed:

Although there had been a sharp decline in invalidity retirements from 1979 on, the acceleration of invalidity retirements in the immediate period following the introduction of the Scheme in 1976 has altered the composition of the pensioner population and the annual pension liability of the Scheme to the extent that even if a downturn in invalidity retirements was to be experienced it would take some years before the proportion of invalidity pensioners in the pensioner population would be reduced.

In other words, the great majority of people who have retired are on invalidity pensions. As at 30 June 1985, invalidity pensions accounted for $345m, or 45 per cent, of the scheme's total annual pension liability of $760m.

It is not my intention to spout statistics overly because that can be well done by those on the other side of the House. We know how good their statistics are when they give figures like $350m. I conclude by saying that the Bill also contains a large number of other amendments, broadly of a housekeeping nature, which I do not intend to go into at this time. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on this Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) in the climate created by this Government of an expanding public sector and an ever increasing Public Service since this Government was first elected. Since the Government took office in March 1983 we have seen 15,000 new public servants added to the employ of the Commonwealth Public Service. In September of this year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced a reduction in the size of the public sector. He said we must reduce it by 2,000 people. That means that we have a net increase over the period of the Labor Government of 13,000 Commonwealth public servants who are subject to the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund. This compares with the situation under the Fraser Government, when over eight years the number of public servants actually declined. There is no evidence at all that Australia is better off as a result of having 15,000-shortly to be 13,000-more public servants. There is no evidence that services have improved or that there have been increased services. In fact, services have decreased. Anyone trying to get admitted to a public hospital in Victoria-even when the nurses are not on strike-will find 27,000 people already in the queue. So services have declined, productivity is less and as we have more public servants our standard of living is falling. We are in the banana republic class.

SPEECH.PARA: The role of the Opposition in getting this legislation before the House is an interesting one. I congratulate the Opposition and its Waste Watch Committee that brought to the attention of the people of Australia the excessive number of invalidity retirements in the Commonwealth Public Service. As a direct result of the watchful Opposition, through its Waste Watch Committee, the Government was forced to do something. We see here an effective Opposition that has dug around, raised the issue and brought it to the attention of the people of Australia. The Government set up a working party to look at the matter, the report of which has not been tabled in this House or made public. So, as a result of the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee, the Government set up a secret working party. The working party has obviously reported to the Government but we have no evidence of that report or of how it has affected the drafting of the legislation before the House. We have no report as to what that committee found. As far as the Opposition and, I suspect, the Caucus are concerned, we are debating this piece of legislation in the dark, not knowing the basis for it. We are even further confused by having an amendment to the Government's amending legislation put before the House which we are meant to understand and debate, in relation to this very complicated superannuation situation.

We have to ask ourselves why this Government is legislating when the working party has not reported its findings. It is very interesting to see who is on that working party-members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, the Department of Finance and the Public Service Board. It really is the corporate state looking at the public sector. No doubt the public sector unions would have a say about it and control over it. The Government was in a closet, had a secret working party and then introduced the legislation. To me, it has the flavour of a government trying to get the issue out of the way after it was raised by the Waste Watch Committee so that the Government can get on and have an election. It also appears-I would be glad of confirmation or otherwise of this by the Acting Treasurer (Mr Hurford) at the end of the debate-that the Department of Finance has its own separate working party or committee looking at the issue. Again it is another case of the public sector looking at the public sector, but there might be some hope for objectivity.

Let us look at the legislation and the circumstances behind it. It relates to the principal superannuation scheme for Commonwealth Public Service employees. Of 74,000 pensioners, 28,000, or nearly 38 per cent, receive invalidity pensions. The Minister said in his second reading speech that invalidity pensions offer higher benefits than those otherwise obtainable on early age retirement. That is obvious when the figures for 1984-85 are examined.

The Waste Watch Committee report contained statistics showing that the invalidity rate in the Commonwealth Public Service was approximately four times that of members of private sector superannuation schemes. It showed that in 1984-85 a greater number of employees retired from the Public Service for invalidity reasons than by reaching normal retirement age. They are stunning figures and shattering statistics really. We on both sides of this House have to ask ourselves why this is so, especially when these retirement pensions are being funded by the Australian taxpayers. More people-3,001-left through invalidity than those who reached normal retirement age, 2,609.

The figures for Victoria, my State, are quite alarming. I would like to know from the Minister whether the working party report which is secret, which has not been tabled but which apparently exists refers to why the Victorian statistics are much greater than the Australian average and the statistics for the other States. In Victoria twice as many Commonwealth public servants were invalided out as in New South Wales. In Victoria the number invalided out was 1,051, while in New South Wales it was 530. This is incongruous when one looks at the numbers involved. I think there are 10,000 more Commonwealth public servants in New South Wales. The causes of invalidity retirement are interesting. Of all invalid pensioners, 26.4 per cent have been invalided out because of mental disorders, both neurotic and psychotic; 26.2 per cent due to diseases of the musculo-skeletal system; and 17.1 per cent due to diseases of the circulatory system. We need an explanation from the Government as to why these statistics for Victoria are greater than the Australian average.

Again looking at Victoria, 309 of its Commonwealth public servants retired due to neuroses, compared with 95 in New South Wales. At first glance this would seem to indicate the ease with which Commonwealth public servants in Victoria can get invalidity pensions through the mental disorders category. That may be a false accusation, but the statistics support it. In the interests of those pensioners in Victoria and in the interests of taxpayers, I ask the Minister to tell us what that working party report says about that.

The definition of `unfit' is something to which I hope the Minister will refer. It needs to be examined. Unfit for office has been defined as `for reason he or she is unable to perform his or her duties for health reasons as specified'. `As specified' is defined as `for reason he or she is in consequence of physical or mental capacity incapable of performing his or her duties'. It would seem that it is necessary to have tighter controls, tighter definitions or tighter procedures invoked in relation to that definition. Again I would like some explanation from the Minister as to whether the secret report refers to this matter. I think it is in the interests of all taxpayers that we get this information.

As to the superannuation scheme generally, it is in fact and effectively a contribution free fund. The members of the Commonwealth Public Service make payments to a fund, but on retirement they get back their payments with interest. In that regard, as I understand it, it is unique in the country. It is in fact a compulsory savings scheme for Commonwealth public servants. It is covered up and called a superannuation scheme. Members of the public may think it is a contributory scheme by way of contribution of the employee to his superannuation payment in the long run, but it is not. It is a compulsory savings scheme in the guise of payments made to a fund which invests those payments. It has large assets, but that Fund, as I understand it, devotes itself entirely to paying back the contributions to its employees. Both the invalidity retirement pension about which I have talked and the age retirement pension are employer financed. By that I mean that they are paid for by the Commonwealth and directly funded from Consolidated Revenue, which means that they are paid by the taxpayer directly. We have a unique situation which I think needs to be examined. I think the Government needs to be accountable for it because the costs are quite enormous. We have taxpayers of Australia every year paying their tax directly to fund public servants' retirement schemes. I think the time has come for this to stop.

A typical private superannuation fund is contributed to by the employee and it is contributed to by the employer and the employer's contributions are usually greater than those of the employee. It is a matter of arrangement; it is a matter of bargaining between the employer and the employee. We have the whole superannuation case, the rush for superannuation, and superannuation being debated in the private sector. But today we are talking about the public sector, where we have direct subsidisation and taxpayers' revenue directly paying retirement and invalid pensions of public servants, compared with private funds which are funded by both the employer and the employee. I believe that the Commonwealth fund should be put on the same footing as private funds. Contributions from Public Service employees should be paid into a fund. There should be an agreed contribution by the Commonwealth-the amount of the contribution having been agreed between the public service sector and the Commonwealth-and a direct fund should be set up, separate and apart from Consolidated Revenue. I believe that it is not only in the interests of the taxpayers of Australia, but also in the interests of Commonwealth public servants in the long run, because there would be an investment fund out of which pensions would be paid.

So there needs to be a change to a contributory fund, a fund contributed to by employers and employees. I have no doubt about that at all. If we do not do that the costs will grow out of control and the burden on the taxpayer will be enormous. Looking at an actuary's report on the long term costs of the fund from back in 1982, the actuary said in relation to the projected costs of the Commonwealth scheme, that is the directly funded scheme, that it is estimated that in 2001-2, that is, by the end of the century, the net benefit expenditure-it is called that but it is in effect the direct cost to revenue and to the taxpayer-will be $1.15 billion. I believe that the time will come then, if it does not come earlier, when the taxpayers of Australia cannot directly afford that. I would appeal to public servants to see that. I think common sense would show that to be true and would show that they have an interest in this, because eventually the taxpayers will say: `Look, we have had enough; we are just not going to go on ad infinitum paying for public service benefits, especially when you get leave loadings and all these other benefits that we do not get as average taxpayers'.

So the crunch point will come some time before the end of the century. It must therefore be in the interests of public servants and taxpayers alike to get the fund on a proper financial footing, on a prudential footing-that is a financial word, I suppose. But it is not prudential at the moment. In fact, I think governments are being negligent in having taxpayers' funds directly funding pensions in this way. I believe there needs to be a greater debate on the Parliament about it. One finds that this area is a bit of a mystery when one starts going to the library to inquire about Commonwealth superannuation. The information is never in one place. One has to go to a number of books and sources to get the information. If we ring up the Public Service Board we find the people there are pretty crotchety and short with us. If we look at the item in the Budget Papers we see that it is carefully worded with the word `Parliament' before it so parliamentarians are blamed, but parliamentarians have a superannuation scheme to which they contribute, and that is not in debate.

I believe that the Government should move on from here-it has just started as a result of the Waste Watch Committee's report-to establish a fully funded, prudential, contributory scheme in which there are contributions by both public servants and government, so that the pensions of public servants can be on a proper financial, prudential and responsible basis, responsible both to the taxpayers and to the public servants themselves. The reforms that we are debating in this legislation, I believe, are just the start of a fair go for taxpayers of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), as my colleagues the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) and the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace) have adequately demonstrated, introduces measures to contain the rate of invalidity retirements and the associated costs under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. It is also clear that the passage of the Bill will complete a major overhaul of the legislation relating to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. I want to divert a little from some of the comments made by my colleagues earlier in the debate to talk a little about how we come to be in this situation and also to pick up on some of the comments made by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton). I think it is reasonable to reflect that the Government has the object of seeing, in one form or another, adequate superannuation provisions in place across Australia for all members of the work force. So the restructuring of the public sector superannuation funds must achieve objectives which provide flexibility and an interchange between employees and must bring at least a reasonable degree of comparableness between private sector employees and public sector employees.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe, as has been made clear in the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the review of the Commonwealth Public Service, that Commonwealth public servants have anything to fear from these changes. In fact, the overwhelming indications are that they support these initiatives. The honourable member for Higgins talked about initiatives of the Waste Watch Committee. He talked about banana republics and, in the usual way, he went on-delicately today, I admit-with the public sector bash. When we see this we are entitled to ask: `Where is the constructive contribution from the other side of the House?'. I therefore turn to the amendment which has been introduced by the Opposition today. What does it say? It says:
whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading-
which really means, looking between the lines, that honourable members opposite will pass it without opposition-
the House is of the opinion that the Government has failed to adequately apply the provisions of the Superannuation Act . . .

Which superannuation Act is referred to? It is the one that was created during the 30 years of government of honourable members opposite-let us not forget that-those who come in here and preach to us: `Let us get rid of the public sector; let us cut it back; let us stop all these wasted dollars going into the public sector'. Those who created this Act talk about failing to apply adequately the provisions of the superannuation Act. Let us have a look at this matter. I see these superannuation changes not only as necessary reform of the Commonwealth superannuation Acts but also as part of a broader austerity measure that has been introduced by the Government, which has been accepted by people across our nation. I have here as guests today members of a delegation from the Bacchus Marsh shire and community groups who are looking to scarce government resources for assistance. When they sit here in this chamber-I am delighted to have them here-and hear this sort of drivel coming from the other side of the House they are entitled to ask: `Where are the scarce dollars?'. I will tell honourable members where they are. They are everywhere. As a society we know we are having to accept austerity measures. We know we are having to tighten the belt. That has been accepted by substantial groups in our community; it has been accepted by wage earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not by them.

—No, as my colleague the honourable member for McEwen interjects, it has not been accepted by the Opposition and not by the people whom it represents. I want to come to that point. It has been accepted by wage and salary earners who are prepared to accept discounting of their wages. It has been accepted by the farm sector which has realised that there is a major drop in our rural export income. It has been accepted by pensioner groups who know that they too must share some of this burden. Which is the group that will not accept it? It is the group that was so adequately depicted in that cartoon in the Australian Financial Review showing those corporate business leaders puffing their cigars, carrying their protest signs saying: `We have never paid tax and we never will'. Now they are protesting against changes such as the fringe benefits tax. They are being backed up by an opposition which represents these sorts of attitudes in these sorts of people. These are people who reject proposals such as a mild and moderate capital gains tax, people who are now opposing the Australia Card. These are the very same people who come into this House and talk about dole bludgers. Honourable members should not forget that the term `dole bludgers' is a product of the Fraser Government. Now these people come into this House and talk about the dole bludgers and welfare cheats, but they will not support moves to tighten up the system. They will not support the Australia Card.

SPEECH.PARA: We find ourselves faced with an ongoing role of contradiction, a role of opposition. We see it in this amendment to the second reading of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill-opposition for the sake of opposition. This comes from people who are led by a man who early in his leadership professed that he would support worthwhile government initiatives. He said that he would not provide opposition just for the sake of opposition. Now we find this sort of thing occurring. Let us not forget that the people who created dole bludgers, in their terms, who presided over a system which created mammoth tax avoidance in this country-the largest growth industry in Australia in the late 1970s was tax minimisation and avoidance-are now opposing the measures to cut back abuses. They are the people who vilified Mr Justice Murphy and then came in here with a sanctimonious defence of former Chief Justice Barwick. They are people who are continually caught up in contradiction. They are people who protest about the assets test yet claim they want welfare spending cut back. They are people who encouraged off shore borrowing but now talk about our national debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I think that we have been more than generous in giving flexibility to the honourable member. I suggest that he come back to the subject of the debate.
—I ask the honourable member to bear in mind the subject of the Bill.

—I take the point of order. I was developing the point that as we are moving to reform the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund and particularly these measures relating to invalidity retirements, these matters must be seen in a broader context of austerity measures in this country. They must also be seen in the context of the amendment introduced by the Opposition. The Opposition has led us down this path. We inherited this sort of legislation, this sort of morass of public sector regulation and difficulty. The Opposition left us with a record deficit, and now it talks about wanting spending cut back.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the measures in this legislation are substantial and should be supported. They should be supported by an opposition which recognises them as a substantial move forward by a government that is prepared to take hard decisions at a time when this country needs them. As I said earlier, the object is to provide across Australia a national superannuation scheme or a model which provides for fair interchange and flexibility of movement between the public and private sectors. Therefore, in all areas it needs to be compatible and it needs to have provisions which make those sorts of objectives feasible. Having said that, I wish to finish with this point: I cannot finish my speech without drawing the attention of the House to an article published in Australian Time earlier this month which discussed the role of the Opposition. It describes the Victorian Opposition as `broke, desperate and directionless'. When Opposition members come into this House and introduce an amendment which effectively says that they support what the Government is doing but they intend to oppose it for the sake of opposing it, I cannot help but reflect that they are broke, desperate and directionless. They have no policies and no proposals for substantial improvement. They simply provide a continuing opposition committed to knocking, knocking and knocking. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (5.37)

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate on the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), I wish to thank all honourable members who have taken part. As the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) said so eloquently, the Government will, of course, reject the Opposition's amendment. The Opposition accuses the Government of failing to apply adequately the Superannuation Act provisions concerning the payment of invalidity pensions, and this, so the Opposition suggests, has caused a significant loss to revenue. That is absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the introduction of the present Commonwealth superannuation scheme in 1976, a massive increase occurred in the number of invalidity retirements. The rate dropped markedly between 1979 and 1981 as a result of administrative action, but now it shows signs of increasing, and that is the reason why this legislation has been so necessary. It is worth pointing out to the House the increases which came about from 1976-77 when 3,206 people retired on the grounds of invalidity. In 1977-78 that number grew to 4,722. In 1978-79 the number was 3,910 and in 1979-80 it was 3,654. As I said, changes were made in that period which caused a reduction, but when one looks at the way the figures have grown in recent years one sees the need for further changes. In 1983-84 the number of retirees on the ground of invalidity totalled 2,767; in 1984-85 the figure was 3,001; in 1985-86 it was 3,027. Since 1981-82 the number of invalidity retirements has grown. Indeed if one looks at the figures per 100 contributors, this is shown again to be so. I drive home this point by giving the following statistics. In 1981-82 the number of invalidity retirements per 100 contributors was 0.82; in 1982-83 it was 0.88; in 1983-84 it was 0.90; in 1984-85 it was 0.95; and in 1985-86 the preliminary figure was at least 0.93. The 1985-86 Commonwealth superannuation scheme invalidity rate per 100 contributors of 0.93 compares with one of 0.58 for the Victorian State superannuation fund. So clearly when one makes that comparison one sees that something had to be done.

These figures that I give and the point that I make in support of this legislation must be seen in a wider context. The adjustment of invalidity pensions for earnings from employment is one of a range of measures being implemented by the Government which aim to contain the high level of invalidity retirements under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. I remind the House that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his statement on the reform of the Australian Public Service on 25 September this year, announced major changes in the arrangements for the redeployment or retrenchment of inefficient or surplus staff and these will counter any tendency that may exist for employers to use invalidity retirement as a means of shedding inefficient staff. Continued employment or re-employment at a lower salary supplemented by a partial invalidity pension are alternatives to invalidity retirement already provided in the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. Under the reforms announced by the Prime Minister secretaries to departments, with the Public Service Board, will retain powers to retire staff on invalidity grounds and secretaries will also have the power to transfer staff to other duties, including at a lower classification. The Board may also use its powers to transfer such staff to another department, for example, when no suitable position is available in the original department.

It is also necessary to see this legislation in the context of the Prime Minister announcing that provisions for invalidity retirement for statutory authorities will be considered for amendment to make them consistent with Public Service Act provisions. In the meantime, Ministers will require authorities within their portfolio responsibilities to take rigorous steps to contain invalidity retirements.

The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in his statement on invalidity retirement from Commonwealth employment on 17 April 1986, indicated that the Commissioner for Superannuation is advising all new invalidity pensioners that their fitness for re-employment may be reviewed from time to time. Persons whose incapacity for employment has been identified by the Commonwealth Medical Officer as being such that their health may later recover are being advised that they will be listed for early medical review. Of course, this is in their interests as well as in the interests of an efficient public sector because they must be much happier if they are healthy and able to return to work, to go back into the work force, than if that were not so.

New invalidity pensioners are being informed that, if they change residential locality after retirement, this will not ordinarily constitute grounds for refusing an offer of re-employment in their former locality unless the change of locality occurred primarily for medical reasons which are still relevant. The Government is reviewing employee compensation arrangements-we must see this measure in that context as well-including the relationship between compensation and superannuation. Measures to rationalise and tighten medical procedures associated with invalidity retirement are also being considered. I repeat: It is in that wider context that one must see this change in law.

The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), in leading for the Opposition, sought an assurance that welfare and service pensions would not be included in the amount of earnings in respect of which the calculation could apply under this Bill. The portion is clearly set out in the Bill. In accordance with proposed new sub-section 73a (1), an invalidity pension would be reduced in relation to the pensioner's personal earnings where the aggregate of the pension and the personal earnings exceeded the specified limit. I draw to the attention of the honourable member for Bradfield new sub-section 73a (1), which defines `personal earnings' as salary, wages, fees or other amounts received by the pensioner for services rendered or work performed, that is, income from personal exertion. The term `personal earnings', therefore, does not include a social welfare or service pension or, for that matter, any type of pension. Accordingly, receipt of a social welfare or service pension would not affect the level of invalidity pension payable under the Superannuation Act 1976 or 1922.

The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) made claims in his usual way that the Government is intent on forcing Australians to take out annuities as a means of providing retirement income. In his usual way he sought to persuade the House that there was something wrong in that. I suggest that retirement incomes should be in the form of income and where they are lump sums, of course, it is so easy for them to be dissipated so that the person becomes dependent on social welfare. If they are in the form of annuities they continue to get income for that person.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are ways around it.

—The honourable member for Bradfield and I fortunately are in a special position as members of parliament-in my case as a Minister and in his case hoping to be a Minister, forlornly, I would say-where we have to close those ways around it because we are trustees for public funds.
—That is not the point. You can structure your tax system to take account of lump sums.
—Order! The honourable member for Bradfield will cease interjecting.

—I will make the point, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we make no apologies for seeking through taxation law to ensure that lump sums are not taken where indeed annuities should be taken for the protection of the person concerned.
—No freedom of choice. You do not like freedom of choice.
—What is your electorate, Roger?
—Order! The Minister will take no notice of the interjections. I will deal with the interjections. Direct all your comments through the Chair.

—You misunderstood me, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was reminding myself of the seat of the honourable member for Higgins because I want to pay him the compliment of responding to the contribution he made in this debate. He sought information regarding the reasons for high levels of invalidity retirements in Victoria. The higher levels of invalidity retirements in that State under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme are reflected by higher than national average levels of invalidity retirements in the Victorian public sector schemes. It is difficult to establish beyond doubt the reasons for this. However, ostensibly it would seem that medical standards for invalidity retirement in that State as applied by the medical profession are tighter, that is, they are less inclined to take a risk that a person refused invalidity retirement is in fact unfit for employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Lastly, I draw to the attention of the House something which I think those who have taken part in this debate already know, that is, we need a Committee stage because I wish to move amendments to proposed new section 73a, to be inserted into the Superannuation Act 1976 by clause 32, to provide in the Act for a limit on pension and personal earnings above which invalidity pensions would be reduced. I thank again those who have taken part. Of course, the Government opposes this second reading amendment of the Opposition and I commend the second reading to the House. (Quorum formed)
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Connolly's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
