TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 32, page 18, lines 16 to 18, omit proposed definition of ``prescribed maximum rate'', insert the following definitions:
`` `prescribed maximum rate' means-
(a) before the operation of sub-section (2)-$19,200 per annum increased by the relevant percentage of that rate; or
(b) after the operation of that sub-section-the rate that is the prescribed maximum rate by virtue of that sub-section;
`prescribed percentage', in relation to a prescribed year, means the prescribed percentage in relation to that year for the purposes of section 148;
`prescribed year' means a prescribed year within the meaning of Part X, other than a year commencing before 1 July 1988;
`relevant maximum rate', in relation to an invalidity pensioner, means-
(a) the prescribed maximum rate; or

(b) 75% of the amount per annum that the Commissioner, having regard to any changes in the rates of remuneration that have occurred since the pensioner ceased to be an eligible employee and any other matters that the Commissioner considers relevant, determines would have been the annual rate of salary of the pensioner if the pensioner had not ceased to be an eligible employee and had continued to occupy the position held immediately before so ceasing,
whichever is the greater;''.
(2) Clause 32, page 18, after the proposed definition of ``relevant pension rate'' in proposed sub-section 73a (1) insert the following definition:
`` `relevant percentage' means the percentage that represents A-B expressed as a percentage of B, where-

a is the only, or earliest, all groups consumer price index number for the weighted average of the 8 capital cities published by the Australian Statistician in respect of the March quarter of 1987; and
b is the only, or earliest, all groups consumer price index number for the weighted average of the 8 capital cities published by the Australian Statistician in respect of the June quarter of 1986.''.
(3) Clause 32, page 18, lines 26 to 28, omit proposed sub-section (2), insert the following sub-section:

``(2) Where rates at which invalidity pensions were payable immediately before the commencement of a prescribed year are increased in accordance with section 148, the rate that, immediately before that commencement, was (because of paragraph (a) of the definition of `prescribed maximum rate' or the previous operation of this sub-section) the prescribed maximum rate is increased, with effect from that commencement, by the prescribed percentage, in relation to that prescribed year, of that rate.''.
(4) Clause 32, page 18, line 38, omit `'prescribed maximum rate'', insert ``relevant maximum rate for the pensioner''.

In the second reading speech on this Bill, I outlined the provisions of the proposed new section 73a of the Superannuation Act 1976 whereby invalidity pensions payable under that Act and the Superannuation Act 1922 would be reduced on a dollar for dollar basis where the aggregate amount of the pension and income from personal exertion of the person concerned exceeded a limit to be prescribed in regulations under the Superannuation Act 1976. I noted that in setting that limit the Government would have regard to the position of persons in receipt of low pensions.

The Government has now decided that it would be preferable for the limit to be provided in the Act rather than being left for prescription in the regulations. The proposed amendments would vary the new section 73a to provide for a limit that the Government considers would achieve its purpose but at the same time protect persons in receipt of low levels of invalidity pension, and allow all pensioners to earn a small amount of additional income without affecting their pension payments. The limit which has been adopted is the greater of 75 per cent of a pensioner's updated pre-retirement salary or 85 per cent of an amount-updated as necessary-reflecting the average weekly total earnings of full time adults in May 1986.

It is intended that the pension adjustment provisions of the Bill have effect from 1 May 1987. Accordingly, provision is made in these amendments for the limit based on the May 1986 average weekly earnings to be increased by the actual movement in the consumer price index between the June quarter 1986 and the March quarter 1987. The figure so determined will apply until 1 July 1988 when it will be adjusted in accordance with the March quarter 1987 to March quarter 1988 movement in the CPI on the same basis as that used for the indexation of Commonwealth superannuation scheme pensions.

Similarly provision is made for the limit based on pre-retirement salary to be updated. The amendments provide for the Commissioner for Superannuation to determine the amount which would have been the annual rate of salary of the invalidity pensioner had he or she continued to occupy the position held immediately before retiring. Adjustment of invalidity pensions in respect of earnings in accordance with these limits will result in estimated annual savings in excess of $4m. An explanatory memorandum explaining the proposed amendments in greater detail has been circulated with the proposed amendments. I now formally present it. I commend the proposed amendments to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not object to these proposals. However, I think they do open up some interesting possibilities which the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) did not answer in his address. Firstly, it is proposed that what was originally going to be the right to regulate these arrangements be changed to a specific reference in the Act. We understand that. However, I would just like to inquire from the Minister how he proposes to see what will be a regulation built into the Act which I would suspect will not have the flexibility which he claims it will have.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to the fact that the Government has only very recently announced its intention to reduce the size of the consumer price index flow-on of Commonwealth retirees. As I recall, the figure was about 2 per cent on the last CPI figures. If he is going to apply that to existing retirees-his new proposal is to relate it to a pre-determined amount as of May 1986, which is a date earlier than what is currently the cut-off point for that 2 per cent-I simply suggest to the Minister that whoever drafted this proposal probably did not take that recent policy determination into account. If, on the other hand, the Minister remains with a regulatory arrangement, he would have greater flexibility to make those changes as he sees fit; in other words, on behalf of all those pensioners, whether they be recipients of early retirement, or whatever reason, or those who have retired on the basis of age. Can I seek the Minister's confirmation that a distinction will not be drawn between the various classifications of pensioners under the Commonwealth Superannuation Act? I think that will not be the Government's intention, but I think it is one which requires some examination.

The Minister also referred earlier to some statistics in relation to access to the pension over a period of years. I wonder whether he has bothered to examine pages 204 and 205 of the annual reports of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and Commissioner for Super- annuation for 1984-85. There is a most interesting statistic. What it basically says is that 61.35 per cent of current recipients of Commonwealth superannuation are also eligible for access to some level of social security benefits; in other words, age pensions. The pension ceases to be paid when the income reaches $218.60 per week or $11,367.20 per annum. That is of some period when this report was prepared and obviously does not take into account the current rate. It is proposed here that the amount of $19,200 will apparently be the cut-off point which is said to be approximately 85 per cent of the annual amount of the May 1986 full time adult average weekly total earnings. I merely make that statistical observation to the Minister because I think we must be very careful in these matters, with all the intentions in the world of being fair, that we do not create anomalies which come back later to haunt us. It is a characteristic of much of the legislation through this House that anomalies quite often tend to go with us. I think it is very important to be able to identify at the very early stage that that is not so.

It is also worth noting that the average pension paid to the 72,498 adult pensioners as at 30 June 1985, which excludes, I might add, children and orphan pensioners, was $10,452 per annum. The superannuation Acts do not provide for the divestment or forgoing of pensions in payment of the total or near total commutation of pensions. The pensions that they receive, therefore, limit the actions of Commonwealth superannuation pensioners to the regularly updated Commonwealth income-tested pensioners and fringe benefits. I only make that observation because there is a growing perception in the community at large that the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund is so generous that it places recipients of Commonwealth pensions in some type of special benefit category, different from the vast majority of the Australian work force. It can be argued with some justification. I know an honourable member, who like me, has taken a close interest in superannuation matters over many years could draw the observation that Commonwealth superannuation vis-a-vis the general thrust of most existing white collar superannuation is fairly generous. I think the figure I quoted, namely, some 61 per cent of beneficiaries still receiving pensions so low from the Commonwealth that they are still able to qualify for some level of secondary Commonwealth benefits through social security does suggest that the system is not as good as it ought to be. One reason why that is so is that many of that 61 per cent could well be people who have qualified for the minimum access to Commonwealth superannuation. It will also have to be taken into account that many others have been in the Commonwealth for a substantial number of years but throughout that period have not reached positions of seniority to the extent that they did qualify for substantial benefits under superannuation.

That leads me, once again, to seek the views of the Minister as to whether the Government is prepared to re-examine the application of Commonwealth superannuation legislation and the administration of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. The legislation which went through this Parliament, as I recall it, about a year ago, contained a number of significant reforms. One of those reforms was to try to encourage contributors to feel that at least they were going to be told what was going to happen with their money-something which, generally speaking, had not been the position previously. But I think it has left open two very important elements which are worth consideration. Firstly, there is no evidence whatsoever to suggest that an effectively closed fund, such as SFIT, necessarily returns to its contributors a level of benefit commensurate with that of the private sector as a whole. The second point which is worth raising in this context is: To what extent should a Commonwealth government, through a statutory authority-albeit one which has done its best in terms of the reforms of last year to isolate and separate from the thrust of the Public Service as a whole-be in a position where it can force its employees into a monopoly type environment where their funds must go to the SFIT scheme as part of their terms of employment? The Government talks of deregulation in terms of the financial sector as a whole. Why is it that, in that context, the Government is not prepared to say, at least to new entrants to the Commonwealth Public Service: `You have a choice. You may put your funds in SFIT or you may put your funds into any approved source of long term superannuation investment.'?

The other major consideration which should be taken into account in this context is this: If the funding of SFIT is offered on an annual tranche basis to a selected group of fund managers who would then have the opportunity to invest those funds in a totally competitive environment so that, over a period of years, on the balance of averages, one would be able to determine without any statistical doubt whatsoever the extent to which the funding of Commonwealth employees' superannuation contributions was guaranteed virtually to get them the highest rate, on an aggregate basis, available to the market at any specific time, surely it could be said that the Commonwealth, as an employer, was doing its duty by its employees? But while we continue with this arrangement for employees-in the context of this legislation we are talking about amendments to the Act which again do nothing to restrict in any way or to expand the opportunities of individual contributors to have that freedom of choice, and even if they choose to go into SFIT, to feel that the funds are then offered out on an annual tranche basis so they are given every opportunity to maximise their return on investments-I think the Government is failing what is undoubtedly one of the largest elements of the total superannuation community of Australia.

The Minister made the point earlier, as did other speakers for the Government, that some 40 per cent of the Australian work force were covered for superannuation. Of course, that is correct. However, the Opposition has never resiled from the fact that that is not a satisfactory basis for superannuation. We support the view that the entire work force should have the opportunity to be superannuated, whether it be in the public sector or the private sector. However, the fundamental difference between our policy and that of the Government is that, in the Government's attempt to realise national superannuation by another means and, because of its fear of its own trade union base, it has not been prepared to argue a case that normal superannuation for most people is based on a contribution from the employer and the employee. The best that the Government has managed to achieve in terms of its private sector superannuation schemes, to a large degree controlled and managed through trade unions-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) for answering some of the questions that I raised during the second reading debate. I refer specifically to his answer concerning the high levels of invalidity pensions in Victoria. As I understood him, he said that it was difficult to establish why the situation was so bad in Victoria, especially as the medical standards were higher. As I get no response now from the Minister I take it that that is so. This means that the mystery only deepens and the figures become more incongruous because the pension invalidity retirement figures in Victoria are horrendous. I have referred to them previously.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have evidence that the medical standards apparently are tighter in Victoria and we are still faced with payouts to those public servants who are invalided out of the public sector. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me respond to the points raised by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton). First of all, I give the honourable member for Bradfield an assurance that no distinction will be drawn between various classes of pensioners. We are dealing with just the one invalidity pension. Secondly, I am informed that the flexibility required to achieve the purposes outlined by him of accommodating any discounts to the consumer price index are built into the wording of this amendment. I also draw to his attention that the figure of $19,200 was decided upon after the discounting decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, I take the point that he made about the low levels of income for some but I need to point out why a limit of 85 per cent of average weekly earnings and 75 per cent of salaries was chosen. The basic thrust of the invalidity pension adjustment procedure is to remove any incentive that might exist for persons to view invalidity retirement as a means of obtaining a taxpayer-financed income supplement while they pursue a second career. The Government recognises that pensioners, particularly those on low pensions, should not be discouraged from supplementing their incomes, where possible. The limit, based on 85 per cent of average weekly earnings, simply provides a level which is acceptable to the Government. In terms of the average pension, which is $15,200, of invalidity pensioners in employment, it would allow roughly an additional 25 per cent, which is $4,000. Ninety per cent of invalidity pensioners receive pensions less than the $19,200 limit. Based on the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for income of individuals, 70 per cent of income recipients in Australia receive less than 85 per cent of average weekly earnings. The limit of 75 per cent of updated, pre-retirement salary allows persons receiving invalidity pensions above the 85 per cent AWE limit to earn an additional 5 per cent of their updated, pre-retirement salaries free of reductions.

I point out that we, in government, will continually re-examine the necessary invalidity pension levels. I note the point that the honourable member made about giving new entrants to the Public Service the choice of deciding between public and private sector funds. I would see great difficulties in giving that choice. But we in this Government are very reasonable people, with open minds, running a very good government in difficult times. Of course, it goes without saying that we look at all of the options before us.

The honourable member for Higgins misconstrued my use of the word `tighter'. I meant to convey to him the message that, as we see it, the medical profession in Victoria is following the letter of the law much more closely than in other States in not wanting in any way to be dragged through the courts for being too strict in its interpretation of who deserves an invalidity pension and who does not. In other words, I suppose in one sense I could have used the word `laxer'. What I said conveyed the opposite of what I intended. The fact is that, if the medical profession is too lax in its assessment of people deserving an invalidity pension, it can be taken to the courts. So the medical profession is looking at its responsibility in a pretty tight way when it comes to make those assessments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond by asking the Minister: Is he saying that the conditions in Victoria-that is, the standards for medical tests-are the same as in other parts of Australia or are they different?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

We have put it down to medical assessments at this stage, but we will do more work on that because it would be in everybody's interests if there were standardisation throughout Australia.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 October, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-(Quorum formed) The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986 will go down in Australian constitutional and legal history as one of the great opportunities lost by the Hawke Labor Government to restore to this nation agreement that not only the Aboriginal people of Australia, specifically those who reside in the Northern Territory, but all Australians regardless of colour, race or where they might live, have some right to expect equality of opportunity. This legislation is an attempt by the Government yet again not only to sell the Aboriginal people short but also to renege on the commitments it has entered into with the Northern Territory Government, the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association, the mining interests of the Northern Territory and in fact every other community interest in that part of Australia. It seems to be difficult for some members of this Government, who belong to a party which claims to believe in consensus, to understand that that word means that an attempt must be made at all times to bring solutions to conflicts of interest which have always existed in relation to land rights in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is a public manifestation of failure. It does not even attempt to reach an adequate balance between what ought to be achieved to meet the legitimate interests of the Aboriginal community of the Northern Territory and the interests of the cattle industry, the mining industry and not least of all the interests of the Northern Territory Government itself-a legally constituted and elected government which has responsibility to keep within its purview of interests all the people of the Northern Territory, including the 23 per cent in the Northern Territory who happened to be Aboriginal people. It is a matter of great concern to me, therefore, that this Government's legislation fails. In this matter it has been led by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), who at least a year ago made serious attempts to bridge the gap which obviously existed between these various community interests groups. He visited the Northern Territory and spoke to them. He negotiated with the Northern Territory Government, with the miners, with the Aboriginal land councils and with the cattlemen's association. He did all the right things. He promised them action. That is the one thing that he has failed to deliver in this legislation. No doubt he will tell the House during his remarks that next year he will look into all these matters; he will keep all these questions in mind. But the fact is that in the minds of all these groups this Minister was trusted, at least for a short time. Now, in desperation, those groups see this Government for what it is-people who will say anything to anybody for long enough to lead them astray.

The Minister has done nothing in the amendments before this House to overcome the fundamental problem which has bedevilled the Aboriginal land rights legislation since 1976 when it was introduced by the Fraser Government. I refer specifically to the degree to which Aboriginal owned land, some 50 per cent of the Northern Territory, can be made available for economic development. There has been a somewhat simplistic, but perhaps understandable, belief that the economic development in the Northern Territory, on the basis of its current economic record, involves either mining or the cattle industry. So be it. But one fact remains inviolate-that is, the economic position of this nation will not improve unless we have the capacity as a people to identify where our resources lie and then determine how best they can be utilised.

The Minister, Government members and certainly past ministers of the Liberal and National parties will share the belief that in many respects Aboriginal land ownership is not identical with the ownership of land held under normal white title. We made it so because we gave them a title which was different. We introduced legislation which was unique in the world. The people upon whose judgment we depended at that time-people like Mr Justice Woodward-advised us that necessary changes would have to be introduced from time to time. The years have passed and it is fair to say that not enough changes have been introduced. Because of our delay in introducing those changes and particularly because of the delays of the last four years, we have allowed a social atmosphere to be created in the Northern Territory which is extremely damaging to the long term viability of both the Aboriginal and white communities there.

No doubt, in due course, the Territory will obtain statehood. When that happens legislation such as this will undoubtedly be transferred to its jurisdiction. Surely if the Minister wants to be a statesman, if he wants to go down in the history of this Commonwealth as a great Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who brought unity to the Australian people, who encouraged Aboriginals to feel that they were part of the totality of the substance and the society of this land, this is the opportunity that he has allowed to pass him by. For that, he will not be thanked, but he will be remembered.

I find it incredible that in his second reading speech, towards the end-I emphasise that-he thought it was necessary to tell the people of Australia that he had not been able to consider a range of other amendments. The point is that the issues which he has chosen to ignore are precisely those which are creating the division among the people of the Northern Territory. Exploration and mining on Aboriginal land is a red hot issue in that State and elsewhere in Australia. The granting of an estate or interest in Aboriginal land to the Northern Territory Government for the provision of essential services is undoubtedly an essential element of any change if we are to have in place the principle of equality of opportunity by which the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory can expect from the Northern Territory Government the provision of services at least at a level similar to that given to other communities in that Territory. While there remains legislation which makes it difficult, if not impossible, for the Northern Territory to approach the Aboriginal communities throughout the State on a similar basis to the way in which it approaches other people the Government is putting in place a division yet again, yet it calls itself a government of consensus and, may I add, a government of concern. In this case we see no evidence of consensus and even less evidence of genuine concern for the long term interests of all the people in the Northern Territory, including, and in this case especially, those who are of Aboriginal descent.

Another element which was ignored to some degree but which was then snuck into the amendments to this Bill in a most extraordinary way because, apparently, the Central Land Council wanted it was the question of protection of sacred sites. It seems odd to me that through this Parliament only in recent times we have passed Aboriginal sacred sites legislation. In the Northern Territory there are Aboriginal sites ordinances on the books. Yet in this Bill we have the provision that land councils will not only be able to determine the protection of Aboriginal sacred sites on Aboriginal land but also be able to determine the protection of those same sites elsewhere. I trust that when the Minister has his opportunity to comment on my observations he will be able to put forward a logical explanation as to why we need three sets of legislation-two from the Commonwealth and one from the Northern Territory-which are meant to be directed at precisely the same set of problems.

Is it any wonder that the cattlemen and the other communities in the Northern Territory regard this legislation with considerable doubt, if not fear, and certainly distrust for a government which introduces amendments of that type without even attempting to explain to people why those changes are necessary? As I said, in the atmosphere of the Northern Territory today, where there is such distrust, no government which claims to look after the interests of the Aboriginal people should take it upon itself to introduce with such arrogance and such lack of real concern changes of this nature unless it is prepared, slowly but carefully, to set in place the groundwork upon which the edifice must be built.

There are other changes, such as methods for calculating payments of royalty equivalents from the Aboriginal Trust Account, which is a matter of great concern not only to the Northern Territory but also to the Aboriginal communities. It is complex, and it deserves to be given due consideration because it is from the Trust Account that we see the opportunity of the Commonwealth's continuing to give royalties which are its share of mining in the Northern Territory back to Aboriginal communities, the land councils and the traditional owners on a shared basis so that many of the services which they need can be supplied, albeit indirectly, from their own financial base. It is a real opportunity and one which this Government must not ignore.

Perhaps the biggest problem facing many Aboriginals-those who own land or those who have access to land-is the question of removal from claim of pastoral properties which are owned by Aboriginals and which are public purpose land. I have already referred to the problem of public purpose land. Under the current legislation and, regrettably, under the amendments put forward by this Government to date, the Northern Territory still does not have adequate access on a similar basis to what it has to all other communities in the Northern Territory for the provision of services of housing, power, water and so forth. These matters rankle with the Northern Territory; they rankle with the white communities; and they rankle with the Aboriginal communities which then ask: `Why cannot we have assimilated services?'.

What is worse is that, because this Government has failed consistently over four years even to attempt to reach a reasonable modus operandi with the Northern Territory Government in this whole range of complex Aboriginal-Northern Territory-type issues, we see today virtual armed confrontation, whether we are talking about Kakadu National Park, World Heritage listing or the issue of Aboriginal title of which, I might add, the Minister has been making much in recent weeks-he gives it, then he takes it away for about seven days and then he gives it back again, and he flies to the Northern Territory as a gesture. For whatever reason he does that, let the point be known that when that title is given to those traditional owners, unlike any title which may be given to any other community and to most Aboriginal communities, this one has a very important codicil. It simply says: `You cannot use your land. You are getting this title only provided that you are prepared to hand it over to the National Parks and Wildlife Service which will then use it as a national park. If you do not want your land, fine, do not do it that way'. Why put in a condition? If the Pitjantjatjara people want to do that, that is their decision, not the Minister's. The Minister does not then have to put in place arrangements setting requirements and conditions upon which matters of that nature should take place.

An Aboriginal lady named Pat Fowell, who is currently the education co-ordinator for the Australian Teachers Federation-not an organisation which one would normally expect to be quoted by members of the Liberal Party, not an organisation that is particularly noted for its favouritism towards the conservative side of politics-had some very interesting remarks to make about this Government and its whole approach to Aboriginal welfare. This is what she said:
The image of the Labor Party as one traditionally more sympathetic than the Liberals to Aboriginal issues (especially the all-important matter of land rights), has been totally destroyed.

It has been totally destroyed for one fundamental reason-ever since just before its election in 1983, this Government, led by this Minister, along the length and breadth of this land has consistently offered the Aboriginal people a bill of goods which it could not buy nor could it sell. It could not buy the land because the land was not its to buy; it was the land of State governments. It could not sell its proposals for national land rights because, again, the vast majority of the Australian people regarded with some horror the basic proposition being put forward by the Minister on behalf of this Hawke Labor Government that it would introduce into this country, through this Parliament, legislation which for all times would determine the ultimate results of land decisions emanating from this Parliament over the property of individual people, corporations and, above all, the States. The greatest evidence of the Government's total unadulterated failure rests in the State of Western Australia. I find it extraordinary that the Minister, in the opening remarks of his second reading speech, said:
Undoubtedly the most substantial and difficult issue that is addressed in the Bill relates to the provision of secure title to land for Aboriginals living in pastoral areas in the Northern Territory.

I agree with the need for this; I emphasise that. I understand the problem; I accept the need for change. But there are disagreements about how many people fit the abovementioned description. Some say 4,000; some say 3,000. But one thing is clear: Because these people do not have access to unalienated land, the way most tribal groups have in the past, they have been treated differently from those in the other position. Let this Minister face the facts. Those communities are dotted around the pastoral properties of the Northern Territory today and I agree, generally speaking, that their economic and social circumstances are less than satisfactory. Some would even claim, as the Minister probably would, that they are shameful. But one thing must not be ignored: Many of those people, before 1972, had jobs. They worked on cattle runs and they were the mainstream-they were the backbone, in fact-of the economic viability of the Northern Territory cattle industry. Of course, the trade union movement of Australia would simply write this off as cheap labour, especially since it was labour not dominated by trade union controls, awards and so forth. Of course, in a sense, it was cheap labour. But at least those communities had the financial and social viability to be able to hold together. But when the Whitlam Government came in and determined that all things must change those people were no longer able to find work on those cattle stations and they became vagrants, whether on their own land or elsewhere. They were effectively vagrants. It is that social problem that we are facing today.

We have seen in the last two weeks the problem of the Pitjantjatjara people in the northern part of South Australia, where 22 young men are now very sick in the Alice Springs hospital, and one has already died, from sniffing petrol. The Minister knows, as I do, that this is a complex and difficult problem. But, in all fairness, it is one which has existed there for the full period of office of this Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I think it demonstrates quite clearly at least one important fact. The granting of land per se will not solve the massive social and economic problems being faced by many communities today. The Pitjantjatjara people were the first community in South Australia to be granted land rights. Much was made of that both by the Liberal side of politics, which made those grants, and by various governments since then. Many would say, in fact, that it was a trail blazer for much of the legislation and the activities of both Federal and State governments since then. But if one leaves people out in the desert and does not give them water and the basic requirements for life, it is rather difficult to argue that one has achieved very much. I think one of the fundamental problems that the Socialist Left in the Australian Labor Party tends to ignore is that people want now to live on their traditional land. But that decision leads on to a whole set of other decisions which face government. On a per capita basis the solution and the provision of basic goods and services and so forth by government to those communities will be extremely difficult indeed.

But one of the fundamental problems facing us in the whole land rights equation in the Northern Territory, leading on from the initial legislation of 1976, is the predisposed belief that Aboriginal communities, if possible, were to be hermetically sealed off from the realities of the world. They were to be apart-a word which today most of us reject out of hand. But we still use the term `homelands' in regard to many of those communities, because that is the term, apparently, they want to use. But I would not want it to be thought that any group in this community should want to pursue a policy directly or indirectly which ultimately leads to the present situation of these communities. About 60,000 Aboriginals live in the Northern Territory and the vast majority of them are in their own traditional lifestyle to one degree or another, whether it be in the north or in the central desert regions but in the longer term their children must be given at least the same level of access to the mainstream of Australia as we would expect for our children. They will be facing very difficult problems of mounting and passing over that social and economic bridge between one world and another. But they are the problems which the Aboriginal people themselves have to face. It is not the duty of this Parliament and it is not the function of this Labor Government to set in place legislation which in fact will make it more difficult for those people to face up to those very difficult decisions which they will have to face in the not so distant future and which they have, to one degree or another, been facing in recent years.
I return to Pat Fowell. As I said, she has probably voted Labor all her life. She is an Aboriginal.

TALK.START.PARA: —And will continue to.

—Maybe she will continue to do so. But, reading what she says, I believe that she has put down her deepest seated conviction-and it is a conviction of betrayal. That is the most important thing of all. She believes that she has been betrayed, as the Aboriginal people have been betrayed, by this Government working through a Minister who has offered the world and has not been able to deliver. Now, in the context of this particular legislation, he has thrown away the greatest opportunity ever given to any Aboriginal Affairs Minister in recent years. I refer to the opportunity of sitting down with all groups-the Aboriginals, both those who have land and those who do not; the land councils that represent their interests; the Northern Territory Government, which is meant to represent everybody's interests; the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association; mining interests and so forth-to work out a regime which could then be introduced into legislation to put in place the fundamental amendments which are vital if we are to see the Northern Territory move out of an environment of conflict into one where both Aboriginals and white Australians and, for that matter, any other group-we all know that the Northern Territory has various racial groups within it-are able to see themselves as common citizens of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: But that is not the opportunity this Minister has taken. He has allowed the left wing Caucus to roll him; he has allowed members of the Central Land Council to come down here and continually lobby against change. They do not want any change. Lobbying for them is second nature and they have done it extremely efficiently. But let the Minister be well aware that in May this year he took amendments to this legislation forward and he discussed the matter with all those groups. They were stupid enough to believe that he was telling the truth and that these necessary changes would take place on the basis of agreements which he entered into with them. I have the texts; I have the words of those amendments which the Minister's back bench committee took out and, with great regret, the Minister did not have the courage to face up to the commitments he had made.

We all know in politics one has to face the realities of the party caucus, but equally as a Minister one has wider responsibility-and those responsibilities are to live up to commitments that one has entered into.

The Minister will tell us tonight, as I said earlier: `Don't worry, I could not do it now; it is all too difficult; I will get around to it next year'. Next year is an election year. Everybody knows that, including the Aboriginal people. Certainly the Central Land Council knows that. If the Minister really believes that it will let him get off the hook which it has now put into his mouth, and if he thinks it will let him out of the net with which it has now trussed him up, he is more naive than I know him to be. The fact remains therefore that these changes are less than likely to reach the reality of legislation. Thus, this fundamental opportunity has been missed. Earlier I mentioned Pat Fowell. This is what she said:

While the minister for education and other federal politicians often express sympathy and understanding towards the plight of Aboriginal people, in three years of power, they have done little to assist us. Time is running out, and any opportunities which the election of a Labor government promised are quickly being lost. The attitude of the Hawke government towards Aboriginal people seems to be a cynical assumption that they can be assured of Aboriginal support because politically we have nowhere else to go.

There may be a whole host of pragmatic reasons why ALP policies cannot be implemented. However, `sympathy' and `understanding' amount to mere tokenism when it is unaccompanied by positive action, especially by a government elected on the basis of promises so to act.
She finishes her comments by saying:
Aboriginal people do not need more tokenism, nor more understanding, nor more sympathy. What is needed is positive action.

This opportunity is certainly not a demonstration of positive action. This Government had chances which were unique in the last four years to bring together all those community interests in a set of amendments which would have given the people of the Northern Territory-Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal alike-the belief that the economic development of their Territory would be assured. They do not want to remain in the position of being constant mendicants, at the receiving end of the handouts from the rich man's table in Canberra. Let the people of the Northern Territory stand on their own. Let the Aboriginal people be able to get the benefits from mining on their land, subject to the protection of their sacred sites and their community interests. All those protections are built into Senator Kilgariff's Bill which was introduced into the Senate a few months ago and which I will reintroduce in the debate tonight. I do so with concern that is based upon the fact that this Government has failed to do anything of a concrete nature to introduce into this legislation any of those fundamental amendments necessary to overcome this problem of economic utilisation of land in the Northern Territory.

Let us look at the facts. We have given more land to Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory than the United States has given to its tribes. We have given 200 per cent more than the Canadian Government has given to Indian tribes in Canada. On international standards, our record stands supreme. But we are failing because we have not given those people the economic incentives, the desire or the opportunities to enter into an arrangement by which ultimately they and their children can be the beneficiaries, along with the rest of the Australian people-the men and women who make up this nation and whose taxes-some $3.4 billion-have gone from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs since 1970 towards supporting the Aboriginal people. We want to see the Aboriginal people gain the opportunity and the respect of their peers. They want to be part of the Australian community--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate at the outset that we have heard from the shadow spokesman for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), the propositions of the mining industry and the grazing industry, but certainly nothing on behalf of the Aborigines of this country. Being a member who represents a considerable proportion of the Aboriginal community and the island people of this country, I must say that that comes as no surprise; but what is surprising is that in this range of conflicting interests that we have in this debate on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill this evening we have heard nothing more than the propositions of the mining and pastoral industries, and no-one else.

SPEECH.PARA: I diverge for one moment to look at the underprivileged people of this country amongst whom are the Aborigines. I wonder whether the Opposition has such a thing as an Aboriginal policy. If it exists, it is well guarded. Is it any wonder that when the Aboriginal spokespeople and representatives come to Canberra they spend very little time talking to the Opposition about Aboriginal matters? This Act has been the subject of one of the most-I suppose, the most-extensive processes of review and consultation. As Chairman of the Caucus Aboriginal Affairs Committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —And a very good one.

—Thank you very much. As Chairman of that Committee I wish to point out that that Committee has travelled the length and breadth of the Northern Territory. We have sat down and spoken to Aboriginal people.
—Why aren't you applying this legislation to every other State? You are a gutless worm.
— Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory will cease interjecting. He will have a chance to contribute later.
—He will join a very fine list of speakers--
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: The comments made by the honourable member for the Northern Territory were unparliamentary and I ask him to withdraw them.
—The unfortunate thing is that the Chair did not hear the remarks amid all the noise. I did not hear the words used by the honourable member.
—They were utterly offensive, I assure you.

—When there is a lot of noise in the chamber and the Chair has not heard the remark it is difficult for the Chair to ask the honourable member to repeat his unparliamentary words. This compounds the difficulty.
—He knows what he said and I assure you it was unparliamentary.

—The difficulty is that the Chair has to rule upon whether the words were unparliamentary. If the Minister wishes to raise a point of order he might draw my attention to the words that he considered unparliamentary.
—He referred to the honourable member for Leichhardt as a gutless worm.
—At least you can't apply a blow torch to his belly because he hasn't got one.
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory has used words which were probably unfortunate.
—They were offensive.

—The Chair decides whether they are offensive. I think they are unfortunate and it might help the debate if the honourable member for Leichhardt continued his speech and the honourable member for the Northern Territory ceased interjecting.

—Quite frankly, I do not listen too much to what the honourable member for the Northern Territory-or is it Brisbane?-says. Usually what he says is a total irrelevance. In 1983 the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) requested Mr Justice Toohey, a former Aboriginal Land Commissioner and now a prominent Federal Court judge, to review the 1976 Act. Seven years on, his report was presented in December 1983. Many of the amendments in this Bill flow directly from Mr Justice Toohey's proposals, and subsequently I will refer to some of those recommendations, particularly in relation to the mining industry. I have no doubt that we will hear from the honourable member for the Northern Territory in relation to his buddies in the mining industry. I do not know whether he ever had a retainer from them but I am sure he will be speaking in support of their interests.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1984 Dr Jon Altman undertook a review of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account. Some of his proposals are picked up in this Bill, others are being implemented in administrative changes and others are still under examination. Overlaying these processes of expert review has been a most careful and painstaking process of consultation with interested parties about possible changes to the Act. `Consultation' has been the key word of the amendments now before this House, contrary to what the shadow Minister may have said, and the Aboriginal people will know this. I speak very confidently in this regard; we have had an enormous consultation process with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You only talked to the Central Land Council.

—The honourable member would not even know where they come from. He is talking from the suburbs of Sydney and, quite frankly, I suppose that he has about three Aboriginals in his electorate and would not know who they were anyway. The process of consultation has been far-reaching. It was quite enlightening to realise, when getting around the Northern Territory and speaking to Aboriginals, that they did not even know who their Federal representative in this place was. May I place on record, as I have done in previous debates on Aboriginal matters, much to the disgust of a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Viner, what he said when Aboriginal land rights were granted in the Northern Territory:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's proposal to recognise Aboriginal land rights in legislation is one more expression of the Government's commitment to liberal and progressive reform-
the sorts of words we might not expect to hear from those present opposite. He further said:

. . . the Government believes that this Bill will allow and encourage Aboriginals in the Northern Territory to give full expression to the affinity with land that characterised their traditional society and gave a unique quality to their life.

Did we hear from the honourable member for Bradfield about the affinity with land? He does not understand it. He is quite out of touch with it. I think it is a sad reflection on the approach of those opposite in relation to Aboriginal matters. Mr Justice Toohey commented in his review that it would be a mistake to conclude from the number of amendments he recommended be made to the Act that it had substantial defects. Rather, to the contrary, his conclusion was that, given its legislative novelty and uniqueness and the need to marry complex notions of traditional Aboriginal law and culture with European institutions and administrative procedures, it had worked surprisingly well. It will continue to work surprisingly well and, with the fine tuning that comes with the amendments now before us, it will work even better.

There has been a considerable amount of criticism of the present mining regime in the Act. It has been claimed by the mining industry and by the Northern Territory Government, not surprisingly, that this regime has hindered exploration and mining on Aboriginal land. That is one side of the story. One particular aspect that has been criticised by these interests has been the so-called veto-the right of Aboriginal owners to refuse to allow exploration or mining on their land. I challenge anyone opposite who is going to speak on this Bill tonight to challenge what Mr Justice Toohey said about the right of veto. In his recommendations his position, his attitude, was clear. He said that the Aboriginals must retain that right to decide whether their lands be mined or not. I ask those opposite, if they want to fly in the face of such an unequivocal finding or recommendation of Mr Justice Toohey, to say so. Mr Justice Woodward, in the second report of the Aboriginal Land Rights Commission, said:
Of all the questions I have had to consider, that of mineral rights has probably caused me the most difficulty and concern.
That difficulty and concern remain. As part of the terms of reference Mr Justice Toohey had `Aboriginal control in relation to mining on Aboriginal land'. That is quite clear. Mr Justice Toohey said:

To the extent that the Land Rights Act gives effect to these principles, the review cannot recommend changes. There has been no suggestion to the contrary. It must be remembered, however, that although Aboriginal groups are given effective control over whether and on what terms mining takes place on their land, the right to and ownership of minerals remains with the Crown in right of the Commonwealth or the Crown in right of the Northern Territory as the case may be. The significance of the distinction between the control of mining and the ownership of minerals will be discussed when I consider negotiated mining agreements. . . .

This legislation now before this place comes here after the utmost of consultation. I do not have to beg this question. I can assure this place that the Aboriginal people are aware of this. They know to whom they have been able to speak in the last three years. They know that the only sympathetic ear to their causes is on this side of the House. Those opposite who represent unfortunately the interests of others to the exclusion of the interests of Aboriginal people will be condemned. It will not be we who condemns them; it will be the Aboriginal people, the indigenous people, of the Northern Territory. I would like to say in conclusion that the Caucus committee on Aborigines has worked tirelessly in this regard. It has enormous support.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has an excellent chairman, if I may say so.

—We will not go into the chairman. As I said at the outset, we travelled the length and breadth of the Northern Territory. It was suggested that we talked to only the Central Land Council, which goes to show how out of touch with this legislation the shadow Minister is. He is not only out of touch with this legislation but out of touch with all legislation relating to Aboriginals in this country. He is out of touch with the Aboriginals of this country and particularly out of touch with the Aboriginals of the Northern Territory. There are a number of amendments being considered and we have not heard anything of those from the shadow Minister. Obviously they will be raised at a later stage, but it is interesting to note that the predominance of them relates to the mining industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us be clear about one thing: We are not talking tonight about Aboriginal land rights for the whole of Australia. We are not talking about a national Aboriginal land rights Bill. We are not talking about land in Queensland, where the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) comes from and where he gets on his soap-box and spruiks so easily. We are not talking about land in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia or particularly Western Australia, or any other Labor Government State. We are talking about land in the Northern Territory exclusively, and I predict that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), as he has already tried to do, will attempt to gag me in this debate. The decisions which this Parliament makes on this Bill will not touch the electorates of any other member in this place but mine. It will not apply where you live, Mr Deputy Speaker. It will not affect your communities. The only people who will live with the consequences of this legislation on a day to day basis are Northern Territorians. All the rest of you, from my point of view, are nothing more than officious bystanders.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable members that no member of this Parliament-and especially so as every State has the power to look after land rights on a State by State basis-has been prepared to see land laws as they apply in the Northern Territory applied to their electorates. And where is the Australian Labor Party's national land rights legislation? No State Parliament in Australia has enacted the same laws. With that uppermost in mind, consider what has happened in the Northern Territory under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. It is clear that the intent of this Parliament has been distorted out of all proportion since the dignified and credible stand taken by the people of Yirrkala and Wattie Creek first brought the issue of Aboriginal land ownership to the notice of Australian people. What was a fine intention has, by the manner of its introduction and operation, generated racial tension in the Territory and created a canker which is now spreading throughout Australia. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has bemoaned this attitudinal change. The Government has called on the people of Australia to show greater tolerance, but it has only itself to blame for this state of affairs; although the Government seeks to lay the blame at the feet of others and it will perpetuate the problem with these amendments.

In the wake of the anti-Vietnam war movement, the noisy and permanently active group of people who thrive on anger and protest found themselves looking for the exhilaration of a new crusade. Unfortunately for Aborigines, they settled on land rights. This Minister was amongst those activists. He probably feels proud of that early involvement, but those people generated hate, emotion and national guilt to foster their new-found cause. That was not a climate in which to develop a sound and stable policy of social reform, because public support fanned by such emotionalism will be short-lived, will quickly burn out, and the political response will be hasty and ill-judged. That is exactly what happened when the Whitlam Government decided to exploit the political potential of this movement.

In 1972 the Australian Labor Party had been out of office for 23 years. Having been in opposition for so long, the urgency was such that there was no time to think clearly. Aboriginal land rights suffered from the syndrome of political impatience. Thus in February 1973 the Whitlam Government established the Aboriginal Land Rights Commission under Mr Justice Woodward to report particularly on the means to establish land rights in the Northern Territory. The Royal Commissioner was told by Prime Minister Whitlam that he `was not to be concerned with whether Aborigines should be granted rights in land, since the Government had already decided that they should. His task was simply to advise how such rights should be granted in the Northern Territory'. The Northern Territory was to be the sacrificial lamb. It was to be the repository of the national conscience.

Consultation was then the in thing, as consensus is today. Consultation continued ad nauseam with Aborigines, as it does today with the land council. As the honourable member for Leichhardt said, there has been extraordinary consultation, but only with land councils. The philosophy was that this was Aboriginal business. Others, despite their legitimate and genuine interest in the outcome, were virtually excluded from consultation. Thus was the first real antagonism to land rights born.

The Whitlam Government produced the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Bill, which the Fraser Government pushed through with only minor changes. This singling out of the Northern Territory by politicians who are not prepared to have their own electorates carry their share of this burden of imaginary national guilt was seen by most Territorians for what it was-sheer hypocrisy. Understandably, resentment and antagonism grew. It did not go unnoticed that, many years after Northern Territory land rights were in place, the Labor State of New South Wales had done nothing. When it finally did, it did next to nothing. South Australia enacted a form of land rights legislation, but it was limited in its application, avoided the claim process and preserved public purpose areas.

In February 1973 the Whitlam Government imposed, by way of ministerial direction, a freeze on the development of all unalienated Crown land in the Northern Territory. The processing of leases applied for had to cease and grazing licences on unalienated land in the process of being converted to a more secure tenure were frozen. Existing mineral exploration licences and mining leases on such land retained their status, but no new licences or tenements of any kind were allowed to be processed. The effects of these restrictions were so severe and unique as to make resource discovery and development in some of the most highly prospected parts of the Northern Territory virtually impossible. Just recently we have seen this Government going back on the undertakings given to miners, including Peko-Wallsend Ltd, by the then Minister in the former Labor Government.

Despite those events, the initial land grants under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act-just short of 20 per cent of the Territory-had broad acceptance from Territorians. But the provision allowing land claims to be made to unalienated land, sparking a massive land grab, confirmed the worst fears and provoked considerable antagonism. Areas such as all national parks, stock routes, stock quarantine reserves and other areas set aside for public purposes were claimed. Many claims were speculative, with no real attempt made to properly identify valid claimants. Land was claimed simply because it could be. This is to be given an effective imprimatur by this legislation, excusing the land councils from maintaining a register of traditional owners. Indeed, how do we have successful claims without traditional owners?

Grazing licences upon which marginal pastoral properties depended for their very existence were claimed. The viability of some station properties was seriously threatened as claims were laid to land areas held under grazing licences which the station owners had been encouraged by the Government to consider theirs by long occupation and usage. That is a brief summary of what has happened as a result of the land rights legislation in the Territory. Such is the nature of the legal, anthropological and sociological industry which descended on Territory Aboriginals, persuading them to claim every last square millimetre of unalienated land.

We should now consider what was intended by this Parliament and by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner, who made the recommendations around which the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act was framed. Mr Justice Woodward must have had some concern that such an outcome was possible, for he counselled Aboriginals in his report, stating:

. . . Aboriginal people should think carefully before laying claim to any areas which are not going to be of value to them-particularly since they have unimpeded access to this country at present if they want to visit it for any traditional purpose.
In 1979 the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Viner, wrote in the Northern Territory News:

. . . I have read and heard many alarming rumours . . . how (Aboriginals) are getting 50 per cent of the land and how afraid people are that their own land may be taken over. I want to put an end to these rumours because they are not only untrue, but dangerous to . . . future racial harmony . . . with so much of the land . . . being either desert or areas no longer having traditional occupants, it is expected that claims will be lodged . . . to another 10 per cent of the Northern Territory.

The Minister predicted that no more than 28 per cent of the Territory would be granted or claimed. But within two short years of the Act the figure had reached almost 47 per cent and now stands at more than 50 per cent. This situation has forced the Territory Government into a role it does not wish, but which it has a duty to perform in the public interest, of protecting the public interest in the complex, costly and tedious land claims process that goes on. This onerous responsibility was forced upon the Northern Territory Government by a Commonwealth that has consistently evaded its duty to clean up the mess. Someone had to represent the general interest as the implications of land claims strangling the rapidly growing towns of Darwin, Alice Springs, Katherine and Tennant Creek became apparent. All other towns in the Northern Territory are already strangled.

During the hearing of a claim for a large area of land, including Uluru National Park and the future Yulara tourist village, the Northern Territory Government was bound to try to preserve the rights of all Australians to those areas. The division between the Territory Government and land councils was driven by Commonwealth inaction. This Minister and this Government have used every chance to widen that gap further by portraying the Territory Government as anti-Aboriginal.

The Northern Territory Government was given no credit for the land it provided, of its own volition, to Aboriginals in town areas-for instance, 30 per cent of the town area of Alice Springs-and in the Sir Edward Pellew group of islands; for its efforts to arrange living areas on pastoral properties, in contrast to the complete lack of action in this regard in other States; or for the arrangement for joint Northern Territory Government-Aboriginal control of, for instance, the Cobourg Peninsula National Park.

The Territory could have been spared the antagonism, the Territory Government could have been spared the adversary role and the racists on both sides could not have exploited this situation if a few simple amendments had been made to the Act. In summary those amendments should encompass the following principles: That the land claim process should not be infinite; that the rights of all Australians to public purpose land should be preserved; that the Territory's elected Government's ability to provide essential services is not inhibited; and that the importance to the Territory and Australia of economic resources-minerals, pastoral land, tourism potential and residential land-are recognised and provided for. That is the broad framework essential to deal with the problems that have come about as a result of the original Act.

I now turn to the specifics of this Bill. It is clear that this Bill addresses most of those problems not at all, and some only in a superficial way. Worse, it threatens to exacerbate difficulties and tensions. The Minister, of course, is very aware of these problems and what they mean to Territorians. So much so that he made a clandestine one-day trip to Darwin to hand over title to 400 square kilometres of Kakadu-the same piece of land that a Federal Court of Australia judge told the Minister to reconsider, taking into account other interests.

The Minister will deny that the trip was clandestine. He will say that he issued a Press release, but what does it say? It explains that Bill Neiji has pneumonia and that this can be `a serious condition for a man of his age' and that the Minister's decision is `not related in any way' to the Government's decisions on mining in Kakadu stages 1 and 2. What hypocrisy. This Minister has treated the Federal Court with contempt, giving the other interested parties-the Territory Government and Geopeko-just seven days to put their case. He probably did not even bother to read those submissions. In the time frame, it is difficult to see how he could have. The 400 square kilometres contains 100 mining lease applications, including probably the richest of Peko-Wallsend's leases. The Minister says that this is not related in any way to Government decisions on mining in Kakadu. What rot!

I quote from a letter to the Northern Territory News of only last Monday, 17 November, which may help members to understand why land rights legislation as it now stands causes dispute and division, even among Aboriginals. The letter is the latest in a saga of dispute that has surrounded a single claim area south-west of Darwin. It states:

The Wagait decision on traditional ownership is unjust and a disgrace to the Northern Land Council and Clyde Holding, the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs . . . The full blood people have every right to . . . seek a fair decision in accordance with Australia's Land Rights Act . . . For the Northern Land Council to have this opposition from the very people they are supposed to be advancing points to the fact their decisions are not as knowledgeable as we are led to believe, or the Aborigines are not as involved as they should be in the decision making process . . . At Lake Bennett . . . two years ago . . . Wagait was discussed and finally all the full bloods were asked to go and sit down together and come to a decision. They agreed the Marrananggu people were the rightful owners . . . The NLC did not accept this decision.

I do not pretend to know the answer to this dispute, but it is by no means an isolated one, and anyone in this House who thinks that the claims process is finally settled, even after the years of hearings, should think again.

There is widespread dissatisfaction amongst Aboriginal and amongst traditional owners with the present land council setup. They feel that the land councils are too big and too busy with their own particular concerns, such as lobbying and registering their message with the Australian Labor Party Caucus, to look after the interests of traditional owners. There is no doubt in my mind that the councils should be split to care for the interests of smaller numbers and the tenure of smaller areas.

But this Bill gives the existing land councils greater powers, no doubt at the behest of the land councils. It makes no attempt to address the question of proper representation and the complaints registered by traditional owners. Under this legislation they have no avenue of complaint, no rights of redress if they feel misrepresented by the absolute power of the land council. At least like other Australians they should be able to seek redress from the Ombudsman. Further, the Bill removes the fundamental raison d'etre of the land councils-the obligation to maintain a register of traditional owners. This Government must intend bureaucratic structures which are not obliged even to keep a list of who they represent-the very people to whom they are answerable. Indeed how are they to have elections? Who is to decide who may vote? There is more dirty work at the crossroads.

I understand that the registers that were supposed to be maintained are a shambles-presumably this is why the Minister has been persuaded to put in this clause. A better option would be to disband the councils for failing to carry out their primary task. I cannot believe the Government can be so thickheaded on this matter. It should be an absolute basic requisite for a council entrusted with the task of consultation with traditional owners on matters such as mining to maintain a register of those people. This is the very crux of the land council's responsibilities.

This Bill demands the incorporation of Ab- original organisations under Commonwealth law receiving money disbursed from a land council, but this clearly should be entirely a Territory responsibility. It will mean different arrangements for different organisations, duplicate incorporation and added complexity. If the Territory Government has declined or disavowed this responsibility, I simply cannot understand it. The further demand for incorporated communities or groups to lodge financial records with land councils is nothing short of a power grab for greater centralised power, greater control by councils, when the move should be in the opposite direction-a move for a black government.

This legislation will now extend the land councils' tentacles into the area of sacred sites. There is already more than adequate Northern Territory legislation on sacred sites-in fact some would say armour-clad legislation-for setting up a sacred sites protection authority, and, for good measure, Commonwealth legislation as well. The cut-off date for claims-set 10 years from now-means that there will have been 20 years in total since the Act was introduced for claims to be made. There is every reason to end this divisive and petty exercise. This Bill should end the land grab now.

The Bill is ambivalent on the vital matter of stock routes and reserves. Claims are still possible and the Minister will use his powers as a big stick. It should be unequivocal that such areas, and public purpose lands in total, are beyond the land claims process and, of course, national parks and all other public land. But this Government has already given away Ayers Rock and more of Kakadu. I mentioned earlier the disastrous effects on the Territory economy of the land freeze imposed by the Whitlam Government in 1973 and extended for more than a decade. This Bill imposes a new freeze on the status of all land under claim. Yet we know that the claims process will take at least another 10 years-more based on present progress. I suppose it will give the Northern Territory a statutory reason for more claims on the Com- monwealth Grants Commission.

Lastly, I note with considerable apprehension the clause which enables a Commissioner to be appointed from the Federal Court of Australia, instead of a justice from the Northern Territory Supreme Court. This is a transparent ploy, designed to allow the Commonwealth to dodge its responsibility to obtain the agreement of the Territory to such appointments. In summary, this is a Bill designed to thwart the legitimate interest of the elected Territory Government, to increase the power of the land councils and to increase the stranglehold of the Commonwealth. It fails to respond to any of the vital issues of racial disharmony, of administrative anomaly, of-to use a current phrase-the unintended consequences of the original land rights Act.

I have raised these problems today and I have raised them before as a Chief Minister. They have been stated and restated by the Territory Government, by the elected representatives in this House and elsewhere. There is a perfectly good private members Bill before the Senate which addresses exactly those problems. According to assurances given to the Territory Government this is the first of two amending Bills. I doubt whether we will ever see the second Bill. The Government has not got the moral courage to do what has to be done and this Bill is evidence of that fact. The Government should dare not make the charge of racism against people in the Territory. It has had the opportunity to remove the antagonism, to finish the divisiveness, and it has not got the stomach for it. The buck stops on the Minister's desk and everyone who must live with his failure of nerve-that means every Territorian, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal-knows it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual we heard a speech from the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) which would have been better delivered in cuckoo land. It is a speech which deserves to be treated with contempt, and I treat it with contempt.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to support the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986. There have been few Bills in the history of the Australian Parliament which have been subjected to such close scrutiny as the Bill before the House. Unlike the Opposition which has had little consultation with Aborigines, as my colleague the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) said earlier, the Government has had extensive consultations with mining interests, pastoralists, the Northern Territory Government and, more importantly, with land councils representing the Aboriginals of the Northern Territory.

At the outset I would like to pay a tribute to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) for his patience and willingness to negotiate with all parties. He has not had an easy role in what is, as every member of this House knows, a difficult portfolio. The Government Caucus Aboriginal Affairs Committee played an important role in assisting in the final determination of this Bill. It, too, was involved in meeting and discussing relevant issues with the various parties concerned. The importance of its role can be gauged from the fact that it was not too long ago that the right of Aboriginal land owners to refuse consent to exploration was under threat as a result of a Cabinet decision. This threat to the right of veto unleashed a bitter reaction from Aboriginals not only in the Northern Territory but from all over Australia and was supported largely by church and community groups. The Caucus Committee, which had a basic sympathy to these cries for help, immediately set about to assist in redressing the situation. It was able to do this after extensive and delicate negotiations with the parties to the dispute. Now we have an amendment Bill in which the right of Aboriginal land owners to refuse consent to exploration on their land has been retained. Yet it does not prevent Aboriginal land owners, who do not object to exploration and subsequent mining on their land, from negotiating terms and conditions for such mining.

This Bill has had its genesis in 1983 when the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs requested Mr Justice Toohey, a former Aboriginal Land Commissioner and now a prominent Federal Court judge, to review the Act. His report, `Seven Years On', was presented in December 1983. Many of the amendments in this Bill flow directly from Mr Justice Toohey's proposals. A review by Dr Jon Altman of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account was completed in 1984 and some of its proposals have been included in this Bill. Others are being implemented by administrative means, whilst others are still under examination.

The Minister, in his second reading speech, pointed out that, whilst good progress has been made on a number of points, there still remained some contentious aspects on which there were sharp divergences of views. Consequently, the Government has decided that there is a need for more time for these issues to be analysed and discussed. These issues will again be subject to further discussion in the new year. The main issues being deferred are those dealing with exploration and mining of Aboriginal lands; the granting of an estate or interest in Aboriginal land to the Northern Territory for essential services; methods of calculating payments of royalty equivalents to the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account; and the removal from claim of pastoral properties owned by Aboriginals and of public purpose land.

No doubt, the mining industry and the Northern Territory Government will argue that this Bill is a sellout to Aboriginals. They have argued that the present Act has hindered exploration and mining on Aboriginal land, particularly through the right of veto. This is a false argument and one that gives little credit to the mining industry. It ignores the fact that there have been a number of factors working to inhibit exploration and mining in the Territory. As we all know, these include the generally depressed state, worldwide, of the minerals industry as well as the moratorium which existed for a number of years on the issue of new exploration licences.
I remind the House that Mr Justice Woodward, in his second report in 1974 on land rights in the Northern Territory, said:
I believe that to deny to Aborigines the right to prevent mining on their land is to deny the reality of their land rights.

Are we, as a parliament, to deny that reality? It is now 10 years since the passing of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.
