This saw the establishment of land councils to act as the representatives of Aboriginal people in relation to Aboriginal land or land which may be subject of a land claim by traditional owners. In that time the land councils have developed an expertise which has served them well in the interests of Aboriginal people. In my dealings with the land councils as a member of the Caucus Aboriginal Affairs Committee and as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, I have found them to be co-operative and prepared to listen to an alternative point of view, although strong in presenting their own point of view. If I had to offer a criticism of the land councils-I have stated this criticism to individual members of the land councils-it is that I would like to see greater Aboriginal involvement in the working role of the councils. In time I am sure that that will be overcome and we will find that the non-Aboriginal advisers and experts employed by the councils will be replaced by Aboriginals. As Mr Justice Toohey commented in his report `Seven Years On', land councils have experienced growing pains associated with organisations of any size. The proposed amendments contained in this Bill seek to cover a number of areas where revised powers and functions for land councils have been deemed necessary to assist in alleviating these growing pains.

At the moment land councils cannot enter binding agreements with anyone seeking an interest in land until the land actually becomes Aboriginal land. The amendments will empower the land councils to negotiate and conclude agreements with people who seek an interest in land under claim. The power to enter into these agreements will assist in the resolution of issues of detriment prior to land being the subject of a grant. Clause 8 of the Bill also allows for agreements entered into by land councils to be binding on land trusts which are subsequently set up to hold that land when a grant is made. Mr Justice Toohey, on page 25 of his report, explained the necessity for this amendment by citing a case in the Daly River area. He stated:

. . . landholders in the vicinity of the river draw water essential for domestic purposes across narrow strips of Crown reserve land. They also traverse that land to use the river for recreational and transport purposes. If, as recommended, that land becomes Aboriginal land, each landholder will have to negotiate an agreement for access to the river and the right to carry water across the land.

Counsel for the claimants in that claim made it clear that they did not wish to deny others these rights . . . However the Act does not provide a means whereby an enforceable undertaking in these terms could be given. In such circumstances, where an undertaking can be given or an agreement made in precise terms, the Act should empower the Land Councils to so act. This would assist the Commissioner in formulating both his comments on detriment and his recommendation, and would assist the Minister in deciding whether to recommend to the Governor-General that a grant, conditional or otherwise, be made.

I do not want to itemise the other amendments to the Bill. It is sufficient to say that there are similar substantial reasons for their inclusion in this Bill. I would like to conclude with a statement made in 1977 by former Senator Neville Bonner who is the only Aboriginal to have ever been elected to Federal Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —From our side of the House too, you might add.

—I ask the honourable member to listen. He served his Party in a distinguished way whilst a member of the other House. I am sure that honourable members on both sides of the House would agree with that. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is no comprehension among whites that Aborigines have been forced to leap from primitive culture to modern society in less than 200 years. Aboriginal people feel like strangers in their own land, like refugees. They have been dispossessed.
This Bill helps the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory to take those necessary steps and will make them feel less like strangers in their own land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has arrived. It always amazes me to see how much concern the Government shows in Aboriginal affairs when legislation such as that which is before us is listed to be debated on a Wednesday which is a non-broadcast day. One wonders what the Government is trying to hide from the people of Australia, in particular, the Aboriginal people. It is known around this place that, if there are Bills that the Government really does not want people to take an interest in, they are listed to be debated on a Wednesday when the proceedings of this House are not broadcast and when people throughout Australia cannot hear what is going on. I am pleased that the Minister has returned to the House because, for the last 20 minutes, there has not been any Minister sitting at the table.
—That's not true.

—It is true. The Minister has just come in. The chair has been vacant for the last 10 minutes. We are opposed to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill that we are debating because we believe that the amendments that are being put to the House tonight do not go far enough. The legislation was initially set up by the Whitlam Government in 1973. Mr Justice Woodward was asked to report to the Parliament. Two reports were brought forward in 1973 and 1974. At that time it was the Fraser Government, led by that very prominent person of today--
—Eminent.

—He is prominent and eminent and he introduced this legislation. Of course, we now know the disastrous consequences of the land rights legislation of the Northern Territory. I believe one of the best things that this socialist Government has done since it came to office has been not to transgress across the width of Australia with its national land rights policy, which was something it intended to do. The National Party in Queensland has been to the fore in the fight and the opposition to this absurd and ridiculous set of circumstances spreading across Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been a member of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs since I was elected to Parliament and I take a very close interest in Aboriginal affairs because I represent many Aborigines in my electorate of Maranoa. But I do not think any fair-minded Australian who, having travelled with us in the Northern Territory in particular, would not say that the situation there is a disaster. It is high time that we stopped this nonsense of kowtowing to these people and trying to kid ourselves that we help them by continuing to grant more and more land to them. Only a few people can have the land anyway as most Aborigines live in cities today. They do not live on large parcels of land. Even if they could all have a bit, there would not be enough to go around. I always use the expression that there are only 170,000 farms in the whole of Australia and there are meant to be about 300,000 Aborigines, so I do not know how we could ever give them all a piece of land. It is quite obvious that they all cannot have it; only a few get it. It is high time that we stopped the nonsense and caught up with some of the facilities that are needed. It is a shocking state of affairs.

One would think that an atomic bomb had hit the Alice Springs area. The kids are not being educated. We have set up these so-called free schools. The whole area is rife with petrol sniffing. I have mentioned that problem to the Minister previously in this place. Of all the States in Australia, the Northern Territory, together with the northern part of South Australia, has the worst problems. The Northern Territory and the northern part of South Australia are tied into the same sort of land movement. The South Australian Labor Government has given huge tracts of land to the Aborigines, turned its back on them and said that all of their problems are solved because they have this land. The Aborigines have always had the land. All that has been done is that the title on a piece of paper has been changed. It has never been any different. Arnhem Land is one of the biggest tracts of land in Australia that has been set aside for Aborigines. It is about 10 times bigger than Tasmania. The Aborigines still have it. The only thing that has been done is that the title has been changed. But we are not following up this ridiculous nonsense with some facilities.

We think we are helping them but their whole social system has broken down. There is no control or discipline on any of the reserves, and we have been to many. On our last few trips we have been to the southern part of the Northern Territory, the Alice Springs and Ayers Rock areas and the northern part of South Australia looking at the outstation movement, which is a separate thing again from the land claim issue. I believe it is high time that we stopped giving more and more land and resources away. We do not have the resources. The nation is bankrupt. We cannot afford the sort of money that people are demanding. We are not prepared even to allow mining in some of these areas. We have reached the absurd position of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wandering up to Kakadu and making pronouncements about not mining. As the Chairman of the Aboriginal Affairs Committee has just said, if anyone sits down on the ground and talks to these people, he soon finds out that they want to mine the land that they have. Why should they not? They are not strange, different or Stone Age people. Most Aborigines do wish to mine on their land. Having received a freehold land grant, why would they not want to exploit the resources that they have? Why would they not want to farm it, mine it or do something with it? There is very little that they can do with it other than mine it. Much of that country cannot be grazed. They have to make a living somehow or other. For God's sake, we cannot have them on the dole ad infinitum. But that is the situation that we have set up-a 100 per cent 1,000-year social security setup. These people will never have any form of income of self-respect. Aborigines are no different from us. We like to earn an honest income. We do not wish to be on the dole. No one wishes to be out of work. The Aborigines are no different. It is high time that we stopped this nonsense.

Fortunately, Queensland has not gone along with the national land rights legislation. It has offered the Aborigines deeds-in-grant which I believe are proving very successful. If people care to travel around Australia and visit all the States, they will find that Queensland is as far advanced in helping Aborigines as any of the other States. It is certainly further advanced than the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Joh is right.

—I am not saying that Joh is not right a lot of the time. He is not necessarily right all the time, but he was certainly right on the national land rights issue. There are not too many things these days in Australia on which Joh is not right. He was certainly right about the election result only a few weeks ago. We buried the Australian Labor Party in Queensland. The ALP was down three per cent on its vote. We absolutely buried them. It was a disgusting performance by the ALP. We will bury those blokes at the next election. I cannot wait for the Special Minister of State (Mr Young)--
—Order!
—Every day in the House he tries to tell us what date the election might be.
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will return to the Bill.
—I cannot wait until he tells me the date of the election so that we can bury this Government--
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will resume his seat. The Chair is prepared to give the honourable member a considerable degree of latitude but I ask him to be relevant to the Bill.

—As we know, this is an important Bill. Unfortunately, it is a tragedy that we even have to debate such a Bill. I have never supported the concept of the so-called land rights legislation in the Northern Territory, but it is something that we seem to be stuck with these days. Some people want excisions from pastoral holdings. Personally, I am opposed to that.
—I bet you are.

—Of course I am. In the long term, all we are doing is setting up segregated enclaves on pastoral properties where we have to continue to maintain all the facilities, et cetera. I have always said that I cannot see why governments cannot help the pastoralists. If we are so keen about their supplying all these facilities--
—We do.

—What is the point in setting up these separate enclaves? We do not do it for white people who are established on stations. We do not go to white people working on stations and say: `Here you are, fellas. There are 20 or 30 ringers on this place. We will give you an excision from this station.' But if there are Aborigines, we say: `Oh, well, you guys need an excision here. You want a cow paddock. You want to run 100 head of cattle. You have to support yourself so here is half the cattle station'. That is the sort of situation we have reached. The Minister has threatened station owners and station managers in the Northern Territory and demanded excisions from their pastoral holdings. It is a ridiculous situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I worked for many years in the Northern Territory and I can assure honourable members from my experience that these things will do no good to the Aboriginal people in the long run. It is ridiculous that we set up these enclaves. Stations cannot afford to employ Aboriginal people any more because of the high wage structure that we have imposed. It is impossible for them to employ these people and most of them have been laid off. I do not believe it is fair to encourage Aborigines to remain on the stations where there is no work available. That is what is happening.

Of course, there are other problems for Aboriginal people. We have the absurd situation that the head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has now been given money to write a book. We heard about the head of the Australian War Memorial writing books but now we have Mr Perkins--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member is again transgressing your ruling. He is not debating the Bill. He is just casting aspersions on the Minister.
—Once again I ask the honourable member to remain relevant to the Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am doing my best. I believe the Bill deals with Aborigines; it says something about them. I do have a number of Aborigines in Maranoa. It happens to be a fairly isolated part of Australia where Aboriginal people still seem to reside. It is my responsibility to look after their interests in this House. All I am saying is that I have had a letter from Mrs McKellar, a resident of Cunnamulla, complaining that she cannot get any funding to help preserve some of the history of her own area, of the Aboriginal people, and yet the head of the Minister's Department, Mr Perkins, can get all the funds he needs to write books about himself and glorify his own existence.
—That is just not true.
—It is true. That is what he is doing.
—It is not true.
—The Minister can tell me in his reply what Mr Perkins is doing.
—He receives no money at all.
—The intention is that he gets some money. Is that right?
—It is quite wrong.
—We will see about that.
—Ask me a question tomorrow.
—I might do that. As I understand it, some thousands of dollars are being set aside for Mr Perkins to start compiling his own epitaph.
—You are wrong.

—I wonder about that. We will see what the Minister says tomorrow about these things. He might even have the courtesy to reply to my speech on these matters when he closes the debate. I can assure the House that some weird and wonderful things continue to go on in his Department. We saw what happened previously. That is one of the best things the Australian Labor Party has done. Sugar Ray Robinson was my representative, and I continually get complaints. He was one of the leaders of the bush; he was one of the reasons why the Minister was forced to close it down. Sugar Ray is a part Aborigine. He lives at Charleville and he was doing all sorts of weird and wonderful things. The latest thing is that Sugar Ray has brought himself a racehorse stud. He has money, and I get complaints from all my Aboriginal people about where the funding from the Minister's Department is going. Sugar Ray Robinson, who was on the Northern Land Council, now has himself a racehorse stud. He loves horses, because every time I go to the races in Charleville, who should be there but Sugar. He is there placing a few bets.
—What are you doing there?

—I am placing a few bets, too, but he wins more than I do. Unfortunately we have seen the Prime Minister up there acting like his own hypocritical self, pontificating about what we should and should not be doing. Meanwhile down here, in the centre of things, the country is going bankrupt. We are posting our biggest balance of payments deficit ever. Yet the Prime Minister is up there trying to tell the rest of Australia that we should not be mining in national parks. We already mine in national parks. There are three uranium mines in parks right now. The companies have made a good job of those; we have all been there and looked at them. Are they falling into great holes in the ground? Are Aborigines falling out of the trees with some strange disease? No, they are not. They have some employment and a bit of dignity. A few jobs are available. There are miners there so these guys have a bit of work to do.
—And they are getting the royalties, too.
—We realise that.
—You don't like that, do you?

—I do not mind letting them have the royalties as long as we all get them on an equal footing. I have always argued that. Some of the changes in this legislation deal with royalties. Around $80m has been paid to Aborigines. One of the worst features of this royalties setup is that they are paid to the Aborigines but the Aborigines are not means tested and they continue to draw social security benefits. Some of them up there are quite wealthy individuals. Again there are only a few; only a few can benefit. Some of them are wealthy and there should be a system whereby there is a bit of justice in the community in the way these things are administered. If an Aboriginal trust is getting millions of dollars and is redistributing that back to its own people and those people happen to have more money in their pockets than is allowed when claiming the dole, they ought not get the dole. They are not being means tested, the money is in trust and everyone seems to turn a blind eye to it. Whilst the Minister has introduced these changes I hope he will look at these problems and make sure that the people to whom this money is distributed are being means tested the same as any other Australians. There is a lot of animosity up there in the Northern Territory amongst the Aborigines themselves about those people who are getting these funds and those who are missing out. That is one of the main reasons why they would like to see a bit of mining. When we are able these days, with all the advancements we have made in mining, to put country back and rehabilitate it after it has been used, I do not know why we cannot go into these areas and mine them and use some of the funds earned to help these people even more. Then we can put the land back. In lots of cases the land ends up better than it was when the mining started. I could show honourable members areas on Fraser Island, for instance, over which there was great controversy. Malcolm Fraser stopped the export of mineral sands and mining on Fraser Island. The areas that have been mined are now in a better state than some other areas. They have much more coverage on them; the sand itself is more protected than it ever was. Australia is not in a position to have the luxury of locking up huge areas of land away from mining and away from some useful purpose. We have a trade imbalance of $2 billion a quarter. We are running a $20 billion deficit, which is beyond the pale. We say to these people in the Northern Territory that we are not going to mine, yet they come to us cap in hand expecting us to give millions of dollars in handouts. We are spending something like $400m a year on the few Aborigines we have in Australia.
—You said there were 300,000.

—That is not a lot of people. There are 16 million people in Australia, and of those 16 million people there are roughly 70,000 full bloods and the rest of the so-called Aborigines have a mixture of all sorts of blood in them. There are very few pure-bred Aborigines left. Most of them are in Queensland, the Northern Territory, the northern part of Western Australia and Central Australia. There are none in Victoria, and I will bet that there are none in the honourable member's electorate.
—There are four.

—I doubt even that. I believe one of the worst aspects of the amendments is the fact that the period for claim will remain at 10 years. As I said earlier, I believe it is time we stopped this nonsense of handing out land higgledy piggledy to these people and caught up with some of the deplorable situations so that those who have been given land can at least catch up with their education, their health and policing et cetera, in some these areas. It is my pleasure to oppose the extension of this socialistic Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill. Before dealing with some of the specifics of the amending legislation I would like to address two issues: Firstly, the consultative process that has accompanied the drafting of the Bill and, secondly, the opposition to Aboriginal rights that is a prominent feature of the campaign of the New Right and their servants on the Opposition benches. My colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has, in conjunction with the Caucus committee on Aboriginal affairs, chaired by the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), spent many hours in deliberation discussing and modifying the amending Bill since the Government's intention to review the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 was first announced in March of this year. This consultation process has been developed by the Minister and the committee since the Government's re-election in 1984. The committee invited representation from Aboriginal individuals and groups, as well as others with an interest or involvement in the issues concerned with the policy deliberations of the committee. This ensured that policy decisions were not made in a political vacuum but instead in a context of informed debate, the purpose of which was to find the most appropriate means to satisfy the needs and aspirations of Aboriginal Australians. This was of paramount concern to the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Caucus committee, in its role of advising the Minister and Cabinet, has received representations from the Northern Territory land councils representing the interests of those on whom the Bill has the most immediate impact-the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory. We have also heard at length the views of the Northern Territory Government and mining and pastoral interests. They sought amendments to weaken the present Act and to diminish the rights of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. Not surprisingly, the Government, through the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the committee, has also received numerous representations from a diverse range of groups supporting the position of the land councils whose diligence and professionalism in representing Aboriginal interests in this matter have been outstanding. The diversity of the groups and individuals who made representations in support of the Aboriginal position reflects the wide range of support that exists for land rights in the general community.

All major trade unions, branches of the Australian Labor Party, a range of community groups, indigenous nations and organisations in the Pacific, and the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia have all strongly expressed a demand that we uphold and defend existing rights. Church groups representing all major denominations at the highest level highlighted the obligation of government in Australia to ensure that demands of Aboriginal people for justice and the recognition of their rights to land, as the indigenous owners of Australia, are achieved before this nation celebrates its Bicentenary in 1988. Aboriginal organisations from every State supported the land councils' tireless representations to our committee. The committee's concern to listen to all views has meant that its deliberations have been almost without precedent in working out the details of the Bill before the House.
Foremost in our minds during these deliberations were the words of Mr Justice Woodward who, in the report of the Aboriginal Land Rights Commission in 1973, asserted:
The lesson of history is that any privileges which Aborigines have sought should not lightly be put aside or reduced.

We have been extremely conscious of the significance of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 which the Bill before the House will amend. Of course, the Northern Territory Government and its sponsors and supporters from the New Right, particularly from the mining industry, have sought at every opportunity to deny Aboriginal people their rights and, in the Northern Territory, to turn back the clock to the ruthless and untrammelled dispossession of Aboriginal people which preceded the introduction of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act in 1976.

At the forefront of this campaign is the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) whose public outbursts against Aboriginal people have been disgracefully opportunistic and racist. He has undertaken, both in his former position as Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and now, unfortunately, as the Federal member for that electorate, a campaign of vilification against the justice of the Act. The remorseless campaign of which the honourable member for the Northern Territory has been--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The honourable member used the expression `racist' against a member of this House. That is unparliamentary, and it should be withdrawn.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw that remark.

—In view of the time available, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will withdraw it. The remorseless campaign in which the honourable member for the Northern Territory has been a key player has been directed at dividing the Australian community, seeking to make race, Aboriginal rights, and land rights in particular, contentious political issues out of which he has sought political advantage. In fact, this man who masquerades as representing the interests of the Northern Territory electorate, of which almost one-third of the people are Aboriginal, when referring in June this year to the Bicentenary, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If there hadn't been a 1788 Aboriginal people would still be bashing their daughters skulls out on rocks when they decided they didn't want their daughters.

What could be said about such a statement, other than that one assumes he would argue that Aboriginal people should be thankful for the genocide that they have suffered as a result of the non-Aboriginal invasion of this land?

Let it be made quite clear to those opposite and to the reactionary ideologues of the New Right that this Government and the Labor Party will not be threatened or blackmailed into taking away or diminishing the rights of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. It is this Labor Government's intention to ensure that Aboriginal people throughout Australia have land rights appropriate to their needs and aspirations. It is a matter of record that at this year's biennial conference the ALP, once again, unanimously reaffirmed this objective of land rights for Aboriginal Australians. We will not resile from this commitment. The time has come for all non-Aboriginal Australians to face up to the injustice of Aboriginal dispossession and the continuum of colonial oppression that has been the hallmark of this nation's history since 1788. It is time this nation grew up.

Let there be no doubt that the troglodytes who sit opposite would de-gut the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act at the earliest opportunity. The philosophical gurus, the acolytes of reaction and exploitation, who determine the political agenda of the Opposition have as their basic objective profit maximisation regardless of the social and environmental costs and have no interest in justice and equity. This is the South African recipe for profit and success. It is in our national interest to recognise Aboriginal rights, as it is inevitable that eventually international attention will focus on the Australian maltreatment of its indigenous population. We should be proud to have proper indigenous rights at the forefront of our nation's values. It is also inevitable that, unless we as a nation act to meet Aboriginal demands for justice, we will be subject to the derision of the international community, at great cost to this country politically, socially and economically.

The provisions of the Bill before the House are derived largely from the recommendations of Mr Justice Toohey, a former land commissioner who undertook, at the request of the first Hawke Government, a review of some aspects of the land rights Act. This Bill reflects in large part his recommendations. In considering the Bill, the Government has sought to extend the powers of the land councils, particularly as they relate to the protection of sacred sites as well as the ability of Aboriginal people to become involved in commercial enterprises. It is the Government's view that everything possible should be done to promote the involvement of Aboriginal people in the wider economy, where they desire it. This is especially so in relation to commercial developments on Aboriginal land.

For this reason the Bill empowers land councils to assist actively Aboriginal people in their respective areas to carry out commercial activities, including resource developments, the provision of tourist facilities and agricultural activities. Indeed, the Minister has indicated to representatives of the land councils that he is keen for the land councils, where appropriate, to participate in commercial activities on a trustee basis for their constituents. Of course, the land councils are statutory bodies and, as such, must account to the Parliament for their finances through the provision of annual reports under section 37a. In addition, the Act empowers the Minister to audit the accounts and records of a land council at any time. That is covered in section 36. I make the point that the record shows that the land councils have, on the whole, been scrupulous in the administration of their financial affairs.

Another significant aspect of the Bill is the amendment which will prevent the alienation of land under claim. The effect of this will be to prevent a malevolent Northern Territory Administration from seeking to stop land being claimed by arbitrary alienation. Previously the Northern Territory Administration has, under the Chief Ministership of the current member for the Northern Territory, attempted to deny the right of Aboriginal people to claim land by arbitrary alienations such as the extension of the Darwin, Katherine and Tennant Creek town boundaries. In an attempt to frustrate the Kenbi land claim, Mr Paul Everingham, as Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, on 29 December 1978 extended the town boundaries of Darwin so that the area of Darwin was larger than that of Greater London, increasing the area from 142 square kilometres to 4,350 square kilometres. Needless to say, the issue has been taken to the High Court of Australia on more than one occasion. To date the judgments have been in favour of Aboriginal people, although I understand the question has yet to be finally resolved. The Northern Territory has done everything in its power to frustrate and prevent the legitimate claims of Aboriginal people to their land, taking litigation to the High Court on 13 occasions.

Another example which is still before the courts, as a result of provocative alienations of land under claim by the Northern Territory Administration while the current member for the Northern Territory was Chief Minister, is the Warumungu land claim around Tennant Creek. In this case the Northern Territory alienated nine of the eleven areas under claim on 29 October 1982, just three days before the hearing of the claim commenced on 1 November 1982. The Land Commissioner was not informed until 3 November 1982. Of course, this matter, too, has been, and continues to be, litigated. Judgment on various issues has been given in the claimant's favour once in the High Court and once in the Federal Court of Australia. There are still cases awaiting judgment, one in the Federal Court and one in the High Court. Only on one occasion has this ploy been successful, and then only on a minor point of law.

So we have had enough of people on the other side of the House talking about their parties' commitment to Aboriginal people. By pursuing litigation the Northern Territory Government has succeeded in wasting massive amounts of taxpayers' money with its only objective being to deny Aboriginal people justice. Of course, such action is discriminatory and has been taken solely to deny Aboriginal people their rights to claim land. For this, the honourable member for the Northern Territory is largely responsible. While preventing the alienation of land under claim the Bill provides for land councils to enter into agreements concerning such land. This will allow a person or a body, such as the Northern Territory Government, that desires to obtain an estate or an interest in land which is the subject of a traditional land claim to negotiate with the land council before the land claim is determined. Of course, the land councils must be satisfied that the Aboriginal people consent to such an agreement. This will enable land councils to agree that, if the land becomes Aboriginal land, they will direct the relevant land trust to grant an estate of interest, including a licence, in the land to the person or body with whom the agreement was reached. The effect of this process will be to limit disputes over detriment to the time when the land claims are being heard. With regard to the question of sacred sites protection, which has been mentioned by two previous speakers from the other side of the House, the Bill provides land councils with a role in protecting sacred sites both on and off Aboriginal land, recognising the primary role that the land councils play in sacred sites protection.

While the Bill is far from perfect in overall terms, it is a significant improvement on the existing Act. One area in which the Government may yet be forced to legislate concerns the provision of excisions or living areas for those Aboriginal people dispossessed by the pastoral industry. This is one group whose needs have not been addressed by these current amendments. However, the Minister has given his assurance to the Caucus committee, the land councils, the Northern Territory Government and the pastoralists that, should Aboriginal needs for adequate and appropriate excisions not be met by the agreed process, he will use his powers to acquire compulsorily the land to meet these needs. The Minister has also made it plain that, in the case of existing claims over identified stock routes and reserves, if after discussions between the Northern Territory Government and the land councils the needs of these people are not satisfied, claims over these areas will be able to proceed. This is notwithstanding the fact that the question of whether stock routes may or may not be claimed is presently before the courts.

It is to be clearly understood that it is the Government's firm intention to allow Aboriginal people to pursue their claims to land and for that land to be available under inalienable freehold title. It should be understood by everyone that this Government will not sit by and see Aboriginal rights whittled away by the pernicious acts of the Northern Territory Government, pastoralists, miners, cronies in the New Right and those people on the Opposition benches. This Party is committed to land rights and we will do everything, as long as we are on this side of the House, to improve the welfare and conditions of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. We will strengthen their claim to land rights as long as we are on this side of the House.

Let me say that to take away or in any way diminish the rights of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory would be a repressive and retrograde step upon which history would judge us harshly. History will judge honourable members opposite harshly. They are running with a group of people in our society whom I do not think they have properly examined. Honourable members opposite are running with people in the mining industry who produced the most racist set of advertisements ever to be produced in this community. These are the people the Opposition is running with; these are the people it is supporting; these are the people who terrified the people in Western Australia, and these are the people the Opposition is protecting by making the sorts of speeches that the previous two speakers made. I do not refer to the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), because I have travelled around with him and I think he is a person who is committed to his shadow portfolio.

It is clear from the voice of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory that they see their future as dependent upon their land being held securely by them under inalienable freehold title. This provides them with the opportunity to reassert control over their society and culture while at the same time participating in the economic development and exploitation of the resources of that land, when and where they regard it to be appropriate, and in a way which accords with their concerns about the protection of their physical and spiritual environment. We hear a lot of talk from the other side of the House about what Aboriginal people ought to be doing. But it seems to me that if people have no home, no shelter and no place to call their own, those people are indeed left with virtually nothing. We should establish a home for these people, a place that they can call their own-a place on the land which we took from them.

We drove them into the problems of petrol sniffing referred to by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). How did they get into that situation? How did the children in those regions he talked about become petrol sniffers? It was because they were driven off their land and put into settlements and were not able to cope with the sort of society in which they found themselves. The question of land grants is fundamental to that society being able to get out of the dilemma that it is currently in, for those people to claw their way back, to regain their culture and the structure of their own society. It is incumbent upon the Australian nation to at last come to some reconciliation with Aboriginal people as the prior owners of Australia. That is what they were; they were the owners of this country, and now we have driven them into the furthest corners of the Northern Territory and the States. But we have an amendment Bill before the House which strengthens the original Act, giving Aboriginals greater control over their own lives and, I believe, a greater chance to further their future as a community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take part in this debate because I believe that it touches on people who are suffering, and have suffered for many years, great deprivation. Much of my political concern has been to bring about the reforms of public policy necessary to remove the causes of poverty. Only by removing the causes of poverty will all people be able to live with dignity, self-respect and security in an economic, social and environmental sense. The majority of the causes of poverty in Australia, and, I guess, in many other countries as well, has been institutionalised by the legislation of parliaments-in this country by the legislation of State and Commonwealth parliaments. Governments all too often institutionalise these causes-and the present Labor Government has been no exception-and then claim the credit for providing relief from the poverty they have caused, or perpetuated, by failing to introduce fair and equitable tax and social security policies and policies across the whole range of issues that affects the people they govern.

SPEECH.PARA: The relief that is provided, then, is palliative. It infrequently cures, and rarely removes, the causes of poverty. Large numbers of Aboriginals are caught in this kind of poverty trap. They suffer a double disadvantage-the disadvantage arising out of the way they were treated and dispossessed prior to the 1967 referendum and the disadvantage arising from the total or partial abdication of responsibility by the States for their Aboriginal citizens. The Commonwealth has sought to grapple with the many intractable problems of providing for these people standards and opportunities equal to those available to the rest of the Australian community.

Sadly, I believe that the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill does too little and it comes later than it could have come. The Australian Labor Party and certain radical Aboriginal leaders, who in each case put self-interest ahead of the interests of the people of the Northern Territory and the Aboriginal people in particular, have caused a four-to-five year delay in the implementation of a number of the measures contained in this Bill. In 1982, when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I announced on behalf of the then Government that we proposed to amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act of 1976. The amendments were part of a package of proposals which had been discussed over the previous 14 months with the Northern Territory Government and the Northern and Central Land Councils. The package included legislation to be introduced by both the Northern Territory and Commonwealth governments. The package finally proposed was a package of reforms, agreed between myself as the Minister and the then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, who is now the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham). We agreed, we achieved a balance and it was a true compromise. It would have made genuine and real progress for some very deprived Aborigines, progress which the Minister now says he hopes this legislation will bring about quickly. One of the reasons why there was not progress at all in 1982 was that the Labor Party failed to see that the proposal then agreed between the elected Northern Territory and the Commonwealth Government was a true balance of interests.

Talking of a balance of interests, I refer to the fact that, while I was the Minister, it was determined that there should be published a booklet explaining in full the proposals that had been agreed to. So vehement, however, was the opposition from the Labor Party that it was decided not to proceed with the package which would have resolved a large number of the problems that the Minister says he has had great success in solving over the past four years. Had the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and his colleagues only read the proposals and attempted to understand the progress that could have been made, many of the now very poor Aborigines in the Northern Territory would have achieved security of tenure in relation to their land long before now. The Fraser Government believed that the proposals would have benefited a large number of Aboriginal people and that their implementation would have reduced the significant tension that was emerging within the population of the Northern Territory.

As the proposals were shaped into legislation we promised that consultations with the land councils in the Northern Territory would continue and that discussions would be held with those communities and people who were clearly affected by it. As I have said, the package involved a balance of interests. The land rights legislation has a direct impact on the lives of many people. Changes to that legislation, then as now, had to be judged against the wider background of creating and sustaining a community in which legitimate and sometimes competing interests could live and work together without unnecessary tension and conflict. It must be remembered that in the Northern Territory the in excess of 100,000 people include people from all backgrounds, people who want to live there in peace and harmony, living out their own lives with independence and security and within a framework which relieves them from being forced into poverty. It was the Fraser Government's view that the proposals taken as a whole provided a substantial advantage and benefit to a large number of Aborigines living in the Northern Territory. It also believed that the proposals would overcome a major cause of tension and opposition to the land rights legislation, opposition which has escalated since the Labor Party came into government. In terms of community acceptance, we now have a much greater problem than we had in 1982. We could have made that progress and significantly reduced the level of tension if only Government members had then supported the changes that had been agreed to by the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth.

We also believed that the proposals would overcome those problems, and to this end we sought to remove a cloud over the social life of the economic development of the Northern Territory by removing the uncertainty as to how much of the Northern Territory would become Aboriginal land. One of the objectives of granting land rights was to achieve a greater degree of social harmony and stability within the wider community by removing as far as possible the legitimate causes of complaint of an important minority group within that community. It was the view of the then Government that, if the tensions then existing were permitted to grow unchecked, the Aborigines of the Northern Territory would be adversely affected, as I believe they have been over the last four years. This is just what has occurred as a consequence of the Labor Party's then expressed opposition to the legislation and to the implementation of the agreement entered into between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory

In 1974 Mr Justice Woodward presented to the Government of the day his recommendations on the appropriate means to recognise and grant land rights to the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory. The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, which was enacted in 1976, was based in large part on the recommendations of Mr Justice Woodward. In 1979 the Commonwealth Government commissioned Mr Barry Rowland, QC, to examine concerns about the practical operation of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. Mr Rowland reported in 1980 indicating several issues which he considered the Government should examine and decide upon. These issues included the conversion of Aboriginal-owned pastoral leases to Aboriginal land and claims to stock routes. He did not recommend what policy decision should be made, but only that there was a need for decision. Following examination of the Rowland report, my predecessor as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, convened a meeting in March 1981 at which he, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and the three chairmen of the Aboriginal land councils, discussed whether there might be some consensus about aspects of the Act or relevant Northern Territory legislation. The meeting acknowledged that there were matters of genuine concern to various groups within the Northern Territory community resulting from the operation of the Act and that there would be merit in discussing these matters further. Further discussions resulted eventually in the preparation by the Northern Territory of a draft proposal. That proposal was submitted to the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council in August 1981.

In August the Northern Land Council accepted the principles of the draft proposal. It further resolved that its representatives should be involved in the development of detailed drafting instructions and that the Council should be given the opportunity to have any draft legislation submitted to it before presentation to Parliament or to the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory. The Central Land Council, on the other hand, neither accepted nor rejected the draft proposal at that time, but indicated that it wanted to continue to be involved in the discussions and would participate in the development of detailed drafting instructions. A working party, comprising officials from the Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments and the chairmen and lawyers of the Northern and Central Land Councils, was established to draw up detailed drafting instructions. The Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments made it know to the land councils that they intended to continue negotiations with them on the preparation of the actual legislation to give effect to the draft proposals. Such negotiations were planned to ensure that the land councils were aware of the form of the legislation prior to its introduction into the Commonwealth and Northern Territory parliaments.

Let me now summarise the proposals that were agreed for legislation. The Northern Territory Government agreed that it would legislate, firstly, to provide a process by which Aborigines now living on pastoral properties could have excised areas for living purposes under perpetual title. It proposed that an independent tribunal headed by a judge of the Northern Territory Supreme Court would help to resolve any deadlock or conflict between the pastoral lessee and the Aboriginal applicants seeking areas to be excised. That process of excision under that framework could have begun in 1982 and been much further advanced than it is now had the Labor Party supported the package of proposals. Secondly, the Northern Territory Government agreed that it would legislate to provide perpetual title to Aboriginals who purchased pastoral leases in the future on the open market. To the extent that there were special conditions favouring the lessee that would apply in relation to mining activities on those leases, and where the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs approved, the Commonwealth, in the case of those perpetual leases, agreed that, if it were necessary as a condition of the grant of lease that there be some form of guarantee, the Commonwealth would underwrite the performance of the covenants of any Aboriginal leaseholder.

Thirdly, the Northern Territory undertook to legislate a grant of title to Aboriginal trustees in respect of Northern Territory parks to which valid claims had already been lodged and at the same time preserve the land for park purposes. Fourthly, the Northern Territory agreed to legislate to provide a grant of perpetual title over the Uluru National Park. In addition, the Northern Territory agreed by public assurances that it would not alienate any land which had been claimed without prior consultation with the relevant land council and that it would not prevent the transfer of pastoral leases to Aboriginals who may wish to purchase them in the future on the open market. Any subsequent alienation was a consequence of the fact that it was clear that the legislation that the Commonwealth undertook to bring into this Parliament would not pass because it would have lacked the support of the Labor Party. Realising that the package of agreements to balance the interests of the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory and the interests of the Aboriginal communities and those of the pastoralists and the miners, in a way that would have made progress, would not come into legislative form, the Northern Territory chose to exercise the full powers that had been given to it at the time of the grant of self-government.

For its part, the Commonwealth undertook to amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act to do three things: Firstly, to eliminate provisions for traditional land claims to pastoral or other leases held by or on behalf of Aboriginals with the exception of claims already lodged over pastoral leases up to 3 June 1982. Secondly, the Commonwealth agreed to remove the provision for the hearing of land claims over stock routes, stock reserves and other areas declared as public purpose areas under Northern Territory legislation. Thirdly, the Commonwealth was going to legislate to remove the provision for the hearing of any land claims in relation to Territory national parks.

I turn in the few minutes remaining to me to expand upon one or two elements of the Commonwealth's agreement in respect of that package. I turn first to the question of claims in respect of pastoral leases owned by Aboriginals, a conspicuous lack in this legislation. Yet in 1982 there was agreement and the matter could well then have been resolved, particularly in relation to purchases of pastoral leases by Ab- originals from that date on. The difficulty arising from the earlier legislation is that Aboriginals who hold or purchase pastoral leases can have their properties claimed by other Aboriginals who assert traditional links with that land. This situation arose in cases such as Borroloola and Beetaloo. In these cases if the lessees had been non-Aboriginals the Act would have protected their land from such claims. Neither the Commonwealth nor the Northern Territory opposed the idea of Aboriginals purchasing pastoral properties. The Commonwealth had encouraged the purchase of such properties through the use of funds provided, firstly, by the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission and, more recently, by the Aboriginal Development Commission, but the progressive conversion of pastoral leases to Ab- original land does not remove those properties from the commercial market and the extent to which the elected Government can--
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Liberal Party-Streetwize Comics-Australian Defence Force Exercise, Kangaroo 86-Administrative Appeals Tribunal: Charges for Referring Tax Appeals-Food Irradiation-Tasmania-HMVS Cerberus-Mr Joseph Adamov-Afghanistan-Seminar on Adult Education in Finland

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last few days there has been a great deal of speculation in the newspapers about leadership challenges within the Liberal Party. I know that it is very hard to believe, but I went to a bit of trouble tonight to find some information about the major contenders on the other side. I found out that, since the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) replaced the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) as Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong has made only 16 speeches in the House whereas, surprisingly, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has made 70. I think that is pretty typical, and I would like to quote to the House from an article in the Australian on 14 November 1986 under the heading `Jim Carlton: the new force in the Liberal Party':

SPEECH.PARA: There is a new force in the Liberal Party-a man whose ideas are now starting to dominate the Opposition coalition and who is potentially the most influential figure on the conservative side of politics.
It is not Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, John Howard or Andrew Peacock.

Rather, it is the honourable member for Mackellar. I would like to throw forward the name of the honourable member for Mackellar as Leader of the Opposition and, in order to help him along, I have put together what I consider to be a reasonable sort of shadow ministry for him. There are three criteria that I used in selecting my ministry: Firstly, as many as possible had to be from New South Wales and they must not have served on the front bench under the honourable member for Bennelong. Secondly, they must have a commitment to the policies of the New Right and, thirdly, they must have obvious hidden talent-hidden because nobody has seen it to date. The honourable member for Mackellar, Leader of the Opposition; the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), Attorney-General; the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman), Treasurer; the honourable member of Warringah (Mr MacKellar), Territories; the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), Primary Industry; the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), Health; the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson): Education and Youth Affairs; Senator Michael Baume, Finance and Taxation-that is one for my friend the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis); Senator Chris Puplick, Trade; the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson), Transport and Aviation; the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), Aboriginal Affairs; the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), Special Minister of State-because he likes doing the job of the Special Minister of State for our side; the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), Social Security-and fix the assets test; the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), Industry, Technology and Commerce; the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), Communications and the Media; the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), Northern Development and Local Government; the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), Foreign Affairs; the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), Small Business and Administrative Services; the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), Defence-because he likes to tell the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) what to do with his submarines; the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), Sport, Recreation and Tourism-because he obviously has some talent there; the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), Veterans' Affairs; Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, Employment and Industrial Relations-because obviously she has had a very good tutor; Senator Parer, Resources and Energy-because he comes from a background in that field and because we have not had any questions on resources and energy that I can remember in the two years that I have been a member of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is he?

—Well you might ask. Finally, Senator Susan Knowles, Community Services and the Status of Women. There is an alternative to the front bench that we have seen in operation in this House over the last 12 months.
—What about White?

—I must admit to my colleagues on this side of the House that, when I was going through the list, there were some potential candidates that I thought the honourable member for Mackellar would like on this front bench. Then I thought: `No, we will balance it up'. I thought that if we put New South Welshmen there in the main they would protect his interests, because we from New South Wales tend to stick together and people know this. I thought that, if we balanced it up with a smattering of people from around the countryside, at least there would be some representation. We have to be a little careful when selecting people from some of the other areas because talent, we have to admit, is not all that thick on the ground on the other side.
—It is thick.

—Perhaps it is thick. I have made this as a constructive criticism because, in all the talk about leadership challenges on the other side, reference keeps going back to the honourable member for Kooyong. Quite honestly, I ask honourable members to consider how many times we have seen him on his feet in recent times-never. He has put 264 questions on the Notice Paper, but very rarely do we see him on his feet in the House. Rather, he is content to sit back and see other people talk about leadership challenges. The article in the Australian, as I have indicated, is a very true reflection of the position and is something to which honourable members on the other side should give some consideration. If they are counting heads and looking to get rid of the temporary Leader of the Opposition, perhaps the honourable member for Mackellar offers the alternative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the House to a Press release issued by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), dated 10 November 1986. This Press release trumpeted the launching by the Minister of two special Canberra editions of a publication entitled Streetwize comics-one on drugs and the other on sexually transmitted diseases. The Minister was lavish with his praise for those comics. He said that they provided useful health information in a format which is easy to read and entertaining. He said that the comics presented story situations which are real life and simple to understand, rather than the more traditional and bureaucratic ways which have often been shown to switch off young people.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the kinds of messages being conveyed by Streetwize comics to our teenage and sub-teenage children-messages which are enthusiastically endorsed by the Minister for Health. The special health issue comic conveys the impression that it is acceptable behaviour for youngsters to mainline drugs so long as they use their own needles. In one scene a teenager says to his friend: `Did you know you can get AIDS through needles?' The friend replies: `Yeah, man, that's why I have my own needle! They're cheap-worth it!'. Girls reading these comics will learn that taking pills for fun is okay, but if they take them all the time they may become addicted and boring.

I could give more graphic accounts of some of the material in the comics which the Minister for Health says provide young people with accurate health information. However, I consider some of the material to be pop pornography and would be likely to offend the sensibilities of honourable members were I to describe some of the more explicit material. In fact, the Minister, in promoting Streetwize comics, appears to have committed an offence under section 19 (4) a of the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications (Amendment) Ordinance 1984. Section 38 of that Ordinance provides for a fine of up to $5,000 for a corporation and $1,000 for an individual.

Streetwize comics have covered eight topics to date and have upset the people of Geelong, my constituents in Corangamite and the public elsewhere when their children have been targeted with this material. The comics were even distributed in show bags at the Geelong Show in October, ending up in the hands of children in the 6 years to 13 years age group. Streetwize comics have been rightly described as garbage comics. In one issue the police are drawn as pigs and depicted as brutal savages, child bashers, bullies, stand-over merchants and ignorant fools. All of this and more has been provided by Federal and State Labor governments with the taxpayers' money.

Geelong's Chief Superintendent of Police, Max Porter, accurately described the comics as denigrating, damaging, insulting and incorrect. He said that they disturbed and disappointed him as they encouraged youths to be aware of ways to get in and out of trouble, rather than how to behave. It concerned him that the comics did not aim to educate youth on what the community accepted as correct social behaviour. The Chief Superintendent's stance was supported by an editorial in the Geelong Advertiser which stated that police have a right to be angry about a government-funded comic which depicts police with pigs' heads as youth bashers and intimidators. The Geelong Advertiser rightly determined that advice was not the issue; rather, the issue was the manner in which the creators of the comics chose to get across their message-including denigration of the police force by portraying it as being staffed by pigs.

These are the causes that Streetwize comics espouse and which the Federal Minister for Health enthusiastically endorses. This is not surprising, given the notoriety he has achieved as the Minister for marihuana following his advocacy of the decriminalisation of marihuana. His championing of Streetwize comics is but another example of how this Minister and community activists can increase the burden of the disadvantaged-ensuring they stay that way-and drag young people, who might otherwise lead normal lives, into the gutter. The Minister, of course, has got it all wrong again. Not only has he erred, but his enthusiasm to embrace the grubby and discredited Streetwize comics has led him into conflict with a senior fellow Minister, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis).

I have here a copy of a letter received from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, dated 7 November 1986, in response to my inquiry about Federal funds being used to help fund such a disreputable publication. I was told, in effect, that the Federal Government ceased to support Streetwize comics when the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations became aware of concerns over the content and language used in the comic. To the credit of the Minister, he expressed his attitude about two years ago to representations about Street- wize comics. I quote what he said:
. . . I share the concern expressed by your constituent that projects of this kind do not have broad community support . . .
He said further:
As noted earlier C.E.P. funding has now ended and . . . the comic will not receive further C.E.P. funding in the future.
How much longer should the Australian people have to tolerate a Federal Minister for Health who is out of step with broad community values-a Minister who is, in effect, a health hazard?
