SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 and 8 November 1986 I had the privilege of visiting the Australian Defence Force exercise, Kangaroo 86. It was the major Australian Defence Force exercise for 1986. It was a great success and involved over 6,000 personnel from all three services. K86 was the first deployment of the complete operational deployment force since its formation in 1980. Previous exercises, such as Swift Eagle, have been only at battalion group level. This operation was based on a low level threat scenario, along similar lines to the more likely types of contingencies stated in the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The exercise scenario had been developed progressively over many months. The scenario outlined was that Orangeland, a mythical island nation situated 2,000 kilometres north-east of Australia, felt that Australia was conducting its export of resources at the expense of Orangeland. The Orangeland head of state, President Walup, decided that direct action against the whole export infrastructure in the Bowen Basin was the best way of teaching Australia a lesson. Our intelligence community was able to find out about these intentions and the operational deployment force was therefore warned for deployment. In the third week of October this year Orangeland's 7012 Raider Company was air landed in the Bowen Basin. This force immediately commenced preparation and reconnaissance for raids on key points within the coal export infrastructure such as export mines, railways and the coal loading facilities in Gladstone. The scene was set for battle.

The operational deployment force brigade, comprising 3,400 personnel, is the major combat element of the ODF and was deployed by air and road into the area of operation in the Bowen Basin. This brigade is based on the 3rd Brigade, Lavarack Barracks, Townsville. The initial area of operations of the ODF brigade covered an area of about 100,000 square kilometres. To illustrate the size of the operational area, Tasmania is but 68,350 square kilometres. The area extended from west of Emerald, east to the outskirts of Gladstone, north to the Norwich Park mine and south to Moura. A second area of operation was used for the final few days of the exercise. This area was much smaller and covered the Shoalwater Bay training area and some adjacent properties.

The 42nd Battalion of the Royal Queensland Regiment-an Army Reserve infantry battalion based in the Mackay, Rockhampton and Gladstone region-was allotted to the ODF brigade for K86. Its performance was outstanding and was a further example of integration between the regular and reserve elements of the Army. The first elements of the brigade arrived in the area of operations about 24 hours after receiving the order to deploy. In the first 48 hours the majority of the brigade's combat elements were deployed and operating within the area. Full deployment was completed within 96 hours. The speed of the deployment caught the enemy by surprise and gave the brigade a significant morale and tactical advantage. The brigade's mission was to support the civil authority by protecting the coal export infrastructure and conducting offensive operations to clear the enemy from the Bowen Basin area. This mission was successfully achieved.

I now make some general comments regarding the exercise. I refer, firstly, to the interaction with the Queensland police. As a state of war was not declared, the civil authority remained paramount. The involvement of the Queensland police at all levels from land force headquarters down to individual section patrols and road blocks was fundamental to the conduct of these operations. The brigade and the police quickly established an excellent rapport and were able to mutually support each other to achieve the mission.

Secondly, I refer to the civil community. Unlike many Australian Defence Force exercises in the past, which have been conducted almost exclusively on military training areas or in sparsely populated areas, K86 was conducted within the civil community. The civil community became actively involved in the exercise and proved to be a prime source of intelligence on enemy movements and activities. The exercise would not have been so successful without the support of the civil community.

Thirdly, I refer to air support. The exercise proved the fundamental need for the brigade to have control of its supporting Royal Australian Air Force transport assets. Having operational control of the Tactical Air Support Force enabled the Brigade to react quickly to reports of enemy activity. It also enabled the rapid evacuation of real and exercise casualties. Fourthly, there is logistic support. The ODF's policy on logistic support was to make maximum use of the existing civil infrastructure where possible. This not only reduced the burden on the Brigade and Logistic Support Group transport assets but added a considerable boost to the local economy, particularly that of Emerald.

Finally, Exercise 86 proved the viability of the ODF in a low level scenario and was valuable in that it confirmed the relationship and procedures as described in the exercise objectives. I congratulate Major-General L. G. O'Donnell, Commander, Land Force; Brigadier M. J. Harris, MC, Commander, 3rd Brigade; Group-Captain L. B. Fisher, Commander, ODF Tactical Air Support Force; and Lieutenant-Colonel G. J. Kells, Commander, 1st Logistic Support Group, and all other members of the Australian Defence Force involved in Exercise Kangaroo 86 on their outstanding and professional achievement. I say to them: Australia is proud of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently there was an increase in charges for referring tax appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from $2 to $200. The Commissioner of Taxation has argued that this is a reasonable mechanism to dissuade taxpayers from lodging trivial claims. However, in my view such an approach is too simplistic, given that many minor difficulties facing taxpayers arise from the ineptness and bad administration which sadly occurs far too often in the Australian Taxation Office.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me cite one example that has come to my attention. In a joint return of income for the year ended 30 June 1982, a taxpayer and his wife disclosed interest income of $5,589.83 from a semi-government authority. On 22 March 1985, almost three years later, the Tax Office forwarded a letter seeking details from the taxpayer's wife in regard to the interest payments. These details were forwarded by the taxpayer's tax agent on 10 April 1985, very quickly, pointing out that the interest had been disclosed in that earlier return. An amount of $1,020 had been paid by the semi-government authority for the year ended 30 June 1982 but was not received by the taxpayer until 5 July 1982. Contrary to the principle that income derived from interest is assessable on receipt in the hands of the taxpayer, the Commissioner included the $1,020 in the return of income for the year ended 30 June 1982. Although the Commissioner adjusted the 1982-83 return, he made no adjustment with respect to the amount in the 1982-83 year. Thus the Commissioner maintained assessments against the taxpayer in regard to the same amount of interest in both years of income.

The taxpayer's agent requested the Commissioner to make a corresponding adjustment, decreasing the amount of income returned by the taxpayer during the year ended 30 June 1983. As a result of this adjustment, the difference in the amount of additional income from which tax would become payable by the taxpayer was a mere $13.86. In the taxpayer's return of income for the year ended 30 June 1982, an additional amount of $510 was included, being the difference between the amount previously disclosed and the total amount received by the taxpayer; that is, the $1,020. In respect of that additional amount, penalty-believe it or not-of $225.58 was imposed by way of notice of assessment dated 15 April 1986. By an adjustment sheet received by the taxpayer on 21 April 1986, the Commissioner responded to the taxpayer's agent's letter of 13 October 1985, reducing the amount of income returned during the year ended 30 June 1983 by $1,020. By a subsequent adjustment sheet for the year ended 30 June 1983, the taxpayer's assessment for that year was reduced by $510. By an amended assessment dated 18 June 1986 issued with respect to the year ended 30 June 1983, a credit was granted to the taxpayer of $234.60 in respect to the adjustment to his return, being a refund on the tax overpaid.

I have listed a large number of dates and a large number of amounts. Honourable members may not be able to absorb them, but it will be on record. The end result is that this saga has continued. Time does not allow me to detail all matters relating to correspondence between the taxpayer's agent and the Commissioner. In summary I point out that if the Commissioner does not make the relevant adjustment in order to receive a diminution of the penalty it will cost the taxpayer $200 to refer the matter to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and that does not include any professional cost. Sadly, in too many ways this matter exemplifies the manner in which the Taxation Office conducts its activities all too often.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am compelled, yet again, to raise in this House the matter of the introduction of food irradiation into Australia. Australian consumers are having thrust upon them irradiation of food using radioactive cobalt 60. The Australian Consumers Association is currently conducting an inquiry over a six-month period on a shoestring budget of $90,000. How can the ACA be expected to deal adequately with the food irradiation subject against the massive resources actively promoting food irradiation in Australia and throughout the world?

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Atomic Energy Commission is committing Australian resources in the active promotion of food irradiation. The question must be asked: Are the relevant Ministers aware of this promotion? If so, do they approve? Answers are urgently needed. Australian consumers are entitled to know. I ask the following questions: Who authorised Australian Government expenditure of $US260,000 in financial support for the second phase of the Asian regional co-operative project on food irradiation for three years in 1985? Who authorised Australian participation in this regional project on food irradiation? Was the Australian representative Dr Pamela A. Wills of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's Isotope Division? Were there other representatives of the Australian Government? If so, who were they and who authorised their attendance? On what basis did the Australian Government or its representative endorse or agree to promote acceptance of the codex standard and code of practice on food irradiation? Is the Australian Atomic Energy Commission de facto responsible for the introduction of food regulations, including food irradiation regulations, into Australia?

Was the Food Standards Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council still considering possible food irradiation regulations at the time the Atomic Energy Commission agreed to promote acceptance of the codex standard on food irradiation? How does the Atomic Energy Commission explain or justify this undermining of the responsible authority? Were the Ministers aware of this undermining? Who authorised the irradiation at 6 to 8 kilogray of contaminated frozen shrimp in Australia during the period from 11 September to 16 October 1978? Where in Australia were the shrimp irradiated? What was the total quantity of contaminated shrimp that was irradiated? Where were the irradiated shrimp marketed and were they identified as having been irradiated? In the list of clearances in the general survey of irradiated food products cleared for human consumption in some countries, including Australia, were some 61 food products decontaminated by irradiation? Does this indicate that food irradiation will be used to clean up contaminated food?

A recent publication titled `Marketing and Communication Guidelines for Acceptance and Usage of Food Irradiation', put out by the international consultative group on food irradiation, is yet another reason to believe that the Australian Consumers Association inquiry will be totally inadequate to match the power and push of the international nuclear club which is hellbent on forcing food irradiation on an unsuspecting Australian consumer community. The international consultative group on food irradiation meeting in Vienna on 14 to 19 September this year set as its overall objective to `achieve the approval, acceptance and usage of food irradiation on a world wide basis'. This high-powered international group has laid out its marketing plan even targeting Government Ministers at a personal level, and special programs have been developed and tailored to meet needs of individual countries. The question must be asked: Who is the Australian representative? Is the Australian representative contributing to the developing marketing strategies and targeting Government Ministers in a global push to introduce food irradiation into Australia? Further, to whom is the Australian representative responsible, if anyone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say just a few words tonight about my beloved home, Tasmania. If I asked the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), who is at the table, what he would like Tasmania to be called, what would he say? Would he say the Apple Isle? Everything in this world needs a hook. Everywhere I go everybody refers to Tasmania as the Apple Isle. It seems to have been forgotten by everybody, but if we listen to cricket commentators we hear them say, for example: `David Boon from the Apple Isle'. It is always listed in tourist booklets as the Apple Isle. Yet, regrettably people in Tasmania are trying to change that image. I have always been a firm believer that, if we have a hook we stay with it. Once we lose that hook we lose the image and the identity of the lovely place from which I and the honour- able member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) come. Beloved Tasmania, a little island with a population of 400,000 will always be known to us as the Apple Isle. The honourable member for Denison represented the Tasmanian apple industry in the Huon Valley which is synonymous with beautiful apples. Now I represent it as the Federal member for that area. Rest assured that I will always push Tasmania as the Apple Isle. I will never call it anything else, for example, the golden isle, the pearl or whatever people call it--
—The treasure island.

—Or the treasure isle. The trouble with this modern world is that we always get these so-called experts from the mainland-thank God that we have lost a few-who always come to Tasmania to try to change the face of it. They try to change what it is to something else. Regrettably, it just does not work.
—They hate us just for being what we are.

—They do. They hate us just for being what we are. But we will never be deterred. My good friend the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) is also in the House tonight. He knows what I mean by the lovely image of the Apple Isle. Let me just say something about parochialism. I am not a parochial politician but we have to stop parochialism in Tasmania. It is divided between the north and the south. Even the Australian Broadcasting Corporation representatives are smiling. That is something. Parochialism just has to stop between the north and south of Tasmania. Regrettably, politicians have become parish pumps in Tasmania. They seem to think that, by running down the north, they will get votes in the south. The two newspapers, the Hobart Mercury and the Examiner fight each other just for a parochial point of view. United we will win; disunited in Tasmania we cannot hope to win.

SPEECH.PARA: Just getting on to a more serious note, today the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) mentioned the Prices Surveillance Authority. It was news to me that we are going to get rid of the Prices Surveillance Authority but it is probably a good thing. Let me just relate something that is very important to the people of Tasmania and Australia. The Prices Surveillance Authority is just an instrument of the Government set up in a corner about which we can say: `Oh, it fixes the prices. It does this and it does that so, therefore, it must be right'. The Prices Surveillance Authority fixes a maximum wholesale price for petrol throughout Australia. Oil companies can go to the Prices Surveillance Authority individually and say to it `We need an increase', and they get the increase individually. All oil companies have different wholesale prices. That is fine. Everybody thinks it is a great idea to have a maximum wholesale price throughout Australia. Regrettably, the oil companies have the ability, when there is a glut of petrol in, say Melbourne or Sydney, to drop the price below the maximum wholesale price sometimes to the extent of about 10 cents a litre. Regrettably, that is the reason why people are looking at the Prices Surveillance Authority and they are saying: `What the dickens is it doing? It recommends a price but the oil companies drop below that price'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose side is it on?
—I do not know whose side it is on. Regrettably, it does not help the Tasmanian people or our beloved isle, which will remain the Apple Isle forever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This year, 1986, is the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy. But long before the formation of our Navy the mighty iron-clad man of war and flagship of the Victorian Navy had spent many years protecting Victoria. I am quite certain that it would have protected Tasmania if Tasmania had wanted it to. The ship, of course, was the Cerberus. In September 1870 Cerberus was completed. She was the first British battleship to have a low free board, breast-work protection, a central superstructure, a central superstructure with fore and aft turrets and, very importantly, she was the first ship in which sail power was dispensed with. This ship has worldwide significance in the history of naval architecture. She is now the only surviving vessel of her type in the world. Let me read a few extracts from the Argus of 10 April 1871. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The arrival in Hobson's Bay yesterday afternoon of the `Cerberus' monitor will be generally accepted as extremely welcome news. It is now over four years since we got the first intimation that we should have her for our protection, and at last she lies at anchor in our waters, one of the most powerful vessels for harbour defence in the world.

. . . until the 29th October, when the `Cerberus' got under way at daylight, and left Sheerness for Plymouth. She had a fair start, but when in the Downs, a gale of wind came on, and her lower decks were regularly washed out. The men were up to their knees in water and had to bale, for it was found that there were no pumps, and the ship would not steer. Something was the matter with her boilers-she would not steam; her rudder did not act properly and she proceeded at the mild rate of one and a half knots, in almost every direction but the right one.
It sounds likes the Liberal Party of Australia. The article continues:
Under these discouraging circumstances, and with a crew of only 25 men, Captain Panter put into Spithead, in order to stop awhile at Portsmouth.

He had to rake the back slums of London before he could get sailors who would go, and he then telegraphed to the Victorian emigration agent at Plymouth to get men ready against his coming to that Port, and in that way he got his crew comparatively alright. Before this he had caused about 50 men to be put in prison, they preferring to go to gaol rather than fulfil their engagement and go to sea in a turret vessel.

. . . on November 20th and got to Malta on the 27th, where, as before, she was much visited and among others by the two Admirals and every captain in the fleet. On the afternoon of the day of arrival two-thirds of the ship's company got on shore and set to drinking. The end of which was that 25 men were left behind in prison.
That is, in Malta. The article continues:

The Bay seemed all alive as she entered Hobson's Bay, and she was the centre of observation. The Russian man-of-war the `Haydamack' dipped ensign to her and Captain Koltovsky hurried on board the `Cerberus' to pay his compliments to their Commander. The boys of H.M.V.S. `Nelson' crowded into the rigging of their ship and made the air ring again and peals of boyish cheers, as the monster steamed past; and nearly every vessel in the Bay hastened to pay the compliment of dipping colours.

The preservation and restoration of the HMVS Cerberus provides an opportunity for local, State and Federal governments to work together to create a bicentennial memorial of national and international significance. The proposal to restore this now unique warship certainly gains further significance in this seventy-fifth anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy. Experts' records indicate that the ship is still salvageable although, clearly, there has been some deterioration. It appears that, unless some prompt action is taken, the alternative for this piece of Australian history is to allow it to rust, become a hulk and collapse. I would like the Federal Government to assist in the funding of the restoration of the mighty Cerberus. Let me finish with a few words from a poem written by John Masefield. He wrote:
I touch my country's mind, I come to grips.
With half her purpose thinking of these ships . . .
They mark our passage as a race of men
Earth will not see such ships as those again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to condemn the Hawke socialist Government as even more pro-Soviet than the Lange Government in New Zealand. It gives me no pleasure to have to attack in this House the disgraceful and shameful decision of the Hawke socialist Government to allow the so-called Soviet political commentator, but in fact paid apologist, Comrade Joseph Adamov, into Australia. It is a classic example of crawling to Moscow, a classic example of appeasement by the Hawke socialist Government towards a murderous and criminal regime.

SPEECH.PARA: Comrade Adamov, who has been seen on Australian television sets far too often, is the public relations mouthpiece for the murderous Soviet regime which has turned the Eastern bloc into the world's largest concentration camp and which has been responsible for the slaughtering of over one million innocent people in Afghanistan. For the first time in my political career, I feel it my duty to praise publicly Prime Minister David Lange and the New Zealand Government for having the courage and the wisdom to refuse Adamov entry into their country. I note that the New Zealand Immigration Director, Mr Don Bond, is reported as having confirmed that Adamov's application for a visa was refused. Mr Bond added that visas can be refused on various grounds, including security. If New Zealand knocked back Comrade Adamov on security grounds, why has Australia let this evil man into this country?

By coincidence, in Canberra today the Australian Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International launched a new Amnesty publication entitled `Afghanistan: Torture of Political Prisoners'. I imagine that Comrade Adamov will smirk and sneer and dismiss this report as a figment of Western imperialist imagination and claim that it is a pack of lies. But, unfortunately for him, and indeed for the Soviet Union, some members of this Parliament, including me, have actually been to the borders of Afghanistan and spoken to victims of Soviet atrocities and victims of Soviet war crimes as bad as anything perpetrated by the nazis in World War II.

The report is a damning indictment of a cruel and heartless regime headed by Comrade Babrak Karmal, a puppet leader put there by Moscow and maintained by Moscow. It deals with torture of an 18-year-old girl student who was strapped into a chair to which electric wires were then attached, which chair was then rotated for between one to four hours per day for 15 days in a row. It details accounts of electric wires being attached to a young man so that he was given a succession of electric shocks. Finally, when the wires were attached to his tongue, he lost consciousness. It sets out in great detail the continuing vile torture and persecution of political prisoners in Afghanistan by the Soviet puppet regime.

Tonight I want to talk about some of the things I saw on the border of Afghanistan in 1984-things that I have not mentioned before in this Parliament. I mention them because this evening in Canberra a number of members of this House were very honoured to meet with Ambassador Edward L. Rowny, who is the special adviser to the President of the United States of America and Secretary of State for arms control matters. Ambassador Rowny has just come back from Reykjavik in Iceland, where he was present at the negotiations that took place between President Reagan and Party Secretary Gorbachev. Whilst most of the publicity has been on nuclear and conventional weapons, one matter raised with the Ambassador this evening at the United States Embassy was the question of the banning of chemical warfare.

In 1984 I saw, in the refugee hospital in Peshawar, not far from the border of Afghanistan, men who were victims of illegal chemical warfare. They were treated by German surgeons. The incidents were filmed and were shown on German television at the very same time as at the United Nations the Soviet Union lied to the world by continuing to claim that illegal chemical warfare was not being used in Afghanistan.

Ambassador Rowny is a very great and courageous man. He does not speak just for the United States. He speaks for the entire free Western world. How he can negotiate with a regime such as the Soviet Union, which is prepared to lie, lie and lie again on the use of illegal chemical warfare in Afghanistan, is absolutely beyond my comprehension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the parliamentary recess this year I attended a seminar on adult education in Finland. The Finnish Government, through the Finnish Association of Adult Education, has for a number of years conducted a seminar each year under the general theme `Meeting in Finland', where participants from the developed and developing world as well as from East and West meet to discuss issues of relevance to adult education and adult educators.

SPEECH.PARA: I was first privileged to attend this meeting in 1979, when the topic was the role of adult education in peace education. This year, appropriately in this the International Year of Peace, the topic was `Year of Peace-For the Sake of Life'. I congratulate the Finnish Government and the Finnish Association of Adult Education on organising this important seminar.

My congratulations also go to Helena Kekkonen, the Secretary-General, and her staff for their organisation of the seminar. Helena Kekkonen visited Australia in late 1984. She has also been awarded the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Peace Prize. Finland has a proud record in not only adult education but also peace education. It has an enviable record of assistance to the developing world and a proud record of opposition to repressive regimes.

The conference this year put emphasis on conditions in Southern Africa and we were privileged to have among us, as participants from South Africa, courageous men and women who have for their own safety had to leave their home in South Africa and live in neighbouring states. We met at Murike in central Finland, a beautiful spot beside a lake. These tranquil surroundings must have been a refreshing change from the brutal conditions in the homeland of the delegates from South Africa. The meeting concluded with the following appeal:
We, the educators from 29 different countries gathered at the `Meeting in Finland' seminar, June 8-14, 1986, have unanimously adopted the following appeal:

1. We express our serious and fundamental concern that violation of universally accepted human rights continues to prevent the accomplishment of the educational work, for example, the increase of literacy, education, cultural and democratic participation. We wish to emphasize the importance of educating children and adults for peace. In this connection we appeal to all governments and international agencies to give moral and material support to governmental and non-governmental institutions and organizations involved in peace education.

2. We are seriously concerned about the continuously increasing inequality between the industrialized and the developing countries. This creates inhuman conditions in the poorest countries. The massive arms expenditures of the industrialized countries should be, as soon as possible, reallocated to contribute to the solution of the problems of developing countries. In this connection we urge ratification of the SALT II nuclear arms agreement.

3. We are especially concerned about the growing critical situation in southern Africa which is due to the illegal presence of the South African Government in Namibia and its apartheid policy in South Africa. The conditions for human rights, education, peace and democracy are non-existent in these countries.

We appeal to the governments of the world to bring pressure to bear on the Government of South Africa by applying comprehensive economic sanctions and by cutting all political, diplomatic and cultural relationships with the apartheid government so that it would free all political prisoners, dismantle the apartheid system, withdraw its troops from the neighbouring countries and realize the UN Security Council resolution No. 435 for the independence of Namibia. All-round support and assistance should be given to the ANC and SWAPO in their efforts to achieve peace in that region.

As I have said, I have attended one of these seminars before in 1979 and again this year. I hope also to attend them in the coming years. I would like to see Australia develop a system of international seminars on such subjects as adult education. Indeed, I am on a committee organising such a seminar which will be part of our bicentennial celebrations in 1988. It is my hope that we can have as good a seminar as the two that I have attended in Finland and that we get as wide a representation of people as the meetings in Finland, with the same quality of discussion and friendship expressed here as I have always experienced in Finland.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Did he state in December 1984 that a Commonwealth Office block would be built in Newcastle; if so (a) when will it be commenced, (b) what will it cost and (c) when will it be completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The construction of a Commonwealth Centre at Newcastle has been under consideration for some time. The need for a Commonwealth Centre remains and in order to meet the immediate needs, particularly the expanding needs of the Australian Taxation Office, my Department is pursuing a pre-commitment lease development for some 14,000 square metres of office space.
(a) Tenders for this development are to be called in the near future and construction is expected to commence following a decision on the successful tender.
(b) Costs are unknown at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which Defence Establishments in Australia provide free parking?
(2) How many parking spaces are there at each establishment?
(3) Is the provision of free parking spaces at Defence establishments considered to be a fringe benefit? If so, what is the:
(a) attributed value of a free car parking space for fringe benefit tax purposes?
(b) how is it calculated; and
(c) what is the estimated revenue for:
(ii) full year.
for the fringe benefits tax on free parking spaces at Defence establishments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(3) Car parking space provided by employers for use by employees is exempt from Fringe Benefit Tax.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 21 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many departmental or other officers visited overseas countries, including the USA, to recruit air traffic controllers and what was the cost of their visits.
(2) How many individuals were recruited and what was the cost of their transfers to Australia.
(3) What retraining was given to those recruited and how much did it cost.
(4) Was the previous experience of the recruited air traffic controllers taken into consideration in the provision of retraining; if not, why not.
(5) How many recruits have since returned to the USA or elsewhere and for what reasons.
(6) Who paid for the return and resettlement of recruits who have left Australia and what are the details of any costs incurred.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During financial year 1981/82 two officers from the Department of Aviation visited the United States of America to recruit USA Air Traffic Controllers. Cost details of their visit are as follows:
There have been no visits by Departmental officers to overseas countries to recruit Air Traffic Controllers since the above visit.

(2) A total of 44 Air Traffic Controllers have been recruited from the United States of America. Resource constraints prevent the Department from providing detailed information on transfer costs. Organisation and funding of air tickets, air freight and settling out allowances was provided by the Australian Embassy, Washington. It has not been possible to determine what funds transferred to the Australian Embassy during financial years 1981/82 and 1982/83 were used for ATC Recruitment purposes. It is known that an average cost of $8000 per trainee/family was used to calculate funds required by the Embassy to transfer the last 8 trainees/families to Australia. It is therefore estimated that the transfer costs for a total of 44 trainees/families was approximately $352,000.

(3) All USA trainees completed a 12 month training course known as Short Term Direct Entry Training. This training was conducted at an average cost of about $25,000 per trainee. Included in this cost is trainees salary, travel allowance and airfare to final field postings. Not included in this cost is instructors salaries and the value of depreciation to buildings and training simulators.

(4) The previous experience of USA Air Traffic Controllers was taken into consideration and they were subsequently placed on Short Term Direct Entry Training Courses rather than the three year Long Term Training Course for trainees with no previous aviation experience. The Short Term course consists of two major phases; 6 months theoretical and practical (simulator) training followed by 6 months practical training at a major Air Traffic Control Centre. It should be noted that Australian Air Traffic Control differs from that operated in the United States with methods and procedures such as Operation Control being unique to Australian Air Traffic Control.

(5) 16 ex-USA Air Traffic Controllers and families elected to be repatriated to the United States at Departmental expense. The reasons for their separation from the Department are not known. 6 ex-USA Air Traffic Controllers resigned before completion of 3 years employment and were ineligible to be repatriated at Departmental expense. It is not known if they returned to the USA.

(6) The Department of Aviation has paid for 16 Air Traffic Controllers and families to return to the USA. The total cost of repatriation, ie. airfares, freight and settling out expenses of 13 families has been $156,873.87. The remaining 3 Air Traffic Controllers and their families were repatriated in the last 3 months and final costs are not yet known.
